title: The Frog and The Ox
author: Aesop's Fables
content: An Ox came down to a reedy pool to drink. As he splashed heavily into the water, he crushed a young Frog into the mud. The old Frog soon missed the little one and asked his brothers and sisters what had become of him. "A great big monster," said one of them, "stepped on little brother with one of his huge feet!" "Big, was he!" said the old Frog, puffing herself up. "Was he as big as this?" "Oh, much bigger!" they cried. The Frog puffed up still more. "He could not have been bigger than this," she said. But the little Frogs all declared that the monster was much, much bigger and the old Frog kept puffing herself out more and more until, all at once, she burst.
content_zh: 一头公牛来到长满芦苇的池塘边喝水。当他重重地踩进水里时，把一只小青蛙踩进了泥里。老青蛙很快发现小青蛙不见了，便问他的兄弟姐妹们他去哪儿了。“一个巨大的怪物，”其中一只回答说，“用他那巨大的脚踩到了小弟弟！”“很大吗？”老青蛙说着，鼓起了自己的肚子。“有这么大吗？”“哦，比这大多了！”他们叫道。老青蛙把肚子鼓得更大了。“他不可能比这还大，”她说。但小青蛙们都说那个怪物要大得多得多，于是老青蛙不停地把肚子鼓得越来越大，直到最后，“砰”的一声，她胀破了肚皮。
moral: Do not attempt the impossible.
moral_zh: 不要尝试不可能的事（量力而行）。

title: Belling the Cat
author: Aesop's Fables
content: The Mice once called a meeting to decide on a plan to free themselves of their enemy, the Cat. At least they wished to find some way of knowing when she was coming, so they might have time to run away. Indeed, something had to be done, for they lived in such constant fear of her claws that they hardly dared stir from their dens by night or day. Many plans were discussed, but none of them was thought good enough. At last a very young Mouse got up and said: "I have a plan that seems very simple, but I know it will be successful. All we have to do is to hang a bell about the Cat's neck. When we hear the bell ringing we will know immediately that our enemy is coming." All the Mice were much surprised that they had not thought of such a plan before. But in the midst of the rejoicing over their good fortune, an old Mouse arose and said: "I will say that the plan of the young Mouse is very good. But let me ask one question: Who will bell the Cat?"
content_zh: 老鼠们召开了一次会议，商讨如何摆脱它们的天敌——猫。至少它们希望能想出一个办法，知道猫什么时候来，这样它们就有时间逃跑。事实上，必须得做点什么了，因为它们终日生活在对猫爪的恐惧中，无论白天黑夜都不敢离开洞穴半步。大家讨论了很多方案，但都不够好。最后，一只很年轻的老鼠站起来说：“我有一个看起来很简单的计划，但我知道它一定会成功。我们要做的就是在猫的脖子上挂一个铃铛。当我们听到铃声响时，立刻就会知道敌人来了。”所有的老鼠都很惊讶，因为它们以前从未想到过这样的计划。正当大家为这好运欢呼时，一只老老鼠站起来说：“我得说，这只小老鼠的计划非常好。但我有一个问题：谁去给猫挂铃铛呢？”
moral: It is one thing to say that something should be done, but quite a different matter to do it.
moral_zh: 说起来容易做起来难。

title: The Town Mouse and The Country Mouse
author: Aesop's Fables
content: A Town Mouse once visited a relative who lived in the country. For lunch the Country Mouse served wheat stalks, roots, and acorns, with a dash of cold water for drink. The Town Mouse ate very sparingly, nibbling a little of this and a little of that, and by her manner making it very plain that she ate the simple food only to be polite. After the meal the friends had a long talk, or rather the Town Mouse talked about her life in the city while the Country Mouse listened. They then went to bed in a cozy nest in the hedgerow and slept in quiet and comfort until morning. In her sleep the Country Mouse dreamed she was a Town Mouse with all the luxuries and delights of city life that her friend had described for her. So the next day when the Town Mouse asked the Country Mouse to go home with her to the city, she gladly said yes. When they reached the mansion in which the Town Mouse lived, they found on the table in the dining room the leavings of a very fine banquet. There were sweetmeats and jellies, pastries, delicious cheeses, indeed, the most tempting foods that a Mouse can imagine. But just as the Country Mouse was about to nibble a dainty bit of pastry, she heard a Cat mew loudly and scratch at the door. In great fear the Mice scurried to a hiding place, where they lay quite still for a long time, hardly daring to breathe. When at last they ventured back to the feast, the door opened suddenly and in came the servants to clear the table, followed by the House Dog. The Country Mouse stopped in the Town Mouse's den only long enough to pick up her carpet bag and umbrella. "You may have luxuries and dainties that I have not," she said as she hurried away, "but I prefer my plain food and simple life in the country with the peace and security that go with it."
content_zh: 一只城市老鼠去拜访住在乡下的亲戚。午餐时，乡下老鼠拿出了麦秆、树根和橡子，还有一点冷水作为饮料。城市老鼠吃得很勉强，挑挑拣拣地吃了一点点，显然只是为了礼貌才吃这些粗茶淡饭。饭后，两位朋友聊了很久，或者说是城市老鼠一直在讲她在城里的生活，而乡下老鼠在听。随后它们在树篱中一个舒适的窝里睡着了，安稳地睡到了天亮。在梦里，乡下老鼠梦见自己成了城市老鼠，享受着朋友描述的种种奢华和快乐。所以第二天，当城市老鼠邀请乡下老鼠跟她回城里时，她欣然答应了。当它们到达城市老鼠居住的豪宅时，发现餐厅桌上摆着一场盛大宴会的残羹冷炙。有糖果、果冻、糕点、美味的奶酪，简直是老鼠能想象到的最诱人的食物。但正当乡下老鼠准备品尝一块精致的糕点时，她听到一只猫在门外大声叫唤并抓挠着门。老鼠们吓得惊慌失措，窜到一个藏身之处，在那里一动不动地躲了很久，大气都不敢出。当它们终于敢回到盛宴旁时，门突然打开了，仆人们进来清理桌子，后面还跟着一只家狗。乡下老鼠在城市老鼠的窝里只停留了片刻，拿起她的旅行袋和雨伞。“你拥有我没有的奢华和美食，”她匆匆离去时说道，“但我宁愿在乡下吃粗茶淡饭，过简单的生活，因为那里有平静和安全。”
moral: Poverty with security is better than plenty in the midst of fear and uncertainty.
moral_zh: 与其在恐惧和不安中享受富足，不如在安全中过贫穷的日子。

title: The Fox and The Grapes
author: Aesop's Fables
content: A Fox one day spied a beautiful bunch of ripe grapes hanging from a vine trained along the branches of a tree. The grapes seemed ready to burst with juice, and the Fox's mouth watered as he gazed longingly at them. The bunch hung from a high branch, and the Fox had to jump for it. The first time he jumped he missed it by a long way. So he walked off a short distance and took a running leap at it, only to fall short once more. Again and again he tried, but in vain. Now he sat down and looked at the grapes in disgust. "What a fool I am," he said. "Here I am wearing myself out to get a bunch of sour grapes that are not worth gaping for." And off he walked very, very scornfully.
content_zh: 一天，一只狐狸发现树枝上挂着一串美丽的成熟葡萄。葡萄看起来汁水饱满，狐狸渴望地盯着它们，口水直流。葡萄挂在一根高高的树枝上，狐狸必须跳起来才够得着。第一次跳跃时，他差了很大一截。于是他退后一小段距离，助跑跳起，结果还是没够着。他试了一次又一次，但都徒劳无功。最后，他坐下来，厌恶地看着葡萄。“我真是个傻瓜，”他说，“把自己累得半死，就为了弄到一串不值得张嘴的酸葡萄。”说完，他非常轻蔑地走开了。
moral: There are many who pretend to despise and belittle that which is beyond their reach.
moral_zh: 很多人会假装藐视和贬低那些他们无法得到的东西（吃不到葡萄说葡萄酸）。

title: The Wolf and The Crane
author: Aesop's Fables
content: A Wolf had been feasting too greedily, and a bone had stuck crosswise in his throat. He could get it neither up nor down, and of course he could not eat a thing. Naturally that was an awful state of affairs for a greedy Wolf. So away he hurried to the Crane. He was sure that she, with her long neck and bill, would easily be able to reach the bone and pull it out. "I will reward you very handsomely," said the Wolf, "if you pull that bone out for me." The Crane, as you can imagine, was very uneasy about putting her head in a Wolf's throat. But she was grasping in nature, so she did what the Wolf asked her to do. When the Wolf felt that the bone was gone, he started to walk away. "But what about my reward!" called the Crane anxiously. "What!" snarled the Wolf, whirling around. "Haven't you got it? Isn't it enough that I let you take your head out of my mouth without snapping it off?"
content_zh: 一只狼吃得太贪婪，一根骨头卡在了喉咙里。他吐不出来也咽不下去，当然什么也吃不下了。对于一只贪吃的狼来说，这自然是糟糕透顶。于是他急忙跑去找鹤。他确信凭借鹤的长脖子和长嘴，一定能轻易地把骨头夹出来。“如果你帮我把骨头取出来，”狼说，“我会给你丰厚的报酬。”正如你所想象的，鹤对于把头伸进狼嘴里这件事感到非常不安。但她本性贪婪，所以还是照狼说的做了。当狼感觉到骨头没了，转身就走。“可是我的报酬呢！”鹤焦急地喊道。“什么！”狼咆哮着转过身，“你还没得到吗？难道让你把头从我嘴里完好无损地拿出来，这还不够吗？”
moral: Expect no reward for serving the wicked.
moral_zh: 不要指望为恶人效劳能得到回报。

title: The Lion and The Mouse
author: Aesop's Fables
content: A Lion lay asleep in the forest, his great head resting on his paws. A timid little Mouse came upon him unexpectedly, and in her fright and haste to get away, ran across the Lion's nose. Roused from his nap, the Lion laid his huge paw angrily on the tiny creature to kill her. "Spare me!" begged the poor Mouse. "Please let me go and some day I will surely repay you." The Lion was much amused to think that a Mouse could ever help him. But he was generous and finally let the Mouse go. Some days later, while stalking his prey in the forest, the Lion was caught in the toils of a hunter's net. Unable to free himself, he filled the forest with his angry roaring. The Mouse knew the voice and quickly found the Lion struggling in the net. Running to one of the great ropes that bound him, she gnawed it until it parted, and soon the Lion was free. "You laughed when I said I would repay you," said the Mouse. "Now you see that even a Mouse can help a Lion."
content_zh: 一只狮子在森林里睡觉，巨大的头枕在爪子上。一只胆小的小老鼠意外地撞见了他，惊慌失措想逃跑时，从狮子的鼻子上跑了过去。狮子被从梦中惊醒，愤怒地用巨大的爪子按住那个小家伙，想杀死她。“饶了我吧！”可怜的老鼠求饶道，“请放我走，总有一天我会报答你的。”狮子觉得老鼠能帮他的想法太可笑了。但他还是大度地放走了老鼠。几天后，狮子在森林里捕猎时，被猎人的网困住了。他无法挣脱，愤怒的吼声响彻森林。老鼠听出了这个声音，很快找到了在网中挣扎的狮子。她跑到捆绑狮子的一根大绳子旁，咬断了绳子，很快狮子就重获自由。“我当时说会报答你，你还笑我呢，”老鼠说，“现在你看到了，即使是一只老鼠也能帮助狮子。”
moral: A kindness is never wasted.
moral_zh: 善行永远不会被浪费。

title: The Gnat and The Bull
author: Aesop's Fables
content: A Gnat flew over the meadow with much buzzing for so small a creature and settled on the tip of one of the horns of a Bull. After he had rested a short time, he made ready to fly away. But before he left he begged the Bull's pardon for having used his horn for a resting place. "You must be very glad to have me go now," he said. "It's all the same to me," replied the Bull. "I did not even know you were there."
content_zh: 一只蚊子嗡嗡叫着飞过草地，对于这么小的生物来说动静可真不小，最后停在了一头公牛的角尖上。休息了一会儿后，他准备飞走。但在离开之前，他请求公牛原谅他借用了牛角休息。“我现在要走了，你一定很高兴吧，”他说。“对我来说都一样，”公牛回答道，“我甚至都不知道你在那儿。”
moral: We are often of greater importance in our own eyes than in the eyes of our neighbor. The smaller the mind the greater the conceit.
moral_zh: 我们往往把自己看得比在别人眼中更重要。心胸越狭隘，人越自负。

title: The Plane Tree
author: Aesop's Fables
content: Two Travellers, walking in the noonday sun, sought the shade of a widespreading tree to rest. As they lay looking up among the pleasant leaves, they saw that it was a Plane Tree. "How useless is the Plane!" said one of them. "It bears no fruit whatever, and only serves to litter the ground with leaves." "Ungrateful creatures!" said a voice from the Plane Tree. "You lie here in my cooling shade, and yet you say I am useless! Thus ungratefully, O Jupiter, do men receive their blessings!"
content_zh: 两个旅行者在正午的烈日下行走，找到一棵枝繁叶茂的大树下休息遮阴。当他们躺着仰望那些令人心旷神怡的树叶时，发现这是一棵悬铃木（法国梧桐）。“这悬铃木真没用！”其中一人说，“它不结任何果实，只会弄得满地落叶。”“不知感恩的家伙！”悬铃木发出了声音，“你们躺在我凉爽的树荫下，却还说我没用！人类就是这样忘恩负义地对待上天赐予的恩惠啊！”
moral: Our best blessings are often the least appreciated.
moral_zh: 最好的恩赐往往最不被珍惜（身在福中不知福）。

title: The Owl and The Grasshopper
author: Aesop's Fables
content: The Owl always takes her sleep during the day. Then after sundown, when the rosy light fades from the sky and the shadows rise slowly through the wood, out she comes ruffling and blinking from the old hollow tree. Now her weird "hoo-hoo-hoo-oo-oo" echoes through the quiet wood, and she begins her hunt for the bugs and beetles, frogs and mice she likes so well to eat. Now there was a certain old Owl who had become very cross and hard to please as she grew older, especially if anything disturbed her daily slumbers. One warm summer afternoon as she dozed away in her den in the old oak tree, a Grasshopper nearby began a joyous but very raspy song. Out popped the old Owl's head from the opening in the tree that served her both for door and for window. "Get away from here, sir," she said to the Grasshopper. "Have you no manners? You should at least respect my age and leave me to sleep in quiet!" But the Grasshopper answered saucily that he had as much right to his place in the sun as the Owl had to her place in the old oak. Then he struck up a louder and still more rasping tune. The wise old Owl knew quite well that it would do no good to argue with the Grasshopper, nor with anybody else for that matter. Besides, her eyes were not sharp enough by day to permit her to punish the Grasshopper as he deserved. So she laid aside all hard words and spoke very kindly to him. "Well sir," she said, "if I must stay awake, I am going to settle right down to enjoy your singing. Now that I think of it, I have a wonderful wine here, sent me from Olympus, of which I am told Apollo drinks before he sings to the high gods. Please come up and taste this delicious drink with me. I know it will make you sing like Apollo himself." The foolish Grasshopper was taken in by the Owl's flattering words. Up he jumped to the Owl's den, but as soon as he was near enough so the old Owl could see him clearly, she pounced upon him and ate him up.
content_zh: 猫头鹰总是在白天睡觉。日落之后，当玫瑰色的光芒从天空中褪去，阴影慢慢笼罩森林时，她才会从老树洞里钻出来，抖动着羽毛，眨着眼睛。此刻，她那怪异的“呼-呼-呼-呜-呜”声在寂静的林间回荡，她开始捕食她最爱吃的虫子、甲虫、青蛙和老鼠。有一只老猫头鹰，年纪越大脾气越坏，越难取悦，特别是如果有什么东西打扰了她白天的睡眠。一个温暖的夏日午后，当她在老橡树的巢穴里打盹时，附近的一只蚂蚱开始唱起快乐但非常刺耳的歌。老猫头鹰把头探出那个既是门又是窗的树洞。“离开这儿，先生，”她对蚂蚱说，“你没礼貌吗？你至少应该尊重我的年纪，让我安静地睡觉！”但蚂蚱无礼地回答说，他像猫头鹰拥有老橡树一样，也有权享受阳光。接着他唱起了更响亮、更刺耳的调子。聪明的老猫头鹰很清楚，和蚂蚱争论是没有用的，事实上和谁争论都没用。而且，她的眼睛在白天不够敏锐，无法按他应得的那样惩罚他。于是她收起严厉的言辞，非常和蔼地对他说。“好吧，先生，”她说，“既然我必须醒着，我就坐下来好好欣赏你的歌声。我想起来了，我这里有一种绝妙的酒，是从奥林匹斯山送来的，据说阿波罗在给众神歌唱前都会喝这种酒。请上来和我一起品尝这美味的饮料吧。我知道它会让你唱得像阿波罗一样动听。”愚蠢的蚂蚱被猫头鹰的奉承话骗了。他跳上了猫头鹰的巢穴，但他刚靠近到老猫头鹰能看清他的距离，她就猛扑过去把他吃掉了。
moral: Flattery is not a proof of true admiration. Do not let flattery throw you off your guard against an enemy.
moral_zh: 奉承并不代表真正的赞赏。不要让奉承使你对敌人放松警惕（糖衣炮弹）。

title: The Oak and The Reeds
author: Aesop's Fables
content: A Giant Oak stood near a brook in which grew some slender Reeds. When the wind blew, the great Oak stood proudly upright with its hundred arms uplifted to the sky. But the Reeds bowed low in the wind and sang a sad and mournful song. "You have reason to complain," said the Oak. "The slightest breeze that ruffles the surface of the water makes you bow your heads, while I, the mighty Oak, stand upright and firm before the howling tempest." "Do not worry about us," replied the Reeds. "The winds do not harm us. We bow before them and so we do not break. You, in all your pride and strength, have so far resisted their blows. But the end is coming." As the Reeds spoke a great hurricane rushed out of the north. The Oak stood proudly and fought against the storm, while the yielding Reeds bowed low. The wind redoubled in fury, and all at once the great tree fell, torn up by the roots, and lay among the pitying Reeds.
content_zh: 一棵巨大的橡树矗立在小溪旁，溪水中生长着一些细长的芦苇。风吹过时，巨大的橡树骄傲地挺立着，百条手臂伸向天空。而芦苇则在风中低头弯腰，唱着悲伤凄凉的歌。“你们确实有理由抱怨，”橡树说，“微风吹皱水面就能让你们低头，而我，强大的橡树，在咆哮的暴风雨面前依然挺立稳固。”“别为我们担心，”芦苇回答说，“风伤不到我们。我们在风面前弯腰，所以不会折断。你凭借傲慢和力量，至今抵抗住了风的打击。但结局快到了。”芦苇正说着，一股巨大的飓风从北方呼啸而来。橡树骄傲地站立着与风暴对抗，而柔顺的芦苇则深深地弯下了腰。风势加倍狂暴，突然间，那棵大树倒下了，被连根拔起，躺在充满怜悯的芦苇丛中。
moral: Better to yield when it is folly to resist, than to resist stubbornly and be destroyed.
moral_zh: 当抵抗是愚蠢的时候，屈服比顽固抵抗而被毁灭要好（能屈能伸）。

title: The Crow and The Pitcher
author: Aesop's Fables
content: In a spell of dry weather, when the Birds could find very little to drink, a thirsty Crow found a pitcher with a little water in it. But the pitcher was high and had a narrow neck, and no matter how he tried, the Crow could not reach the water. The poor thing felt as if he must die of thirst. Then an idea came to him. Picking up some small pebbles, he dropped them into the pitcher one by one. With each pebble the water rose a little higher until at last it was near enough so he could drink.
content_zh: 在一段干旱的天气里，鸟儿们很难找到水喝，一只口渴的乌鸦发现了一个有一点水的罐子。但是罐子很高，瓶口很窄，无论他怎么试，乌鸦都够不着水。可怜的家伙觉得他快要渴死了。突然他想到了一个主意。他捡起一些小石子，一颗一颗地丢进罐子里。随着每一颗石子的落下，水位一点点升高，直到最后离得足够近，他终于喝到了水。
moral: In a pinch a good use of our wits may help us out.
moral_zh: 在紧要关头，善用智慧可以帮我们摆脱困境。

title: The Two Goats
author: Aesop's Fables
content: Two Goats, frisking gayly on the rocky steeps of a mountain valley, chanced to meet, one on each side of a deep chasm through which poured a mighty mountain torrent. The trunk of a fallen tree formed the only means of crossing the chasm, and on this not even two squirrels could have passed each other in safety. The narrow path would have made the bravest tremble. Not so our Goats. Their pride would not permit either to stand aside for the other. One set her foot on the log. The other did likewise. In the middle they met horn to horn. Neither would give way, and so they both fell, to be swept away by the roaring torrent below.
content_zh: 两只山羊在山谷陡峭的岩壁上快乐地嬉戏，偶然相遇了，它们分别站在一条深渊的两侧，深渊下奔流着湍急的山洪。一根倒下的树干是跨越深渊的唯一通道，在这上面，甚至两只松鼠都无法安全地擦肩而过。这条狭窄的小路即使是勇者也会颤抖。但我们的山羊可不这么想。它们的骄傲不允许任何一方为对方让路。一只把脚踏上了原木，另一只也照做了。在中间，它们角对着角相遇了。谁也不肯让步，结果它们都掉下去了，被下面咆哮的洪流卷走了。
moral: It is better to yield than to come to misfortune through stubbornness.
moral_zh: 退一步海阔天空，因固执而招致不幸是不值得的。

title: The Wild Boar and The Fox
author: Aesop's Fables
content: A Wild Boar was sharpening his tusks busily against the stump of a tree, when a Fox happened by. Now the Fox was always looking for a chance to make fun of his neighbors. So he made a great show of looking anxiously about, as if in fear of some hidden enemy. But the Boar kept right on with his work. "Why are you doing that?" asked the Fox at last with a grin. "There isn't any danger that I can see." "True enough," replied the Boar, "but when danger does come there will not be time for such work as this. My weapons will have to be ready for use then, or I shall suffer for it."
content_zh: 一只野猪正在树桩上忙着磨獠牙，这时一只狐狸路过。这只狐狸总是找机会取笑邻居。于是他装出一副焦急四顾的样子，好像害怕有什么隐藏的敌人。但野猪继续干他的活。“你为什么要那样做？”狐狸最后咧着嘴笑着问，“我看不到任何危险啊。”“的确如此，”野猪回答说，“但当危险真的来临时，就没时间做这个了。我的武器必须时刻准备好，否则我就要吃亏了。”
moral: Preparedness for war is the best guarantee of peace.
moral_zh: 备战是和平最好的保障（有备无患）。

title: The Heron
author: Aesop's Fables
content: A Heron was walking sedately along the bank of a stream, his eyes on the clear water, and his long neck and pointed bill ready to snap up a likely morsel for his breakfast. The clear water swarmed with fish, but Master Heron was hard to please that morning. "No small fry for me," he said. "Such scanty fare is not fit for a Heron." Now a fine young Perch swam near. "No indeed," said the Heron. "I wouldn't even trouble to open my beak for anything like that!" As the sun rose, the fish left the shallow water near the shore and swam below into the cool depths toward the middle. The Heron saw no more fish, and very glad was he at last to breakfast on a tiny Snail.
content_zh: 一只苍鹭在河岸边从容地踱步，眼睛盯着清澈的河水，长长的脖子和尖尖的喙准备随时啄食合意的早餐。清水里鱼群密集，但这天早上苍鹭大师很难取悦。“我才不要小鱼苗，”他说，“这样寒酸的食物配不上苍鹭。”这时一条漂亮的年轻鲈鱼游了过来。“不行，”苍鹭说，“我甚至都不屑为这种东西张嘴！”随着太阳升起，鱼儿们离开了岸边的浅水区，游向中间凉爽的深水区。苍鹭再也看不到鱼了，最后他不得不很高兴地把一只小蜗牛当了早餐。
moral: Do not be too hard to suit or you may have to be content with the worst or with nothing at all.
moral_zh: 不要太挑剔，否则你可能不得不接受最差的，或者什么都没有。

title: The Fox and The Stork
author: Aesop's Fables
content: The Fox one day thought of a plan to amuse himself at the expense of the Stork, at whose odd appearance he was always laughing. "You must come and dine with me today," he said to the Stork, smiling to himself at the trick he was going to play. The Stork gladly accepted the invitation and arrived in good time and with a very good appetite. For dinner the Fox served soup. But it was set out in a very shallow dish, and all the Stork could do was to wet the very tip of his bill. Not a drop of soup could he get. But the Fox lapped it up easily, and, to increase the disappointment of the Stork, made a great show of enjoyment. The hungry Stork was much displeased at the trick, but he was a calm, even-tempered fellow and saw no good in flying into a rage. Instead, not long afterward, he invited the Fox to dine with him in turn. The Fox arrived promptly at the time that had been set, and the Stork served a fish dinner that had a very appetizing smell. But it was served in a tall jar with a very narrow neck. The Stork could easily get at the food with his long bill, but all the Fox could do was to lick the outside of the jar, and sniff at the delicious odor. And when the Fox lost his temper, the Stork said calmly: "Do not play tricks on your neighbors unless you can stand the same treatment yourself."
content_zh: 一天，狐狸想出了一个捉弄鹳的主意，他总是嘲笑鹳那古怪的模样。“今天你一定要来和我一起吃饭，”他对鹳说，心里暗自为即将上演的恶作剧发笑。鹳欣然接受了邀请，准时到达，胃口大开。狐狸端出的晚餐是汤。但这汤盛在一个非常浅的盘子里，鹳只能弄湿一点点喙尖。他一滴汤也喝不到。而狐狸却轻而易举地喝了个精光，为了增加鹳的失望感，他还故意表现出非常享受的样子。饥饿的鹳对这个恶作剧很不高兴，但他是个冷静、脾气温和的家伙，觉得发火没什么用。相反，没过多久，他回请狐狸吃饭。狐狸准时赴约，鹳端出的鱼宴闻起来香气扑鼻。但这食物盛在一个长颈窄口的罐子里。鹳凭借长喙可以轻易吃到食物，但狐狸只能舔舔罐子外面，闻闻那美味的香气。当狐狸发脾气时，鹳平静地说：“除非你自己能忍受同样的待遇，否则不要捉弄邻居。”
moral: Do not play tricks on your neighbors unless you can stand the same treatment yourself.
moral_zh: 己所不欲，勿施于人。

title: The Cock and the Fox
author: Aesop's Fables
content: One bright evening as the sun was sinking on a glorious world a wise old Cock flew into a tree to roost. Before he composed himself to rest, he flapped his wings three times and crowed loudly. But just as he was about to put his head under his wing, his beady eyes caught a flash of red and a glimpse of a long pointed nose, and there just below him stood Master Fox. "Have you heard the wonderful news?" cried the Fox in a very joyful and excited manner. "What news?" asked the Cock very calmly. But he had a queer, fluttery feeling inside him, for, you know, he was very much afraid of the Fox. "Your family and mine and all other animals have agreed to forget their differences and live in peace and friendship from now on forever. Just think of it! I simply cannot wait to embrace you! Do come down, dear friend, and let us celebrate the joyful event." "How grand!" said the Cock. "I certainly am delighted at the news." But he spoke in an absent way, and stretching up on tiptoes, seemed to be looking at something afar off. "What is it you see?" asked the Fox a little anxiously. "Why, it looks to me like a couple of Dogs coming this way. They must have heard the good news and—" But the Fox did not wait to hear more. Off he started on a run. "Wait," cried the Cock. "Why do you run? The Dogs are friends of yours now!" "Yes," answered the Fox. "But they might not have heard the news. Besides, I have a very important errand that I had almost forgotten about." The Cock smiled as he buried his head in his feathers and went to sleep, for he had succeeded in outwitting a very crafty enemy.
content_zh: 在一个明媚的傍晚，夕阳西下，照耀着壮丽的世界，一只聪明的老公鸡飞到树上栖息。在安顿下来休息之前，他拍了三下翅膀，大声啼叫。但正当他准备把头埋进翅膀下时，他那如珠子般的小眼睛捕捉到了一抹红色和一个尖尖的长鼻子，就在他下面站着狐狸先生。“你听到那个好消息了吗？”狐狸用非常快乐和兴奋的语气喊道。“什么消息？”公鸡非常镇定地问。但他心里有一种奇怪的慌乱感，因为你知道，他非常害怕狐狸。“你的家族和我的家族，以及所有的动物都同意忘记分歧，从此永远和平友好地生活在一起。想想看！我简直迫不及待要拥抱你了！快下来吧，亲爱的朋友，让我们一起庆祝这个喜庆的日子。”“太棒了！”公鸡说，“我听到这个消息真是太高兴了。”但他说话时心不在焉，垫着脚尖，似乎在眺望远方。“你看到了什么？”狐狸有点焦急地问。“哦，我看好像有几只狗正朝这边跑来。他们一定也听到了好消息，并且——”但狐狸没等听完就撒腿跑了。“等等，”公鸡喊道，“你跑什么？狗现在是你的朋友了！”“是的，”狐狸回答，“但他们可能还没听到这个消息。再说，我有一件非常重要的差事差点忘了。”公鸡微笑着把头埋进羽毛里睡着了，因为他成功地骗过了一个非常狡猾的敌人。
moral: The trickster is easily tricked.
moral_zh: 骗人者其人恒骗之（聪明反被聪明误）。

title: The Stag and His Reflection
author: Aesop's Fables
content: A Stag, drinking from a crystal spring, saw himself mirrored in the clear water. He greatly admired the graceful arch of his antlers, but he was very much ashamed of his spindling legs. "How can it be," he sighed, "that I should be cursed with such legs when I have so magnificent a crown." At that moment he scented a panther and in an instant was bounding away through the forest. But as he ran his wide-spreading antlers caught in the branches of the trees, and soon the Panther overtook him. Then the Stag perceived that the legs of which he was so ashamed would have saved him had it not been for the useless ornaments on his head.
content_zh: 一只公鹿在清澈的泉边喝水，看到了自己在水中的倒影。他非常欣赏自己鹿角那优美的弧度，但对自己细长的腿感到非常羞愧。“怎么会这样，”他叹息道，“我拥有如此宏伟的皇冠，却被诅咒长了这样的一双腿。”就在这时，他闻到了豹子的气味，瞬间便在森林中飞奔起来。但当他奔跑时，他那宽大的鹿角卡在了树枝上，很快豹子就追上了他。这时公鹿才明白，那双让他感到羞愧的腿本可以救他的命，如果不是因为头顶上那无用的装饰品的话。
moral: We often make much of the ornamental and despise the useful.
moral_zh: 我们往往重视装饰而轻视实用。

title: The Young Crab and His Mother
author: Aesop's Fables
content: "Why in the world do you walk sideways like that?" said a Mother Crab to her son. "You should always walk straight forward with your toes turned out." "Show me how to walk, mother dear," answered the little Crab obediently, "I want to learn." So the old Crab tried and tried to walk straight forward. But she could walk sideways only, like her son. And when she wanted to turn her toes out she tripped and fell on her nose.
content_zh: “你到底为什么要那样横着走？”螃蟹妈妈对她的儿子说，“你应该总是脚尖朝外，直着向前走。”“演示给我看怎么走，亲爱的妈妈，”小螃蟹顺从地回答，“我想学。”于是老螃蟹试了又试，想直着向前走。但她只能像她儿子一样横着走。当她想把脚尖朝外时，她绊倒了，鼻子着地摔了一跤。
moral: Do not tell others how to act unless you can set a good example.
moral_zh: 己身不正，何以正人（言传不如身教）。

title: The Wolf in Sheep's Clothing
author: Aesop's Fables
content: A certain Wolf could not get enough to eat because of the watchfulness of the Shepherds. But one night he found a sheep skin that had been cast aside and forgotten. The next day, dressed in the skin, the Wolf strolled into the pasture with the Sheep. Soon a little Lamb was following him about and was quickly led away to slaughter. That evening the Wolf entered the fold with the flock. But it happened that the Shepherd took a fancy for mutton broth that very evening, and, picking up a knife, went to the fold. There the first he laid hands on and killed was the Wolf.
content_zh: 有一只狼因为牧羊人的警惕而吃不到足够的食物。但有一天晚上，他发现了一张被丢弃遗忘的羊皮。第二天，披着这张皮，狼混进了羊群在草地上漫步。很快一只小羊羔跟在他身后，被迅速引走杀掉了。那天晚上，狼随着羊群进入了羊圈。但碰巧那天晚上牧羊人想喝羊肉汤，于是拿起一把刀走进了羊圈。他在那里抓到的并杀掉的第一只羊，就是那只狼。
moral: The evil doer often comes to harm through his own deceit.
moral_zh: 多行不义必自毙。

title: The Fox and the Goat
author: Aesop's Fables
content: A Fox fell into a well, and though it was not very deep, he found that he could not get out again. After he had been in the well a long time, a thirsty Goat came by. The Goat thought the Fox had gone down to drink, and so he asked if the water was good. "The finest in the whole country," said the crafty Fox, "jump in and try it. There is more than enough for both of us." The thirsty Goat immediately jumped in and began to drink. The Fox just as quickly jumped on the Goat's back and leaped from the tip of the Goat's horns out of the well The foolish Goat now saw what a plight he had got into, and begged the Fox to help him out. But the Fox was already on his way to the woods "If you had as much sense as you have beard, old fellow," he said as she ran, "you would have been more cautious about finding a way to get out again before you jumped in."
content_zh: 一只狐狸掉进了一口井里，虽然井不是很深，但他发现自己出不来了。他在井里待了很久之后，一只口渴的山羊路过。山羊以为狐狸是下去喝水的，便问水好不好喝。“这是全国最好的水，”狡猾的狐狸说，“跳下来尝尝吧。足够我们要两个人喝的。”口渴的山羊立刻跳了下去开始喝水。狐狸同样迅速地跳到山羊背上，踩着山羊的角尖跳出了井。愚蠢的山羊这才意识到自己的处境，恳求狐狸救他出去。但狐狸已经跑向树林了。“老伙计，如果你的脑子和你的胡子一样多，”他边跑边说，“你在跳下去之前就会更谨慎地考虑怎么出来了。”
moral: Look before you leap.
moral_zh: 三思而后行。

title: The Eagle and the Beetle
author: Aesop's Fables
content: A Beetle once begged the Eagle to spare a Hare which had run to her for protection. But the Eagle pounced upon her prey, the sweep of her great wings tumbling the Beetle a dozen feet away. Furious at the disrespect shown her, the Beetle flew to the Eagle's nest and rolled out the eggs. Not one did she spare. The Eagle's grief and anger knew no bounds, but who had done the cruel deed she did not know. Next year the Eagle built her nest far up on a mountain crag; but the Beetle found it and again destroyed the eggs. In despair the Eagle now implored great Jupiter to let her place her eggs in his lap. There none would dare harm them. But the Beetle buzzed about Jupiter's head, and made him rise to drive her away; and the eggs rolled from his lap. Now the Beetle told the reason for her action, and Jupiter had to acknowledge the justice of her cause. And they say that ever after, while the Eagle's eggs lie in the nest in spring, the Beetle still sleeps in the ground. For so Jupiter commanded.
content_zh: 一只甲虫曾经恳求鹰放过一只跑来寻求她保护的野兔。但鹰猛扑向猎物，巨大的翅膀一挥，把甲虫扇飞了十几英尺远。甲虫对这种不尊重的行为感到愤怒，飞到鹰的巢里，把鹰蛋都滚了出来。一个也没留。鹰的悲伤和愤怒无法形容，但她不知道是谁干的残忍勾当。第二年，鹰把巢筑在悬崖高处；但甲虫找到了那里，再次摧毁了蛋。绝望中，鹰恳求伟大的朱庇特让她把蛋放在他的膝盖上。在那里没人敢伤害它们。但甲虫在朱庇特头顶嗡嗡叫，让他站起来赶走她；结果蛋从他的膝盖上滚落了下来。这时甲虫说明了她这么做的原因，朱庇特不得不承认她的理由是正当的。据说从此以后，当春天鹰蛋在巢里时，甲虫还在地下沉睡。因为这是朱庇特的命令（为了避免鹰和甲虫的冲突）。
moral: Even the weakest may find means to avenge a wrong.
moral_zh: 即使是最弱小者也能找到复仇的方法（不要轻视弱者）。

title: The Wolf and the Kid
author: Aesop's Fables
content: There was once a little Kid whose growing horns made him think he was a grown-up Billy Goat and able to take care of himself. So one evening when the flock started home from the pasture and his mother called, the Kid paid no heed and kept right on nibbling the tender grass. A little later when he lifted his head, the flock was gone. He was all alone. The sun was sinking. Long shadows came creeping over the ground. A chilly little wind came creeping with them making scary noises in the grass. The Kid shivered as he thought of the terrible Wolf. Then he started wildly over the field, bleating for his mother. But not half-way, near a clump of trees, there was the Wolf! The Kid knew there was little hope for him. "Please, Mr. Wolf," he said trembling, "I know you are going to eat me. But first please pipe me a tune, for I want to dance and be merry as long as I can." The Wolf liked the idea of a little music before eating, so he struck up a merry tune and the Kid leaped and frisked gaily. Meanwhile, the flock was moving slowly homeward. In the still evening air the Wolf's piping carried far. The Shepherd Dogs pricked up their ears. They recognized the song the Wolf sings before a feast, and in a moment they were racing back to the pasture. The Wolf's song ended suddenly, and as he ran, with the Dogs at his heels, he called himself a fool for turning piper to please a Kid, when he should have stuck to his butcher's trade.
content_zh: 从前有一只小山羊，他长出的小角让他觉得自己已经是一只成年的公山羊，能够照顾自己了。所以有一天晚上，当羊群开始从草地回家，母亲呼唤他时，小山羊没有理会，继续啃着嫩草。过了一会儿，当他抬起头时，羊群不见了。他孤身一人。太阳正在下山。长长的阴影在地面上蔓延。一阵寒冷的微风随之而来，在草丛中发出可怕的声音。小山羊想到可怕的狼，不禁发抖。然后他开始在田野里疯狂地跑，咩咩地叫着找妈妈。但没跑到一半，在一丛树旁，狼出现了！小山羊知道自己没什么希望了。“求求你，狼先生，”他颤抖着说，“我知道你要吃我。但请先给我吹支曲子吧，我想在还能跳的时候跳舞快乐一下。”狼觉得吃东西前听点音乐也不错，于是吹起了欢快的曲子，小山羊快乐地跳来跳去。与此同时，羊群正缓慢地向家移动。在寂静的晚风中，狼的笛声传得很远。牧羊犬竖起了耳朵。他们认出了这是狼在享用盛宴前唱的歌，瞬间便向草地飞奔回来。狼的歌声戛然而止，当他逃跑时，狗紧跟在他脚后跟，他骂自己是个傻瓜，本该干屠夫的行当，却为了取悦一只小山羊当起了风笛手。
moral: Do not let anything turn you from your purpose.
moral_zh: 不要让任何事情使你偏离目标（对于狼：专注于本职；对于羊：聪明反击）。

title: The Wolf and the Sheep
author: Aesop's Fables
content: A Wolf had been hurt in a fight with a Bear. He was unable to move and could not satisfy his hunger and thirst. A Sheep passed by near his hiding place, and the Wolf called to him. "Please fetch me a drink of water," he begged, "that might give me strength enough so I can get me some solid food." "Solid food!" said the Sheep. "That means me, I suppose. If I should bring you a drink, it would only serve to wash me down your throat. Don't talk to me about a drink!"
content_zh: 一只狼在和熊的打斗中受了伤。他动弹不得，无法充饥解渴。一只羊路过他的藏身之处，狼叫住了他。“请帮我弄点水喝，”他乞求道，“那可能会给我足够的力量去弄点固体食物。”“固体食物！”羊说，“我想那就是指我吧。如果我给你拿水来，那只能帮你把我顺着喉咙冲下去。别跟我提喝水的事！”
moral: A knave's hypocrisy is easily seen through.
moral_zh: 恶棍的虚伪很容易被识破。

title: The Hare and His Ears
author: Aesop's Fables
content: The Lion had been badly hurt by the horns of a Goat, which he was eating. He was very angry to think that any animal that he chose for a meal, should be so brazen as to wear such dangerous things as horns to scratch him while he ate. So he commanded that all animals with horns should leave his domains within twenty-four hours. The command struck terror among the beasts. All those who were so unfortunate as to have horns, began to pack up and move out. Even the Hare, who, as you know, has no horns and so had nothing to fear, passed a very restless night, dreaming awful dreams about the fearful Lion. And when he came out of the warren in the early morning sunshine, and there saw the shadow cast by his long and pointed ears, a terrible fright seized him. "Goodby, neighbor Cricket," he called. "I'm off. He will certainly make out that my ears are horns, no matter what I say."
content_zh: 狮子在吃一只山羊时被羊角严重刺伤了。想到他选择作为美餐的动物竟然如此厚颜无耻，戴着这样危险的东西在被吃的时候抓伤他，他非常生气。于是他命令所有长角的动物必须在二十四小时内离开他的领地。这个命令在野兽中引起了恐慌。所有不幸长角的动物开始收拾行装搬走。即使是野兔，你也知道，他没有角所以没什么好怕的，也过了一个非常不安的夜晚，做着关于可怕狮子的噩梦。当他在清晨的阳光下走出洞穴，看到自己长长的尖耳朵投下的影子时，一阵可怕的恐惧抓住了他。“再见，蟋蟀邻居，”他喊道，“我要走了。不管我说什么，他肯定会把我的耳朵当成角的。”
moral: Do not give your enemies the slightest reason to attack your reputation. Your enemies will seize any excuse to attack you.
moral_zh: 欲加之罪，何患无辞（不要给敌人任何攻击你的借口）。

title: The Ass and the Load of Salt
author: Aesop's Fables
content: A Merchant, driving his Ass homeward from the seashore with a heavy load of salt, came to a river crossed by a shallow ford. They had crossed this river many times before without accident, but this time the Ass slipped and fell when halfway over. And when the Merchant at last got him to his feet, much of the salt had melted away. Delighted to find how much lighter his burden had become, the Ass finished the journey very gayly. Next day the Merchant went for another load of salt. On the way home the Ass, remembering what had happened at the ford, purposely let himself fall into the water, and again got rid of most of his burden. The angry Merchant immediately turned about and drove the Ass back to the seashore, where he loaded him with two great baskets of sponges. At the ford the Ass again tumbled over; but when he had scrambled to his feet, it was a very disconsolate Ass that dragged himself homeward under a load ten times heavier than before.
content_zh: 一个商人赶着他的驴子，驮着重重的一袋盐从海边回家，来到一条有浅滩的河边。他们以前多次安全渡过这条河，但这一次驴子走到一半时滑倒了。当商人终于让他站起来时，大部分盐已经融化了。发现负担变轻了这么多，驴子非常高兴地完成了旅程。第二天，商人又去运盐。在回家的路上，驴子记起在浅滩发生的事，故意让自己跌进水里，又一次摆脱了大部分负担。愤怒的商人立刻转身赶着驴子回到海边，在那里给他装了两大筐海绵。在浅滩处，驴子又跌倒了；但当他爬起来时，这只沮丧的驴子不得不拖着比以前重十倍的负担回家。
moral: The same measures will not suit all circumstances.
moral_zh: 同样的方法并不适用于所有情况（弄巧成拙）。

title: The Wolf and the Lean Dog
author: Aesop's Fables
content: A Wolf prowling near a village one evening met a Dog. It happened to be a very lean and bony Dog, and Master Wolf would have turned up his nose at such meager fare had he not been more hungry than usual. So he began to edge toward the Dog, while the Dog backed away. "Let me remind your lordship," said the Dog, his words interrupted now and then as he dodged a snap of the Wolf's teeth, "how unpleasant it would be to eat me now. Look at my ribs. I am nothing but skin and bone. But let me tell you something in private. In a few days my master will give a wedding feast for his only daughter. You can guess how fine and fat I will grow on the scraps from the table. Then is the time to eat me." The Wolf could not help thinking how nice it would be to have a fine fat Dog to eat instead of the scrawny object before him. So he went away pulling in his belt and promising to return. Some days later the Wolf came back for the promised feast. He found the Dog in his master's yard, and asked him to come out and be eaten. "Sir," said the Dog, with a grin, "I shall be delighted to have you eat me. I'll be out as soon as the porter opens the door." But the "porter" was a huge Dog whom the Wolf knew by painful experience to be very unkind toward wolves. So he decided not to wait and made off as fast as his legs could carry him.
content_zh: 一天晚上，一只狼在村子附近徘徊，遇见了一只狗。这恰好是一只非常瘦骨嶙峋的狗，如果不是因为狼比平时更饿，他肯定会瞧不上这顿寒酸的饭菜。于是他开始逼近狗，而狗则步步后退。“容我提醒大人，”狗一边躲避狼的利齿一边断断续续地说，“现在吃我会有多不愉快。看看我的肋骨。我只剩下皮包骨了。但我私下告诉你一件事。几天后我的主人要为他唯一的女儿举办婚宴。你可以猜到吃桌上的剩菜我会长得多么肥美。那时候才是吃我的好时机。”狼不禁想到有一只肥美的狗吃，总比眼前这个干瘪的东西好。于是他勒紧裤腰带离开了，并承诺会回来。几天后，狼回来赴约。他发现狗在主人的院子里，便让他出来被吃。“先生，”狗咧嘴笑着说，“我很乐意让你吃。只要门房一开门我就出来。”但那个“门房”是一只巨大的狗，狼从痛苦的经验中知道他对狼很不客气。于是他决定不等了，撒腿就跑。
moral: Do not depend on the promises of those whose interest it is to deceive you.
moral_zh: 不要相信那些为了欺骗你而许下诺言的人。

title: The Dog and His Reflection
author: Aesop's Fables
content: A Dog, to whom the butcher had thrown a bone, was hurrying home with his prize as fast as he could go. As he crossed a narrow footbridge, he happened to look down and saw himself reflected in the quiet water as if in a mirror. But the greedy Dog thought he saw a real Dog carrying a bone much bigger than his own. If he had stopped to think he would have known better. But instead of thinking, he dropped his bone and sprang at the Dog in the river, only to find himself swimming for dear life to reach the shore. At last he managed to scramble out, and as he stood sadly thinking about the good bone he had lost, he realized what a stupid Dog he had been.
content_zh: 屠夫给了一只狗一根骨头，狗叼着他的战利品尽可能快地往家跑。当他穿过一座狭窄的人行桥时，偶然低头，看到自己在平静的水如镜面般的倒影。但这只贪婪的狗以为自己看到了一只真的狗叼着一根比自己的大得多的骨头。如果他停下来想一想就会明白。但他没有思考，而是扔掉了自己的骨头，扑向河里的那只狗，结果发现自己只能为了保命拼命游向岸边。最后他终于爬了出来，当他悲伤地想着自己失去的好骨头时，他意识到自己是一只多么愚蠢的狗。
moral: It is very foolish to be greedy.
moral_zh: 贪婪是非常愚蠢的。

title: The Boy and the Filberts
author: Aesop's Fables
content: A Boy was given permission to put his hand into a pitcher to get some filberts. But he took such a great fistful that he could not draw his hand out again. There he stood, unwilling to give up a single filbert and yet unable to get them all out at once. Vexed and disappointed he began to cry. "My boy," said his mother, "be satisfied with half the nuts you have taken and you will easily get your hand out. Then perhaps you may have some more filberts some other time."
content_zh: 一个男孩被允许把手伸进罐子里拿一些榛子。但他抓了满满一大把，手却拿不出来了。他站在那里，不愿意放弃一颗榛子，却又无法一次把它们都拿出来。他又急又气，开始哭了起来。“孩子，”他母亲说，“只要你满足于拿一半的坚果，你的手很容易就能拿出来。那样也许以后你还能再拿一些榛子。”
moral: Do not attempt too much at once.
moral_zh: 不要试图一次贪多（知足常乐）。

title: The Ant and the Dove
author: Aesop's Fables
content: A Dove saw an Ant fall into a brook. The Ant struggled in vain to reach the bank, and in pity, the Dove dropped a blade of straw close beside it. Clinging to the straw like a shipwrecked sailor to a broken spar, the Ant floated safely to shore. Soon after, the Ant saw a man getting ready to kill the Dove with a stone. But just as he cast the stone, the Ant stung him in the heel, so that the pain made him miss his aim, and the startled Dove flew to safety in a distant wood.
content_zh: 一只鸽子看到一只蚂蚁掉进了小溪。蚂蚁挣扎着想爬上岸，但徒劳无功，鸽子出于同情，叼了一根稻草扔到它旁边。蚂蚁像遭遇海难的水手抓着断桅杆一样紧紧抓住稻草，安全地漂到了岸边。不久之后，蚂蚁看到一个人正准备用石头打死鸽子。正当他要扔石头时，蚂蚁咬了他的脚后跟一口，疼痛让他失了准头，受惊的鸽子飞到了远处安全的树林里。
moral: A kindness is never wasted.
moral_zh: 善行永远不会白费。

title: The Tortoise and the Ducks
author: Aesop's Fables
content: The Tortoise, you know, carries his house on his back. No matter how hard he tries, he cannot leave home. They say that Jupiter punished him so, because he was such a lazy stay-at-home that he would not go to Jupiter's wedding, even when especially invited. After many years, Tortoise began to wish he had gone to that wedding. When he saw how gaily the birds flew about and how the Hare and the Chipmunk and all the other animals ran nimbly by, always eager to see everything there was to be seen, the Tortoise felt very sad and discontented. He wanted to see the world too, and there he was with a house on his back and little short legs that could hardly drag him along. One day he met a pair of Ducks and told them all his trouble. "We can help you to see the world," said the Ducks. "Take hold of this stick with your teeth and we will carry you far up in the air where you can see the whole countryside. But keep quiet or you will be sorry." The Tortoise was very glad indeed. He seized the stick firmly with his teeth, the two Ducks took hold of it one at each end, and away they sailed up toward the clouds. Just then a Crow flew by. He was very much astonished at the strange sight and cried: "This must surely be the King of Tortoises!" "Why certainly—" began the Tortoise. But as he opened his mouth to say these foolish words he lost his hold on the stick, and down he fell to the ground, where he was dashed to pieces on a rock.
content_zh: 你知道，乌龟背着他的房子。无论他怎么努力，都离不开家。据说朱庇特这样惩罚他，是因为他是个懒惰的宅男，甚至在被特别邀请时也不去参加朱庇特的婚礼。多年后，乌龟开始后悔没去参加那个婚礼。当他看到鸟儿们快乐地飞翔，野兔和花栗鼠以及其他所有动物敏捷地跑过，总是急切地想看遍世间万物时，乌龟感到非常悲伤和不满。他也想看看世界，可他还背着房子，那双小短腿几乎拖不动他。一天，他遇到了一对鸭子，向他们诉说了自己的烦恼。“我们可以帮你看看世界，”鸭子说，“用牙齿咬住这根棍子，我们会带你飞到高空，你可以看到整个乡村。但要保持安静，否则你会后悔的。”乌龟非常高兴。他用牙齿紧紧咬住棍子，两只鸭子各咬住一头，他们便向云端飞去。这时一只乌鸦飞过。他对这奇景感到非常惊讶，大叫道：“这一定是乌龟之王！”“那当然——”乌龟刚开口。但他为了说这些蠢话一张嘴，就松开了棍子，从空中掉了下来，摔在岩石上粉身碎骨。
moral: Foolish curiosity and vanity often lead to misfortune.
moral_zh: 愚蠢的好奇心和虚荣心往往导致不幸。

title: The Ass and His Driver
author: Aesop's Fables
content: An Ass was being driven along a road leading down the mountain side, when he suddenly took it into his silly head to choose his own path. He could see his stall at the foot of the mountain, and to him the quickest way down seemed to be over the edge of the nearest cliff. Just as he was about to leap over, his master caught him by the tail and tried to pull him back, but the stubborn Ass would not yield and pulled with all his might. "Very well," said his master, "go your way, you willful beast, and see where it leads you." With that he let go, and the foolish Ass tumbled head over heels down the mountain side.
content_zh: 一头驴被赶着走在下山的小路上，突然他那愚蠢的脑袋里冒出一个念头，要自己选路走。他能看到山脚下的厩舍，对他来说，最快的下山路似乎是直接跳下最近的悬崖。正当他要跳下去时，主人抓住了他的尾巴试图把他拉回来，但这头顽固的驴子不肯屈服，拼命挣扎。“好吧，”主人说，“走你的路吧，你这任性的畜生，看看那会带你去哪儿。”说完他松开了手，愚蠢的驴子便大头朝下滚下了山坡。
moral: They who will not listen to reason but stubbornly go their own way against the friendly advice of those who are wiser than they, are on the road to misfortune.
moral_zh: 那些不听从理智，固执己见，无视智者友好建议的人，正走在通往不幸的路上。

title: The Ants and the Grasshopper
author: Aesop's Fables
content: One bright day in late autumn a family of Ants were bustling about in the warm sunshine, drying out the grain they had stored up during the summer, when a starving Grasshopper, his fiddle under his arm, came up and humbly begged for a bite to eat. "What!" cried the Ants in surprise, "haven't you stored anything away for the winter? What in the world were you doing all last summer?" "I didn't have time to store up any food," whined the Grasshopper; "I was so busy making music that before I knew it the summer was gone." The Ants shrugged their shoulders in disgust. "Making music, were you?" they cried. "Very well; now dance!" And they turned their backs on the Grasshopper and went on with their work.
content_zh: 深秋的一个晴朗日子，一群蚂蚁在温暖的阳光下忙碌着，晾晒他们夏天储存的谷物。这时，一只饥肠辘辘的蚂蚱夹着小提琴走过来，低声下气地乞求一口吃的。“什么！”蚂蚁们惊讶地叫道，“你没为冬天储存任何东西吗？你整个夏天到底在干什么？”“我没时间储存食物，”蚂蚱哀嚎道，“我忙着作曲，不知不觉夏天就过去了。”蚂蚁们厌恶地耸耸肩。“作曲是吗？”他们叫道，“很好，现在去跳舞吧！”说完他们背过身去继续干活，不再理会蚂蚱。
moral: There's a time for work and a time for play.
moral_zh: 工作有时，娱乐有时（少壮不努力，老大徒伤悲）。

title: The Bundle of Sticks
author: Aesop's Fables
content: A certain Father had a family of Sons, who were forever quarreling among themselves. No words he could say did the least good, so he cast about in his mind for some very striking example that should make them see that discord would lead them to misfortune. One day when the quarreling had been much more violent than usual and each of the Sons was moping in a surly manner, he asked one of them to bring him a bundle of sticks. Then handing the bundle to each of his Sons in turn he told them to try to break it. But although each one tried his best, none was able to do so. The Father then untied the bundle and gave the sticks to his Sons to break one by one. This they did very easily. "My Sons," said the Father, "do you not see how certain it is that if you agree with each other and help each other, it will be impossible for your enemies to injure you? But if you are divided among yourselves, you will be no stronger than a single stick in that bundle."
content_zh: 一位父亲有一群儿子，他们总是争吵不休。无论他说什么都没用，于是他绞尽脑汁想找个生动的例子，让他们明白不和会导致不幸。一天，当争吵比平时更激烈，每个儿子都气鼓鼓地生闷气时，他让其中一个拿来一捆木棍。然后他把这捆木棍依次递给每个儿子，让他们试着折断它。虽然每个人都竭尽全力，但没人能折断。父亲随后解开捆绑，把木棍一根根给儿子们折。他们很容易就折断了。“孩子们，”父亲说，“你们难道看不出来吗？如果你们团结一致，互相帮助，敌人就不可能伤害你们。但如果你们四分五裂，你们就会像那一根根木棍一样不堪一击。”
moral: In unity is strength.
moral_zh: 团结就是力量。

title: The Ass, the Fox, and the Lion
author: Aesop's Fables
content: An Ass and a Fox had become close comrades, and were constantly in each other's company. While the Ass cropped a fresh bit of greens, the Fox would devour a chicken from the neighboring farmyard or a bit of cheese filched from the dairy. One day the pair unexpectedly met a Lion. The Ass was very much frightened, but the Fox calmed his fears. "I will talk to him," he said. So the Fox walked boldly up to the Lion. "Your highness," he said in an undertone, so the Ass could not hear him, "I've got a fine scheme in my head. If you promise not to hurt me, I will lead that foolish creature yonder into a pit where he can't get out, and you can feast at your pleasure." The Lion agreed and the Fox returned to the Ass. "I made him promise not to hurt us," said the Fox. "But come, I know a good place to hide till he is gone." So the Fox led the Ass into a deep pit. But when the Lion saw that the Ass was his for the taking, he first of all struck down the traitor Fox.
content_zh: 一头驴和一只狐狸成了亲密伙伴，总是形影不离。驴子吃新鲜的青草时，狐狸就吃从邻居农场偷来的鸡或从奶牛场顺来的奶酪。一天，这对搭档意外遇到了一只狮子。驴子吓得不轻，但狐狸安抚了他。“我去跟他谈谈，”他说。于是狐狸大胆地走到狮子面前。“陛下，”他低声说，不想让驴子听见，“我有个好主意。如果您答应不伤害我，我就把那个愚蠢的家伙引到一个出不来的坑里，您可以尽情享用。”狮子同意了，狐狸回到驴子身边。“我让他答应不伤害我们了，”狐狸说，“不过来吧，我知道个躲藏的好地方，等他走了再说。”于是狐狸把驴子引到了一个深坑里。但当狮子看到驴子已经是囊中之物时，他首先打死了背叛朋友的狐狸。
moral: Traitors may expect treachery.
moral_zh: 背叛者必遭背叛。

title: The Wolf and the Lamb
author: Aesop's Fables
content: A stray Lamb stood drinking early one morning on the bank of a woodland stream. That very same morning a hungry Wolf came by farther up the stream, hunting for something to eat. He soon got his eyes on the Lamb. As a rule Mr. Wolf snapped up such delicious morsels without making any bones about it, but this Lamb looked so very helpless and innocent that the Wolf felt he ought to have some kind of an excuse for taking its life. "How dare you paddle around in my stream and stir up all the mud!" he shouted fiercely. "You deserve to be punished severely for your rashness!" "But, your highness," replied the trembling Lamb, "do not be angry! I cannot possibly muddy the water you are drinking up there. Remember, you are upstream and I am downstream." "You do muddy it!" retorted the Wolf savagely. "And besides, I have heard that you told lies about me last year!" "How could I have done so?" pleaded the Lamb. "I wasn't born until this year." "If it wasn't you, it was your brother!" "I have no brothers." "Well, then," snarled the Wolf, "It was someone in your family anyway. But no matter who it was, I do not intend to be talked out of my breakfast." And without more words the Wolf seized the poor Lamb and carried her off to the forest.
content_zh: 一天清晨，一只迷路的小羊站在林间小溪边喝水。同一天早上，一只饥饿的狼来到上游寻找食物。他很快盯上了小羊。通常狼先生会毫不犹豫地一口吞下这样的美味，但这只小羊看起来如此无助和无辜，狼觉得杀她总得找个借口。“你怎么敢在我的小溪里踩来踩去，把泥都搅起来了！”他凶狠地吼道，“你这种鲁莽行为必须受到严厉惩罚！”“但是，陛下，”颤抖的小羊回答，“请别生气！我不把您上面喝的水弄脏。请记住，您在上游，我在下游。”“你就是弄脏了！”狼野蛮地反驳道，“而且，我听说你去年说过我的坏话！”“我怎么可能呢？”小羊辩解道，“我今年才出生。”“如果不是你，那就是你哥哥！”“我没有哥哥。”“好吧，”狼咆哮道，“反正是你家里的谁。不管是谁，我不打算因为你的辩解而失去我的早餐。”说完，狼抓起可怜的小羊把她拖进了森林。
moral:
The tyrant can always find an excuse for his tyranny.
The unjust will not listen to the reasoning of the innocent.
moral_zh: 暴君总能为暴政找到借口。不义者不会听无辜者的讲理。

title: The Travelers and the Sea
author: Aesop's Fables
content: Two Travelers were walking along the seashore. Far out they saw something riding on the waves. "Look," said one, "a great ship rides in from distant lands, bearing rich treasures!" The object they saw came ever nearer the shore. "No," said the other, "that is not a treasure ship. That is some fisherman's skiff, with the day's catch of savoury fish." Still nearer came the object. The waves washed it up on shore. "It is a chest of gold lost from some wreck," they cried. Both Travelers rushed to the beach, but there they found nothing but a water-soaked log.
content_zh: 两个旅行者沿着海边行走。在远处，他们看到有什么东西在波浪上漂浮。“看，”其中一个说，“一艘大船从远方驶来，载着丰富的宝藏！”他们看到的东西离岸边越来越近。“不，”另一个说，“那不是宝船。那是渔夫的小船，载着一天捕获的美味鱼儿。”物体漂得更近了。海浪把它冲上了岸。“这是沉船遗失的金箱子！”他们叫道。两个旅行者冲向海滩，但他们在那里只发现了一根浸水的木头。
moral: Do not let your hopes carry you away from reality.
moral_zh: 不要让希望使你脱离现实（希望越大失望越大）。

title: The Rabbit, the Weasel and the Cat
author: Aesop's Fables
content: A Rabbit left his home one day for a dinner of clover. But he forgot to latch the door of his house and while he was gone a Weasel walked in and calmly made himself at home. When the Rabbit returned, there was the Weasel's nose sticking out of the Rabbit's own doorway, sniffing the fine air. The Rabbit was quite angry—for a Rabbit—, and requested the Weasel to move out. But the Weasel was perfectly content. He was settled down for good. A wise old Cat heard the dispute and offered to settle it. "Come close to me," said the Cat, "I am very deaf. Put your mouths close to my ears while you tell me the facts." The unsuspecting pair did as they were told and in an instant the Cat had them both under her claws. No one could deny that the dispute had been definitely settled.
content_zh: 一天，一只兔子离家去吃三叶草晚餐。但他忘了锁门，在他离开期间，一只鼬鼠走进去，泰然自若地安了家。当兔子回来时，看到鼬鼠的鼻子从自家门口伸出来，嗅着清新的空气。兔子非常生气——对一只兔子来说——要求鼬鼠搬走。但鼬鼠心满意足，打算长住下去。一只聪明的老猫听到了争吵，提出要调解。“靠近我，”猫说，“我耳朵很背。把嘴凑到我耳边告诉我事实。”毫无戒心的两只动物照做了，瞬间猫就把他们压在了爪子下。没人能否认这场纠纷得到了彻底解决。
moral: The strong are apt to settle questions to their own advantage.
moral_zh: 强者倾向于以对自己有利的方式解决问题（鹬蚌相争渔翁得利）。

title: The Monkey and the Cat
author: Aesop's Fables
content: Once upon a time a Cat and a Monkey lived as pets in the same house. They were great friends and were constantly in all sorts of mischief together. What they seemed to think of more than anything else was to get something to eat, and it did not matter much to them how they got it. One day they were sitting by the fire, watching some chestnuts roasting on the hearth. How to get them was the question. "I would gladly get them," said the cunning Monkey, "but you are much more skillful at such things than I am. Pull them out and I'll divide them between us." Pussy stretched out her paw very carefully, pushed aside some of the cinders, and drew back her paw very quickly. Then she tried it again, this time pulling a chestnut half out of the fire. A third time and she drew out the chestnut. This performance she went through several times, each time singeing her paw severely. As fast as she pulled the chestnuts out of the fire, the Monkey ate them up. Now the master came in, and away scampered the rascals, Mistress Cat with a burnt paw and no chestnuts. From that time on, they say, she contented herself with mice and rats and had little to do with Sir Monkey.
content_zh: 很久以前，一只猫和一只猴子作为宠物住在同一所房子里。他们是好朋友，经常一起搞各种恶作剧。他们想得最多的似乎就是怎么弄到吃的，至于怎么弄到的并不重要。一天，他们坐在火边，看着炉膛里烤着的栗子。问题是怎么把它们弄出来。“我很乐意去拿，”狡猾的猴子说，“但在这种事上你比我熟练多了。你把它们拨出来，我来分给我们吃。”猫咪非常小心地伸出爪子，推开一些煤渣，然后迅速缩回爪子。接着她又试了一次，这次把一颗栗子拨出了一半。第三次她把栗子弄了出来。她重复了几次这个动作，每次都把爪子烫得很疼。她刚把栗子从火里拨出来，猴子就立刻把它们吃掉了。这时主人进来了，两个调皮鬼撒腿就跑，猫小姐爪子被烫伤了，却一颗栗子也没吃到。据说从那以后，她只满足于抓老鼠，不再理睬猴子先生了。
moral: The flatterer seeks some benefit at your expense.
moral_zh: 奉承者想利用你来获利（火中取栗）。

title: The Dogs and and the Hides
author: Aesop's Fables
content: Some hungry Dogs saw a number of hides at the bottom of a stream where the Tanner had put them to soak. A fine hide makes an excellent meal for a hungry Dog, but the water was deep and the Dogs could not reach the hides from the bank. So they held a council and decided that the very best thing to do was to drink up the river. All fell to lapping up the water as fast as they could. But though they drank and drank until, one after another, all of them had burst with drinking, still, for all their effort, the water in the river remained as high as ever.
content_zh: 几只饥饿的狗看到河底有一些皮革，那是制革匠浸泡在那里的。对于饥饿的狗来说，一张好皮是一顿美餐，但水很深，狗从岸上够不着皮革。于是他们开了个会，决定最好的办法是把河水喝干。大家都开始尽可能快地喝水。虽然他们喝呀喝，直到一个个都撑破了肚皮，但尽管如此努力，河里的水位还是纹丝不动。
moral: Do not try to do impossible things.
moral_zh: 不要试图做不可能的事（不自量力）。

title: The Oxen and the Wheels
author: Aesop's Fables
content: A pair of Oxen were drawing a heavily loaded wagon along a miry country road. They had to use all their strength to pull the wagon, but they did not complain. The Wheels of the wagon were of a different sort. Though the task they had to do was very light compared with that of the Oxen, they creaked and groaned at every turn. The poor Oxen, pulling with all their might to draw the wagon through the deep mud, had their ears filled with the loud complaining of the Wheels. And this, you may well know, made their work so much the harder to endure. "Silence!" the Oxen cried at last, out of patience. "What have you Wheels to complain about so loudly? We are drawing all the weight, not you, and we are keeping still about it besides."
content_zh: 两头公牛拉着一辆载重货车走在泥泞的乡村道路上。他们不得不使出全身力气拉车，但他没有抱怨。车轮却不同。虽然比起公牛，他们的任务很轻，但他们每转一圈都要吱吱嘎嘎地呻吟。可怜的公牛拼命拉着车穿过深泥，耳朵里充满了车轮大声的抱怨。这就好比火上浇油，让他们的工作更难忍受。“闭嘴！”公牛终于忍无可忍地叫道，“你们车轮有什么好大声抱怨的？拉动所有重量的是我们，不是你们，而且我们还一声不吭呢。”
moral: They complain most who suffer least.
moral_zh: 吃苦最少的人抱怨最多。

title: The Kid and the Wolf
author: Aesop's Fables
content: "A frisky young Kid had been left by the herdsman on the thatched roof of a sheep shelter to keep him out of harm's way. The Kid was browsing near the edge of the roof, when he spied a Wolf and began to jeer at him, making faces and abusing him to his heart's content. "I hear you," said the Wolf, "and I haven't the least grudge against you for what you say or do. When you are up there it is the roof that's talking, not you."
content_zh: 一只活泼的小山羊被牧人留在羊圈的茅草屋顶上，以确保安全。小山羊在屋顶边缘吃草时，看到了一只狼，便开始嘲笑他，做鬼脸，尽情地辱骂他。“我听到了，”狼说，“我对你的言行一点也不记恨。当你站在上面时，是屋顶在说话，不是你。”
moral: Do not say anything at any time that you would not say at all times.
moral_zh: 狐假虎威（环境赋予的优势并不代表真正的实力）。

title: The Lion and the Ass
author: Aesop's Fables
content: One day as the Lion walked proudly down a forest aisle, and the animals respectfully made way for him, an Ass brayed a scornful remark as he passed. The Lion felt a flash of anger. But when he turned his head and saw who had spoken, he walked quietly on. He would not honor the fool with even so much as a stroke of his claws.
content_zh: 一天，狮子骄傲地走过森林通道，动物们恭敬地为他让路，这时一头驴在他经过时发出了一声轻蔑的叫声。狮子感到一阵怒火。但当他转过头看到是谁在说话时，他静静地走了。他不屑于用爪子去拍那个傻瓜一下。
moral: Do not resent the remarks of a fool. Ignore them.
moral_zh: 不要在意傻瓜的言论，无视他们。

title: The Boys and the Frogs
author: Aesop's Fables
content: Some Boys were playing one day at the edge of a pond in which lived a family of Frogs. The Boys amused themselves by throwing stones into the pond so as to make them skip on top of the water. The stones were flying thick and fast and the Boys were enjoying themselves very much; but the poor Frogs in the pond were trembling with fear. At last one of the Frogs, the oldest and bravest, put his head out of the water, and said, "Oh, please, dear children, stop your cruel play! Though it may be fun for you, it means death to us!"
content_zh: 一天，几个男孩在住着一窝青蛙的池塘边玩耍。男孩们扔石头打水漂取乐。石头密集而快速地飞来，男孩们玩得很开心；但池塘里可怜的青蛙却吓得发抖。最后，其中一只最老最勇敢的青蛙把头伸出水面说：“哦，求求你们，亲爱的孩子们，停止你们残酷的游戏吧！虽然这对你们来说很有趣，但对我们来说意味着死亡！”
moral: Always stop to think whether your fun may not be the cause of another's unhappiness.
moral_zh: 要把快乐建立在别人的痛苦之上。

title: The Wolf and the Lion
author: Aesop's Fables
content: A Wolf had stolen a Lamb and was carrying it off to his lair to eat it. But his plans were very much changed when he met a Lion, who, without making any excuses, took the Lamb away from him. The Wolf made off to a safe distance, and then said in a much injured tone: "You have no right to take my property like that!" The Lion looked back, but as the Wolf was too far away to be taught a lesson without too much inconvenience, he said: "Your property? Did you buy it, or did the Shepherd make you a gift of it? Pray tell me, how did you get it?"
content_zh: 一只狼偷了一只小羊，正要把他带回巢穴吃掉。但他遇到了狮子，计划全变了，狮子没有任何借口就抢走了小羊。狼跑到安全距离，然后用非常委屈的语气说：“你没有权利那样抢走我的财产！”狮子回头看了看，但因为狼太远了，教训他太麻烦，于是说：“你的财产？是你买的，还是牧羊人送给你的礼物？请告诉我，你是怎么得来的？”
moral: What is evil won is evil lost.
moral_zh: 不义之财来得快去得也快（黑吃黑）。

title: The Monkey and the Dolphin
author: Aesop's Fables
content: It happened once upon a time that a certain Greek ship bound for Athens was wrecked off the coast close to Piraeus, the port of Athens. Had it not been for the Dolphins, who at that time were very friendly toward mankind and especially toward Athenians, all would have perished. But the Dolphins took the shipwrecked people on their backs and swam with them to shore. Now it was the custom among the Greeks to take their pet monkeys and dogs with them whenever they went on a voyage. So when one of the Dolphins saw a Monkey struggling in the water, he thought it was a man, and made the Monkey climb up on his back. Then off he swam with him toward the shore. The Monkey sat up, grave and dignified, on the Dolphin's back. "You are a citizen of illustrious Athens, are you not?" asked the Dolphin politely. "Yes," answered the Monkey, proudly. "My family is one of the noblest in the city." "Indeed," said the Dolphin. "Then of course you often visit Piraeus." "Yes, yes," replied the Monkey. "Indeed, I do. I am with him constantly. Piraeus is my very best friend." This answer took the Dolphin by surprise, and, turning his head, he now saw what it was he was carrying. Without more ado, he dived and left the foolish Monkey to take care of himself, while he swam off in search of some human being to save.
content_zh: 很久以前，一艘前往雅典的希腊船只在雅典港口比雷埃夫斯附近的海岸失事了。如果不是那时对人类，特别是对雅典人非常友好的海豚，所有人都会丧生。但海豚背着遭遇海难的人游到了岸边。当时希腊人有一个习俗，就是在航行时带上他们的宠物猴子和狗。所以当一只海豚看到一只猴子在水里挣扎时，以为是一个人，就让猴子爬到他的背上。然后他背着猴子游向岸边。猴子在海豚背上坐得端端正正，神情庄重。“你是著名的雅典城的公民，对吗？”海豚礼貌地问。“是的，”猴子骄傲地回答，“我的家族是城里最高贵的家族之一。”“真的吗，”海豚说，“那你一定经常去比雷埃夫斯了。”“是啊，是啊，”猴子回答，“我当然去。我经常和他在一起。比雷埃夫斯是我最好的朋友。”这个回答让海豚大吃一惊，他转过头，这才看清自己背的是什么。他二话没说，潜入水中，丢下愚蠢的猴子让他自生自灭，自己游去寻找需要获救的人类了。
moral: One falsehood leads to another.
moral_zh: 一个谎言由于另一个谎言（撒谎终会被揭穿）。

title: The Ass and the Grasshoppers
author: Aesop's Fables
content: One day as an Ass was walking in the pasture, he found some Grasshoppers chirping merrily in a grassy corner of the field. He listened with a great deal of admiration to the song of the Grasshoppers. It was such a joyful song that his pleasure-loving heart was filled with a wish to sing as they did. "What is it?" he asked very respectfully, "that has given you such beautiful voices? Is there any special food you eat, or is it some divine nectar that makes you sing so wonderfully?" "Yes," said the Grasshoppers, who were very fond of a joke; "it is the dew we drink! Try some and see." So thereafter the Ass would eat nothing and drink nothing but dew. Naturally, the poor foolish Ass soon died.
content_zh: 一天，一头驴子在牧场上散步，发现角落的草丛里有几只蚂蚱在快乐地叫着。他非常羡慕地听着蚂蚱的歌声。这歌声如此欢快，让他那颗热爱享乐的心充满了像他们一样歌唱的愿望。“是什么？”他非常恭敬地问，“让你们拥有如此美妙的声音？是因为你们吃了什么特别的食物，还是喝了什么神酒才让你们唱得这么好听？”“是的，”喜欢开玩笑的蚂蚱说，“我们喝的是露水！你试试看。”于是从此以后，驴子只吃露水，只喝露水。自然，这头可怜愚蠢的驴子很快就死了。
moral: The laws of nature are unchangeable.
moral_zh: 自然规律不可改变（不要盲目模仿）。

title: A Raven and a Swan
author: Aesop's Fables
content: A Raven, which you know is black as coal, was envious of the Swan, because her feathers were as white as the purest snow. The foolish bird got the idea that if he lived like the Swan, swimming and diving all day long and eating the weeds and plants that grow in the water, his feathers would turn white like the Swan's. So he left his home in the woods and fields and flew down to live on the lakes and in the marshes. But though he washed and washed all day long, almost drowning himself at it, his feathers remained as black as ever. And as the water weeds he ate did not agree with him, he got thinner and thinner, and at last he died.
content_zh: 一只乌鸦，你知道他是黑得像煤炭一样的，嫉妒天鹅，因为她的羽毛像最纯净的雪一样白。这只愚蠢的鸟以为，如果他像天鹅一样生活，整天游泳潜水，吃水里生长的水草，他的羽毛就会像天鹅一样变白。于是他离开了森林和田野的家，飞到湖边和沼泽地生活。但虽然他整天洗啊洗，差点把自己淹死，他的羽毛还是和以前一样黑。而且因为吃不惯水草，他变得越来越瘦，最后死了。
moral: A change of habits will not alter nature.
moral_zh: 改变习惯改变不了本性（江山易改，本性难移）。

title: The Mice and the Weasels
author: Aesop's Fables
content: The Weasels and the Mice were always up in arms against each other. In every battle the Weasels carried off the victory, as well as a large number of the Mice, which they ate for dinner next day. In despair the Mice called a council, and there it was decided that the Mouse army was always beaten because it had no leaders. So a large number of generals and commanders were appointed from among the most eminent Mice. To distinguish themselves from the soldiers in the ranks, the new leaders proudly bound on their heads lofty crests and ornaments of feathers or straw. Then after long preparation of the Mouse army in all the arts of war, they sent a challenge to the Weasels. The Weasels accepted the challenge with eagerness, for they were always ready for a fight when a meal was in sight. They immediately attacked the Mouse army in large numbers. Soon the Mouse line gave way before the attack and the whole army fled for cover. The privates easily slipped into their holes, but the Mouse leaders could not squeeze through the narrow openings because of their head-dresses. Not one escaped the teeth of the hungry Weasels.
content_zh: 鼬鼠和老鼠总是处于战争状态。在每次战斗中，鼬鼠都取得胜利，并抓走大量老鼠作为第二天的晚餐。绝望中，老鼠们召开了一次会议，大家认为老鼠军队总是被打败是因为没有领袖。于是他们从最杰出的老鼠中任命了大量的将军和指挥官。为了让自己与普通士兵区分开来，新领袖们骄傲地在头上绑上了高高的冠饰、羽毛或稻草装饰。然后在老鼠军队进行了长期的战术准备后，他们向鼬鼠发出了挑战。鼬鼠急切地接受了挑战，因为只要有食物，他们随时准备战斗。他们立即大举进攻老鼠军队。很快，老鼠防线在攻击下崩溃，全军逃窜寻找掩护。普通士兵很容易溜进洞里，但老鼠领袖们却因为头饰被卡住，挤不进狭窄的洞口。结果没有一个逃脱饥饿的鼬鼠的牙齿。
moral: Greatness has its penalties.
moral_zh: 地位越高，风险越大（枪打出头鸟）。

title: The Fox and the Leopard
author: Aesop's Fables
content: A Fox and a Leopard, resting lazily after a generous dinner, amused themselves by disputing about their good looks. The Leopard was very proud of his glossy, spotted coat and made disdainful remarks about the Fox, whose appearance he declared was quite ordinary. The Fox prided himself on his fine bushy tail with its tip of white, but he was wise enough to see that he could not rival the Leopard in looks. Still he kept up a flow of sarcastic talk, just to exercise his wits and to have the fun of disputing. The Leopard was about to lose his temper when the Fox got up, yawning lazily. "You may have a very smart coat," he said, "but you would be a great deal better off if you had a little more smartness inside your head and less on your ribs, the way I am. That's what I call real beauty."
content_zh: 一只狐狸和一只豹子美餐后懒洋洋地休息，为了打发时间，争论起谁更好看。豹子对他光亮、有斑点的皮毛非常自豪，轻蔑地评论狐狸，说他长得很普通。狐狸为自己那条白尾尖的蓬松大尾巴感到自豪，但他聪明地意识到自己在长相上比不过豹子。但他还是滔滔不绝地说着风凉话，只是为了锻炼脑子，享受争论的乐趣。豹子正要发脾气，狐狸站起来，懒洋洋地打了个哈欠。“你也许有一件漂亮的外衣，”他说，“但如果你的脑子里多一点智慧，而不是都在肋骨上，你会过得更好，就像我一样。那才是我所谓的真正美丽。”
moral: A fine coat is not always an indication of an attractive mind.
moral_zh: 美丽的外表并不总是代表迷人的心灵（绣花枕头烂草包）。

title: The Eagle and the Jackdaw
author: Aesop's Fables
content: An Eagle, swooping down on powerful wings, seized a lamb in her talons and made off with it to her nest. A Jackdaw saw the deed, and his silly head was filled with the idea that he was big and strong enough to do as the Eagle had done. So with much rustling of feathers and a fierce air, he came down swiftly on the back of a large Ram. But when he tried to rise again he found that he could not get away, for his claws were tangled in the wool. And so far was he from carrying away the Ram, that the Ram hardly noticed he was there. The Shepherd saw the fluttering Jackdaw and at once guessed what had happened. Running up, he caught the bird and clipped its wings. That evening he gave the Jackdaw to his children. "What a funny bird this is!" they said laughing, "what do you call it, father?" "That is a Jackdaw, my children. But if you should ask him, he would say he is an Eagle."
content_zh: 一只鹰凭借强有力的翅膀俯冲下来，用爪子抓住一只小羊，带回了巢。一只寒鸦看到了这一幕，愚蠢的脑袋里充满了他也可以像鹰一样强大去做的念头。于是他带着猛烈的气势和羽毛的摩擦声，迅速冲下一只大公羊的背。但当他想再次飞起时，发现自己飞不走了，因为他的爪子缠在了羊毛里。别说带走公羊了，公羊几乎没注意到他在那儿。牧羊人看到扑腾的寒鸦，立刻猜到了发生了什么。他跑过去抓住这只鸟，修剪了他的翅膀。那天晚上他把寒鸦给了孩子们。“这是只多么有趣的鸟啊！”他们笑着说，“这叫什么鸟，爸爸？”“那是只寒鸦，孩子们。但如果你问他，他会说他是一只鹰。”
moral: Do not let your vanity make you overestimate your powers.
moral_zh: 不要让虚荣心使你高估自己的能力（东施效颦）。

title: The Dog, the Cock, and the Fox
author: Aesop's Fables
content: A Dog and a Cock, who were the best of friends, wished very much to see something of the world. So they decided to leave the farmyard and to set out into the world along the road that led to the woods. The two comrades traveled along in the very best of spirits and without meeting any adventure to speak of. At nightfall the Cock, looking for a place to roost, as was his custom, spied nearby a hollow tree that he thought would do very nicely for a night's lodging. The Dog could creep inside and the Cock would fly up on one of the branches. So said, so done, and both slept very comfortably. With the first glimmer of dawn the Cock awoke. For the moment he forgot just where he was. He thought he was still in the farmyard where it had been his duty to arouse the household at daybreak. So standing on tip-toes he flapped his wings and crowed lustily. But instead of awakening the farmer, he awakened a Fox not far off in the wood. The Fox immediately had rosy visions of a very delicious breakfast. Hurrying to the tree where the Cock was roosting, he said very politely: "A hearty welcome to our woods, honored sir. I cannot tell you how glad I am to see you here. I am quite sure we shall become the closest of friends." "I feel highly flattered, kind sir," replied the Cock slyly. "If you will please go around to the door of my house at the foot of the tree, my porter will let you in." The hungry but unsuspecting Fox, went around the tree as he was told, and in a twinkling the Dog had seized him.
content_zh: 一只狗和一只公鸡是最好的朋友，很想去看看世界。于是他们决定离开农场，沿着通往树林的路出发去闯荡世界。两位伙伴兴致勃勃地赶路，没遇到什么值得一提的冒险。夜幕降临时，公鸡按照习惯寻找栖息的地方，发现附近有一棵空心树，觉得很适合过夜。狗可以钻进洞里，公鸡则飞到树枝上。说干就干，两个都睡得很舒服。黎明的第一缕曙光出现时，公鸡醒了。那一刻他忘了自己在哪里。他以为自己还在农场，在那里的职责是天亮时叫醒全家。于是他踮起脚尖，拍打翅膀，高声啼叫。但他不仅没叫醒农夫，反而叫醒了不远处树林里的一只狐狸。狐狸立刻幻想到了美味的早餐。他急忙跑到公鸡栖息的树下，非常有礼貌地说：“热烈欢迎来到我们的树林，尊敬的先生。我无法表达见到您有多高兴。我确信我们会成为最亲密的朋友。”“我不胜荣幸，好心的先生，”公鸡狡黠地回答，“如果您能绕到树下我房子的门口，我的门房会给您开门的。”饥饿但毫无戒心的狐狸照他说的绕到树后，瞬间就被狗抓住了。
moral: Those who try to deceive may expect to be paid in their own coin.
moral_zh: 想骗人者终将被骗（以其人之道还治其人之身）。

title: The Frog and the Mouse
author: Aesop's Fables
content: A young Mouse in search of adventure was running along the bank of a pond where lived a Frog. When the Frog saw the Mouse, he swam to the bank and croaked: "Won't you pay me a visit? I can promise you a good time if you do." The Mouse did not need much coaxing, for he was very anxious to see the world and everything in it. But though he could swim a little, he did not dare risk going into the pond without some help. The Frog had a plan. He tied the Mouse's leg to his own with a tough reed. Then into the pond he jumped, dragging his foolish companion with him. The Mouse soon had enough of it and wanted to return to shore; but the treacherous Frog had other plans. He pulled the Mouse down under the water and drowned him. But before he could untie the reed that bound him to the dead Mouse, a Hawk came sailing over the pond. Seeing the body of the Mouse floating on the water, the Hawk swooped down, seized the Mouse and carried it off, with the Frog dangling from its leg. Thus at one swoop he had caught both meat and fish for his dinner.
content_zh: 一只寻找冒险的年轻老鼠沿着池塘边奔跑，那里住着一只青蛙。当青蛙看到老鼠时，游到岸边呱呱叫道：“你不来拜访我吗？我保证你会玩得开心的。”老鼠不需要太多劝说，因为他非常渴望看看这个世界。虽然他会一点游泳，但他不敢在没有帮助的情况下冒险下水。青蛙有个计划。他用一根坚韧的芦苇把老鼠的腿绑在自己的腿上。然后他跳进池塘，拖着他那愚蠢的同伴。老鼠很快就受够了，想回岸上；但奸诈的青蛙另有打算。他把老鼠拉到水下淹死了。但在他解开绑着死老鼠的芦苇之前，一只老鹰飞过池塘。看到漂浮在水面上的老鼠尸体，老鹰俯冲下来，抓起老鼠飞走了，青蛙还悬挂在老鼠的腿上。就这样，老鹰一次俯冲就抓到了肉和鱼作为晚餐。
moral: Those who seek to harm others often come to harm themselves through their own deceit.
moral_zh: 害人终害己。

title: The Man and the Satyr
author: Aesop's Fables
content: A long time ago a Man met a Satyr in the forest and succeeded in making friends with him. The two soon became the best of comrades, living together in the Man's hut. But one cold winter evening, as they were walking homeward, the Satyr saw the Man blow on his fingers. "Why do you do that?" asked the Satyr. "To warm my hands," the Man replied. When they reached home the Man prepared two bowls of porridge. These he placed steaming hot on the table, and the comrades sat down very cheerfully to enjoy the meal. But much to the Satyr's surprise, the Man began to blow into his bowl of porridge. "Why do you do that?" he asked. "To cool my porridge," replied the Man. The Satyr sprang hurriedly to his feet and made for the door. "Goodby," he said, "I've seen enough. A fellow that blows hot and cold in the same breath cannot be friends with me!"
content_zh: 很久以前，一个人在森林里遇到了一个半羊人，并成功和他交了朋友。两人很快成了最好的伙伴，一起住在人的小屋里。但一个寒冷的冬夜，当他们走回家时，半羊人看到人往手指上吹气。“你为什么那样做？”半羊人问。“为了暖手，”人回答。当他们到家后，人准备了两碗粥。他把热气腾腾的粥放在桌上，伙伴们很高兴地坐下来享用美餐。但让半羊人惊讶的是，人开始往粥碗里吹气。“你为什么那样做？”他问。“为了把粥吹凉，”人回答。半羊人急忙站起来走向门口。“再见，”他说，“我看够了。一个同一张嘴既吹热气又吹冷气的家伙不能做我的朋友！（意指反复无常、当面一套背后一套）”
moral: The man who talks for both sides is not to be trusted by either.
moral_zh: 两面三刀的人不值得任何人信任。

title: The Cock and the Jewel
author: Aesop's Fables
content: A Cock was busily scratching and scraping about to find something to eat for himself and his family, when he happened to turn up a precious jewel that had been lost by its owner. "Aha!" said the Cock. "No doubt you are very costly and he who lost you would give a great deal to find you. But as for me, I would choose a single grain of barleycorn before all the jewels in the world."
content_zh: 一只公鸡正忙着到处抓挠，为自己和家人寻找食物，这时他碰巧翻出了一颗主人丢失的珍贵宝石。“啊哈！”公鸡说，“毫无疑问你很值钱，丢了你的人肯定愿意花大价钱找到你。但对我来说，我宁愿要一粒大麦，也不要世界上所有的珠宝。”
moral: Precious things are without value to those who cannot prize them.
moral_zh: 对于不懂欣赏的人来说，珍宝一文不值（各取所需）。

title: The Fox and the Lion
author: Aesop's Fables
content: A very young Fox, who had never before seen a Lion, happened to meet one in the forest. A single look was enough to send the Fox off at top speed for the nearest hiding place. The second time the Fox saw the Lion he stopped behind a tree to look at him a moment before slinking away. But the third time, the Fox went boldly up to the Lion and, without turning a hair, said, "Hello, there, old top."
content_zh: 一只从未见过狮子的年轻狐狸，偶然在森林里遇到了一只。只看了一眼，狐狸就以最快的速度逃向最近的藏身处。第二次狐狸看到狮子时，他停在树后看了一会儿，然后溜走了。但第三次，狐狸大胆地走到狮子面前，面不改色地说：“喂，老兄。”
moral:
Familiarity breeds contempt.
Acquaintance with evil blinds us to its dangers.
moral_zh: 熟悉产生轻视（少见多怪，多见不怪）。与恶为伍会让我们对危险视而不见。

title: The Birds, the Beasts, and the Bat
author: Aesop's Fables
content: The Birds and the Beasts declared war against each other. No compromise was possible, and so they went at it tooth and claw. It is said the quarrel grew out of the persecution the race of Geese suffered at the teeth of the Fox family. The Beasts, too, had cause for fight. The Eagle was constantly pouncing on the Hare, and the Owl dined daily on Mice. It was a terrible battle. Many a Hare and many a Mouse died. Chickens and Geese fell by the score—and the victor always stopped for a feast. Now the Bat family had not openly joined either side. They were a very politic race. So when they saw the Birds getting the better of it, they were Birds for all there was in it. But when the tide of battle turned, they immediately sided with the Beasts. When the battle was over, the conduct of the Bats was discussed at the peace conference. Such deceit was unpardonable, and Birds and Beasts made common cause to drive out the Bats. And since then the Bat family hides in dark towers and deserted ruins, flying out only in the night.
content_zh: 鸟类和兽类宣战了。没有妥协的可能，于是它们展开了殊死搏斗。据说这是因为鹅族受到狐狸家族的迫害引发的争吵。兽类也有战斗的理由。鹰不断扑杀野兔，猫头鹰每天吃老鼠。这是一场可怕的战斗。许多野兔和老鼠死去了。鸡和鹅成批倒下——胜利者总是停下来享用盛宴。蝙蝠家族没有公开加入任何一方。它们是非常圆滑的种族。所以当它们看到鸟类占上风时，它们就全力支持鸟类。但当战局逆转时，它们立即倒向兽类。战斗结束后，在和平会议上讨论了蝙蝠的行为。这种欺骗行为是不可原谅的，鸟类和兽类联合起来驱逐了蝙蝠。从此以后，蝙蝠家族就躲在黑暗的塔楼和废墟中，只在夜间飞出来。
moral: The deceitful have no friends.
moral_zh: 骗子没有朋友（骑墙派没有好下场）。

title: Hercules and the Wagoner
author: Aesop's Fables
content: A Farmer was driving his wagon along a miry country road after a heavy rain. The horses could hardly drag the load through the deep mud, and at last came to a standstill when one of the wheels sank to the hub in a rut. The farmer climbed down from his seat and stood beside the wagon looking at it but without making the least effort to get it out of the rut. All he did was to curse his bad luck and call loudly on Hercules to come to his aid. Then, it is said, Hercules really did appear, saying: "Put your shoulder to the wheel, man, and urge on your horses. Do you think you can move the wagon by simply looking at it and whining about it? Hercules will not help unless you make some effort to help yourself." And when the farmer put his shoulder to the wheel and urged on the horses, the wagon moved very readily, and soon the Farmer was riding along in great content and with a good lesson learned.
content_zh: 一场大雨后，一个农夫赶着货车走在泥泞的乡村道路上。马匹艰难地拉着重物穿过深泥，最后当一个轮子陷进车辙直到轮毂时，车子停了下来。农夫从座位上爬下来，站在车旁看着，却不费一点力气把车弄出来。他所做的只是诅咒自己的坏运气，并大声呼唤大力神海格力斯来帮忙。据说，海格力斯真的出现了，说：“把你的肩膀顶在车轮上，伙计，赶你的马。你以为光看着发牢骚就能推动车子吗？除非你自己努力，否则大力神是不会帮你的。”当农夫把肩膀顶在车轮上并催促马匹时，车子很快移动了，农夫很快开心地赶着路，学到了很好的一课。
moral:
Self help is the best help.
Heaven helps those who help themselves.
moral_zh: 自助者天助。

title: The Travelers and the Purse
author: Aesop's Fables
content: Two men were traveling in company along the road when one of them picked up a well-filled purse. "How lucky I am!" he said. "I have found a purse. Judging by its weight it must be full of gold." "Do not say 'I have found a purse,'" said his companion. "Say rather 'we have found a purse' and 'how lucky we are.' Travelers ought to share alike the fortunes or misfortunes of the road." "No, no," replied the other angrily. "I found it and I am going to keep it." Just then they heard a shout of "Stop, thief!" and looking around, saw a mob of people armed with clubs coming down the road. The man who had found the purse fell into a panic. "We are lost if they find the purse on us," he cried. "No, no," replied the other, "You would not say 'we' before, so now stick to your 'I'. Say 'I am lost.'"
content_zh: 两个人在路上结伴而行，其中一人捡到了一个装得满满的钱包。“我真幸运！”他说，“我捡到了一个钱包。看这重量里面肯定装满了金子。”“别说‘我捡到了一个钱包’，”他的同伴说，“应该说‘我们捡到了一个钱包’，还有‘我们真幸运’。旅行者应该同甘共苦。”“不，不，”那人愤怒地回答，“是我捡到的，我要自己留着。”就在这时，他们听到有人喊“抓贼啊！”，回头一看，一群人拿着木棍冲了过来。捡到钱包的人慌了。“如果我们被发现身上有钱包，我们就完了，”他叫道。“不，不，”同伴回答，“你之前不肯说‘我们’，所以现在坚持你的‘我’吧。说‘我完了’。”
moral: We cannot expect any one to share our misfortunes unless we are willing to share our good fortune also.
moral_zh: 除非我们愿意分享好运，否则不能指望别人分担我们的不幸。

title: The Leap at Rhodes
author: Aesop's Fables
content: A certain man who visited foreign lands could talk of little when he returned to his home except the wonderful adventures he had met with and the great deeds he had done abroad. One of the feats he told about was a leap he had made in a city Called Rhodes. That leap was so great, he said, that no other man could leap anywhere near the distance. A great many persons in Rhodes had seen him do it and would prove that what he told was true. "No need of witnesses," said one of the hearers. "Suppose this city is Rhodes. Now show us how far you can jump."
content_zh: 有一个人去外国游历，回到家乡后，除了他在国外遇到的奇遇和伟大事迹外，几乎不谈别的。他吹嘘的壮举之一是在罗德岛的一个城市做的一次跳跃。他说那一跳非常远，没有其他人能跳得那也没远。罗德岛的许多人都见过他跳，可以证明他说的是真的。“不需要证人，”其中一个听众说，“假设这座城市就是罗德岛。现在跳给我们看看你能跳多远。”
moral: Deeds count, not boasting words.
moral_zh: 事实胜于雄辩（用行动说话）。

title: The Dogs and the Fox
author: Aesop's Fables
content: Some Dogs found the skin of a Lion and furiously began to tear it with their teeth. A Fox chanced to see them and laughed scornfully. "If that Lion had been alive," he said, "it would have been a very different story. He would have made you feel how much sharper his claws are than your teeth."
content_zh: 几只狗发现了一张狮子皮，疯狂地用牙齿撕咬起来。一只狐狸碰巧看到，轻蔑地笑了。“如果那只狮子还活着，”他说，“故事就会完全不同了。他会让你们感觉到他的爪子比你们的牙齿锋利得多。”
moral: It is easy and also contemptible to kick a man that is down.
moral_zh: 落井下石既容易又可鄙。

title: The Mother and the Wolf
author: Aesop's Fables
content: Early one morning a hungry Wolf was prowling around a cottage at the edge of a village, when he heard a child crying in the house. Then he heard the Mother's voice say: "Hush, child, hush! Stop your crying, or I will give you to the Wolf!" Surprised but delighted at the prospect of so delicious a meal, the Wolf settled down under an open window, expecting every moment to have the child handed out to him. But though the little one continued to fret, the Wolf waited all day in vain. Then, toward nightfall, he heard the Mother's voice again as she sat down near the window to sing and rock her baby to sleep. "There, child, there! The Wolf shall not get you. No, no! Daddy is watching and Daddy will kill him if he should come near!" Just then the Father came within sight of the home, and the Wolf was barely able to save himself from the Dogs by a clever bit of running.
content_zh: 一天清晨，一只饿狼在村边的茅屋附近徘徊，这时他听到屋里有个孩子在哭。接着他听到母亲的声音说：“嘘，孩子，嘘！别哭了，不然我就把你给狼吃！”狼对这顿美餐的前景感到惊讶又高兴，便在开着的窗户下安顿下来，时刻等着孩子被递出来。虽然小家伙继续哭闹，但狼等了一整天也没等到。临近傍晚，他再次听到母亲的声音，她坐在窗边唱歌哄孩子睡觉。“好了，孩子，好了！狼抓不到你。不，不！爸爸在看着呢，如果狼敢靠近，爸爸就会杀了他！”就在这时，父亲出现了，狼靠着机灵的奔跑才勉强从狗爪下逃脱。
moral: Do not believe everything you hear.
moral_zh: 不要轻信此言（有些话只是说说而已）。

title: The Wolf and His Shadow
author: Aesop's Fables
content: A Wolf left his lair one evening in fine spirits and an excellent appetite. As he ran, the setting sun cast his shadow far out on the ground, and it looked as if the wolf were a hundred times bigger than he really was. "Why," exclaimed the Wolf proudly, "see how big I am! Fancy me running away from a puny Lion! I'll show him who is fit to be king, he or I." Just then an immense shadow blotted him out entirely, and the next instant a Lion struck him down with a single blow.
content_zh: 一天傍晚，一只狼离开巢穴，精神饱满，胃口极好。当他奔跑时，落日把他的影子在地上拉得很长，看起来比他实际大了一百倍。“哇，”狼骄傲地惊叹，“看我有多大！想想我竟然还要躲避一只瘦小的狮子！我要让他看看谁才配当国王，是他还是我。”就在这时，一个巨大的阴影完全遮住了他，下一瞬间，一只狮子一巴掌把他打倒在地。
moral: Do not let your fancy make you forget realities.
moral_zh: 不要让幻想使你忘记现实（要有自知之明）。

title: The Monkey and the Camel
author: Aesop's Fables
content: At a great celebration in honor of King Lion, the Monkey was asked to dance for the company. His dancing was very clever indeed, and the animals were all highly pleased with his grace and lightness. The praise that was showered on the Monkey made the Camel envious. He was very sure that he could dance quite as well as the Monkey, if not better, so he pushed his way into the crowd that was gathered around the Monkey, and rising on his hind legs, began to dance. But the big hulking Camel made himself very ridiculous as he kicked out his knotty legs and twisted his long clumsy neck. Besides, the animals found it hard to keep their toes from under his heavy hoofs. At last, when one of his huge feet came within an inch of King Lion's nose, the animals were so disgusted that they set upon the Camel in a rage and drove him out into the desert. Shortly afterward, refreshments, consisting mostly of Camel's hump and ribs, were served to the company.
content_zh: 在为狮子王举行的盛大庆典上，猴子被邀请为大家跳舞。他的舞姿确实非常灵巧，动物们都对他优雅轻盈的动作非常满意。对猴子的赞美让骆驼心生嫉妒。他确信自己也能跳得和猴子一样好，甚至更好，于是他挤进围观猴子的人群，用后腿站立起来，开始跳舞。但这只笨重的骆驼踢着满是疙瘩的腿，扭着细长笨拙的脖子，让自己看起来非常可笑。而且，动物们很难不被他沉重的蹄子踩到脚。最后，当他的一只大脚差点踢到狮子王的鼻子时，动物们非常厌恶，愤怒地攻击骆驼，把他赶到了沙漠里。不久之后，大家享用了点心，主要是骆驼峰和骆驼排骨。
moral: Do not try to ape your betters.
moral_zh: 东施效颦（不要盲目模仿比你强的人）。

title: The Dog and His Master's Dinner
author: Aesop's Fables
content: A Dog had learned to carry his master's dinner to him every day. He was very faithful to his duty, though the smell of the good things in the basket tempted him. The Dogs in the neighborhood noticed him carrying the basket and soon discovered what was in it. They made several attempts to steal it from him. But he always guarded it faithfully. Then one day all the Dogs in the neighborhood got together and met him on his way with the basket. The Dog tried to run away from them. But at last he stopped to argue. That was his mistake. They soon made him feel so ridiculous that he dropped the basket and seized a large piece of roast meat intended for his master's dinner. "Very well," he said, "you divide the rest."
content_zh: 一只狗学会了每天给主人送晚餐。他非常忠于职守，尽管篮子里美食的香气诱惑着他。附近的狗注意到他提着篮子，很快发现里面有什么。他们试了几次想偷走，但他总是忠实地守护着。直到有一天，附近所有的狗聚在一起，在他送饭的路上拦住了他。狗试图逃跑。但最后他停下来争论。那是他的错误。他们很快让他觉得自己很可笑，于是他扔下篮子，抢了一大块本来给他主人的烤肉。“好吧，”他说，“剩下的你们分吧。”
moral: Do not stop to argue with temptation.
moral_zh: 不要试图与诱惑争辩（一旦动摇就容易堕落）。

title: The Vain Jackdaw and his Borrowed Feathers
title_zh: 虚荣的寒鸦和借来的羽毛
author: Aesop's Fables
content: A Jackdaw chanced to fly over the garden of the King's palace. There he saw with much wonder and envy a flock of royal Peacocks in all the glory of their splendid plumage. Now the black Jackdaw was not a very handsome bird, nor very refined in manner. Yet he imagined that all he needed to make himself fit for the society of the Peacocks was a dress like theirs. So he picked up some castoff feathers of the Peacocks and stuck them among his own black plumes. Dressed in his borrowed finery he strutted loftily among the birds of his own kind.
