Then he flew down into the garden among the Peacocks. But they soon saw who he was. Angry at the cheat, they flew at him, plucking away the borrowed feathers and also some of his own. The poor Jackdaw returned sadly to his former companions. There another unpleasant surprise awaited him. They had not forgotten his superior airs toward them, and, to punish him, they drove him away with a rain of pecks and jeers.
content_zh: 一只寒鸦偶然飞过国王宫殿的花园。在那里，他惊奇而羡慕地看到一群皇家孔雀展示着它们灿烂辉煌的羽毛。黑色的寒鸦既不英俊，举止也不优雅。但他幻想自己之所以不能融入孔雀的圈子，只是因为缺一件像他们那样的衣服。于是他捡起孔雀脱落的羽毛，插在自己的黑羽毛中间。穿着借来的盛装，他在同类中高傲地昂首阔步。然后他飞到花园里的孔雀中间。但孔雀们很快看穿了他。对他这种欺骗行为感到愤怒，它们扑向他，拔掉了借来的羽毛，连带着也拔掉了他自己的一些羽毛。可怜的寒鸦悲伤地回到以前的同伴身边。但在那里还有一个不愉快的惊喜等着他。它们没忘记他之前那副高人一等的架势，为了惩罚他，它们用一阵啄击和嘲笑把他赶走了。
moral: Borrowed feathers do not make fine birds.
moral_zh: 借来的羽毛成就不了漂亮的鸟（金玉其外，败絮其中）。

title: The Rat and the Elephant
author: Aesop's Fables
content: A Rat was traveling along the King's highway. He was a very proud Rat, considering his small size and the bad reputation all Rats have. As Mr. Rat walked along—he kept mostly to the ditch—he noticed a great commotion up the road, and soon a grand procession came in view. It was the King and his retinue. The King rode on a huge Elephant adorned with the most gorgeous trappings. With the King in his luxurious howdah were the royal Dog and Cat. A great crowd of people followed the procession. They were so taken up with admiration of the Elephant, that the Rat was not noticed. His pride was hurt. "What fools!" he cried. "Look at me, and you will soon forget that clumsy Elephant! Is it his great size that makes your eyes pop out? Or is it his wrinkled hide? Why, I have eyes and ears and as many legs as he! I am of just as much importance, and"— But just then the royal Cat spied him, and the next instant, the Rat knew he was not quite so important as an Elephant.
content_zh: 一只老鼠在国王的大道上行走。考虑到他又小名声又坏，他还是只非常骄傲的老鼠。当鼠先生往前走时——他主要贴着沟边走——他注意到路上有一阵骚动，很快一支盛大的队伍出现在视野中。那是国王和他的随从。国王骑着一头装饰华丽的大象。和国王一起坐在豪华象轿里的是皇家狗和猫。一大群人跟随在后。他们都忙着赞美大象，没人注意到老鼠。他的自尊心受到了伤害。“一群傻瓜！”他喊道，“看看我，你们很快就会忘记那头笨重的大象！是他的巨大体型让你们瞪大了眼睛吗？还是他皱巴巴的皮？我有眼睛、耳朵，腿也和他一样多！我也同样重要，而且——”但就在这时，皇家猫发现了他，下一瞬间，老鼠就知道自己并没有大象那么重要了。
moral: A resemblance to the great in some things does not make us great.
moral_zh: 在某些方面与伟大相似并不意味着我们也伟大。

title: The Sheep and the Pig
author: Aesop's Fables
content: One day a shepherd discovered a fat Pig in the meadow where his Sheep were pastured. He very quickly captured the porker, which squealed at the top of its voice the moment the Shepherd laid his hands on it. You would have thought, to hear the loud squealing, that the Pig was being cruelly hurt. But in spite of its squeals and struggles to escape, the Shepherd tucked his prize under his arm and started off to the butcher's in the market place. The Sheep in the pasture were much astonished and amused at the Pig's behavior, and followed the Shepherd and his charge to the pasture gate. "What makes you squeal like that?" asked one of the Sheep. "The Shepherd often catches and carries off one of us. But we should feel very much ashamed to make such a terrible fuss about it like you do." "That is all very well," replied the Pig, with a squeal and a frantic kick. "When he catches you he is only after your wool. But he wants my bacon! gree-ee-ee!"
content_zh: 一天，牧羊人发现他的羊群吃草的牧场里有一只肥猪。他很快抓住了这只猪，牧羊人一碰它，它就拼命尖叫。听到那响亮的尖叫声，你还会以为这只猪受到了残酷的伤害。但尽管它尖叫挣扎着想逃跑，牧羊人还是夹着战利品前往市场的肉铺。牧场里的羊对猪的行为感到非常惊讶和好笑，跟着牧羊人和他的猎物走到牧场门口。“你为什么叫成那样？”一只羊问，“牧羊人经常抓我们中的一个带走。但如果像你这样大吵大闹，我们会感到非常羞愧。”“说得轻巧，”猪一边尖叫一边疯狂踢打回答道，“他抓你们只是为了要你们的毛。但他想要我的肉啊！唧——唧——唧！”
moral: It is easy to be brave when there is no danger.
moral_zh: 站着说话不腰疼（没有危险时表现勇敢很容易）。

title: The Peacock
author: Aesop's Fables
content: The Peacock, they say, did not at first have the beautiful feathers in which he now takes so much pride. These, Juno, whose favorite he was, granted to him one day when he begged her for a train of feathers to distinguish him from the other birds. Then, decked in his finery, gleaming with emerald, gold, purple, and azure, he strutted proudly among the birds. All regarded him with envy. Even the most beautiful pheasant could see that his beauty was surpassed. Presently the Peacock saw an Eagle soaring high up in the blue sky and felt a desire to fly, as he had been accustomed to do. Lifting his wings he tried to rise from the ground. But the weight of his magnificent train held him down. Instead of flying up to greet the first rays of the morning sun or to bathe in the rosy light among the floating clouds at sunset, he would have to walk the ground more encumbered and oppressed than any common barnyard fowl.
content_zh: 据说孔雀起初并没有现在引以为傲的美丽羽毛。这些羽毛是朱诺（天后）有一天赐给他的，因为他是朱诺的宠儿，他恳求朱诺赐给他一尾羽毛，以前和其他鸟类区分开来。于是，身着盛装，闪耀着翡翠、黄金、紫色和蔚蓝光芒的他，骄傲地在鸟群中阔步。所有鸟都羡慕地看着他。即使是最美丽的野鸡也能看出自己的美貌被超越了。不久，孔雀看到一只鹰在高高的蓝天翱翔，心里也想飞，就像他以前习惯做的那样。他展开翅膀试图从地上飞起。但他那华丽的长尾巴的重量把他压了下来。与其飞上去迎接清晨的第一缕阳光，或在日落时分漂浮的云彩间沐浴玫瑰色的光芒，他不得不比任何普通的家禽更笨重、更压抑地在地上行走。
moral: Do not sacrifice your freedom for the sake of pomp and show.
moral_zh: 不要为了排场和炫耀而牺牲自由。

title: The Hare and the Tortoise
author: Aesop's Fables
content: A Hare was making fun of the Tortoise one day for being so slow. "Do you ever get anywhere?" he asked with a mocking laugh. "Yes," replied the Tortoise, "and I get there sooner than you think. I'll run you a race and prove it." The Hare was much amused at the idea of running a race with the Tortoise, but for the fun of the thing he agreed. So the Fox, who had consented to act as judge, marked the distance and started the runners off. The Hare was soon far out of sight, and to make the Tortoise feel very deeply how ridiculous it was for him to try a race with a Hare, he lay down beside the course to take a nap until the Tortoise should catch up. The Tortoise meanwhile kept going slowly but steadily, and, after a time, passed the place where the Hare was sleeping. But the Hare slept on very peacefully; and when at last he did wake up, the Tortoise was near the goal. The Hare now ran his swiftest, but he could not overtake the Tortoise in time.
content_zh: 一天，一只野兔嘲笑乌龟太慢。“你到底能不能到达目的地啊？”他嘲笑着问。“能，”乌龟回答，“而且我比你想象的更早到达。我和你赛跑来证明这一点。”野兔觉得和乌龟赛跑这个主意太好笑了，但为了好玩他同意了。于是答应做裁判的狐狸标记了距离，宣布比赛开始。野兔很快就跑得没影了，为了让乌龟深刻体会到和野兔赛跑是多么荒谬，他躺在路边睡起了大觉，打算等乌龟赶上来。与此同时，乌龟缓慢但从不懈怠地爬着，过了一会儿，经过了野兔睡觉的地方。但野兔睡得很香；当他终于醒来时，乌龟已经接近终点了。野兔现在拼命奔跑，但他已经无法及时追上乌龟了。
moral: The race is not always to the swift.
moral_zh: 跑得快不一定赢（坚持就是胜利，骄兵必败）。

title: The Ass Carrying the Image
author: Aesop's Fables
content: A sacred Image was being carried to the temple. It was mounted on an Ass adorned with garlands and gorgeous trappings, and a grand procession of priests and pages followed it through the streets. As the Ass walked along, the people bowed their heads reverently or fell on their knees, and the Ass thought the honor was being paid to himself. With his head full of this foolish idea, he became so puffed up with pride and vanity that he halted and started to bray loudly. But in the midst of his song, his driver guessed what the Ass had got into his head, and began to beat him unmercifully with a stick. "Go along with you, you stupid Ass," he cried. "The honor is not meant for you but for the image you are carrying."
content_zh: 一尊神像正被运往寺庙。它被安放在一头装饰着花环和华丽饰物的驴背上，一队隆重的祭司和侍从跟在后面穿过街道。当驴子走过时，人们虔诚地低头或跪下，驴子以为这是在向他致敬。满脑子这种愚蠢的想法，他变得骄傲自大，停下脚步开始大声嘶叫。但就在他唱歌的时候，赶驴人猜到了驴子在想什么，开始用棍子无情地打他。“快走，你这头蠢驴，”他喊道，“这荣誉不是给你的，是给你背上的神像的。”
moral: Do not try to take the credit to yourself that is due to others.
moral_zh: 不要试图把属于别人的功劳揽到自己身上（不要自作多情）。

title: The Lion and the Gnat
author: Aesop's Fables
content: "Away with you, vile insect!" said a Lion angrily to a Gnat that was buzzing around his head. But the Gnat was not in the least disturbed. "Do you think," he said spitefully to the Lion, "that I am afraid of you because they call you king?" The next instant he flew at the Lion and stung him sharply on the nose. Mad with rage, the Lion struck fiercely at the Gnat, but only succeeded in tearing himself with his claws. Again and again the Gnat stung the Lion, who now was roaring terribly. At last, worn out with rage and covered with wounds that his own teeth and claws had made, the Lion gave up the fight. The Gnat buzzed away to tell the whole world about his victory, but instead he flew straight into a spider's web. And there, he who had defeated the King of beasts came to a miserable end, the prey of a little spider.
content_zh: “滚开，卑鄙的昆虫！”狮子对一只在他头边嗡嗡叫的蚊子愤怒地说。但蚊子一点也没被吓到。“你以为，”他恶毒地对狮子说，“因为他们叫你国王我就怕你吗？”下一瞬间他飞向狮子，狠狠地叮了他的鼻子。狮子气得发疯，猛烈地拍打蚊子，但只把自己的脸抓破了。蚊子一次又一次地叮咬狮子，狮子发出可怕的吼声。最后，狮子精疲力竭，满身都是自己牙齿和爪子造成的伤口，放弃了战斗。蚊子嗡嗡叫着飞走，想告诉全世界他的胜利，但他却径直飞进了一张蜘蛛网。在那里，这个打败了万兽之王的家伙迎来了悲惨的结局，成了一只小蜘蛛的猎物。
moral:
The least of our enemies is often the most to be feared.
Pride over a success should not throw us off our guard.
moral_zh: 最小的敌人往往最可怕。胜利后的骄傲不应让我们放松警惕。

title: The Bear and the Bees
author: Aesop's Fables
content: A Bear roaming the woods in search of berries happened on a fallen tree in which a swarm of Bees had stored their honey. The Bear began to nose around the log very carefully to find out if the Bees were at home. Just then one of the swarm came home from the clover field with a load of sweets. Guessing what the Bear was after, the Bee flew at him, stung him sharply and then disappeared into the hollow log. The Bear lost his temper in an instant, and sprang upon the log tooth and claw, to destroy the nest. But this only brought out the whole swarm. The poor Bear had to take to his heels, and he was able to save himself only by diving into a pool of water.
content_zh: 一只在森林里寻找浆果的熊偶然发现了一棵倒下的树，一群蜜蜂在里面储存了蜂蜜。熊开始非常小心地在圆木周围嗅探，想看看蜜蜂在不在家。就在这时，蜂群中的一只从三叶草田带着花蜜回来了。猜到了熊的目的，蜜蜂飞向他，狠狠地蛰了他一下，然后消失在空心圆木里。熊瞬间发了脾气，用牙齿和爪子扑向圆木，想捣毁蜂巢。但这只引来了整个蜂群。可怜的熊不得不撒腿就跑，只有跳进水塘里才保住了一条命。
moral: It is wiser to bear a single injury in silence than to provoke a thousand by flying into a rage.
moral_zh: 忍受一次伤害比发怒招惹一千次伤害更明智（小不忍则乱大谋）。

title: The Hares and the Frogs
author: Aesop's Fables
content: Hares, as you know, are very timid. The least shadow, sends them scurrying in fright to a hiding place. Once they decided to die rather than live in such misery. But while they were debating how best to meet death, they thought they heard a noise and in a flash were scampering off to the warren. On the way they passed a pond where a family of Frogs was sitting among the reeds on the bank. In an instant the startled Frogs were seeking safety in the mud. "Look," cried a Hare, "things are not so bad after all, for here are creatures who are even afraid of us!"
content_zh: 野兔，你知道，是非常胆小的。一点点阴影就能吓得他们四处逃窜躲藏。有一次他们决定与其活得这么痛苦不如死了算了。但正当他们讨论如何最好地迎接死亡时，他们听到了一点响声，瞬间便逃回了洞穴。在路上，他们经过一个池塘，一群青蛙正坐在岸边的芦苇丛中。受惊的青蛙瞬间钻进泥里寻求安全。“看，”一只野兔叫道，“事情终究没那么糟，因为这里还有连我们要都害怕的生物呢！”
moral: However unfortunate we may think we are there is always someone worse off than ourselves.
moral_zh: 无论我们觉得多么不幸，总有人比我们更惨（比上不足，比下有余）。

title: The Shepherd Boy and the Wolf
author: Aesop's Fables
content: A Shepherd Boy tended his master's Sheep near a dark forest not far from the village. Soon he found life in the pasture very dull. All he could do to amuse himself was to talk to his dog or play on his shepherd's pipe. One day as he sat watching the Sheep and the quiet forest, and thinking what he would do should he see a Wolf, he thought of a plan to amuse himself. His Master had told him to call for help should a Wolf attack the flock, and the Villagers would drive it away. So now, though he had not seen anything that even looked like a Wolf, he ran toward the village shouting at the top of his voice, "Wolf! Wolf!" As he expected, the Villagers who heard the cry dropped their work and ran in great excitement to the pasture. But when they got there they found the Boy doubled up with laughter at the trick he had played on them. A few days later the Shepherd Boy again shouted, "Wolf! Wolf!" Again the Villagers ran to help him, only to be laughed at again. Then one evening as the sun was setting behind the forest and the shadows were creeping out over the pasture, a Wolf really did spring from the underbrush and fall upon the Sheep. In terror the Boy ran toward the village shouting "Wolf! Wolf!" But though the Villagers heard the cry, they did not run to help him as they had before. "He cannot fool us again," they said. The Wolf killed a great many of the Boy's sheep and then slipped away into the forest.
content_zh: 一个牧童在离村子不远的黑森林附近放羊。很快他觉得牧场生活很无聊。他只能和狗说话或吹牧笛来解闷。一天，当他坐着看羊群和安静的森林，想着如果看到狼该怎么办时，他想出了一个找乐子的计划。他的主人告诉他，如果狼攻击羊群就呼救，村民们会来赶走狼。所以现在，虽然他连个狼影也没看见，但他向村子跑去，拼命大喊：“狼来了！狼来了！”正如他所料，听到的村民放下手中的活，激动地跑向牧场。但当他们到达那里时，发现男孩因为自己搞的恶作剧笑得直不起腰。几天后，牧童又喊：“狼来了！狼来了！”村民们又跑来帮他，结果又被嘲笑了一番。然后有一天傍晚，当太阳在森林后落下，阴影笼罩牧场时，一只真狼从灌木丛中跳出来扑向羊群。男孩惊恐地向村子跑去，喊着“狼来了！狼来了！”虽然村民们听到了喊声，但他们没有像以前那样跑来帮他。“他别想再骗我们了，”他们说。狼咬死了男孩的许多羊，然后溜进了森林。
moral: Liars are not believed even when they speak the truth.
moral_zh: 撒谎者即使说真话也没人相信（狼来了的故事）。

title: The Lion, the Bear, and the Fox
author: Aesop's Fables
content: Just as a great Bear rushed to seize a stray kid, a Lion leaped from another direction upon the same prey. The two fought furiously for the prize until they had received so many wounds that both sank down unable to continue the battle. Just then a Fox dashed up, and seizing the kid, made off with it as fast as he could go, while the Lion and the Bear looked on in helpless rage. "How much better it would have been," they said, "to have shared in a friendly spirit."
content_zh: 正当一只巨大的熊冲过去抓住一只迷路的小山羊时，一只狮子从另一个方向扑向同一个猎物。两者为了战利品激烈搏斗，直到双方都受了重伤，倒在地上无法继续战斗。就在这时，一只狐狸冲了上来，抓起小山羊，拼命逃跑，而狮子和熊只能无奈地愤怒看着。“如果我们当初友好地分享，”他们说，“该有多好啊。”
moral: Those who have all the toil do not always get the profit.
moral_zh: 出力者未必得利（鹬蚌相争渔翁得利）。

title: The Dog in the Manger
author: Aesop's Fables
content: A Dog asleep in a manger filled with hay, was awakened by the Cattle, which came in tired and hungry from working in the field. But the Dog would not let them get near the manger, and snarled and snapped as if it were filled with the best of meat and bones, all for himself. The Cattle looked at the Dog in disgust. "How selfish he is!" said one. "He cannot eat the hay and yet he will not let us eat it who are so hungry for it!" Now the farmer came in. When he saw how the Dog was acting, he seized a stick and drove him out of the stable with many a blow for his selfish behavior.
content_zh: 一只狗睡在装满干草的马槽里，被从田里劳作回来又累又饿的牛群吵醒了。但这只狗不让他们靠近马槽，对着他们咆哮撕咬，好像里面装满了最好的肉和骨头，全是他自己的一样。牛群厌恶地看着狗。“他多自私啊！”一头牛说，“他自己不吃干草，却也不让我们这些饿极了的牛吃！”这时农夫进来了。当他看到狗的行为时，抓起一根棍子，狠狠地打了他几下，把他赶出了马厩，惩罚他的自私行为。
moral: Do not grudge others what you cannot enjoy yourself.
moral_zh: 不要嫉妒别人享受你自己无法享受的东西（占着茅坑不拉屎）。

title: The Farmer and the Stork
author: Aesop's Fables
content: A Stork of a very simple and trusting nature had been asked by a gay party of Cranes to visit a field that had been newly planted. But the party ended dismally with all the birds entangled in the meshes of the Farmer's net. The Stork begged the Farmer to spare him. "Please let me go," he pleaded. "I belong to the Stork family who you know are honest and birds of good character. Besides, I did not know the Cranes were going to steal." "You may be a very good bird," answered the Farmer, "but I caught you with the thieving Cranes and you will have to share the same punishment with them."
content_zh: 一只天性单纯轻信的鹳，被一群快乐的鹤邀请去参观一块新种的田地。但这聚会以悲剧收场，所有的鸟都被缠在了农夫的网眼里。鹳恳求农夫放过他。“请放我走，”他哀求道，“我是鹳家族的，你知道我们是诚实且品行良好的鸟。而且，我不知道鹤是去偷东西的。”“你可能是一只很好的鸟，”农夫回答，“但我抓到你和偷窃的鹤在一起，你就必须和他们一起接受同样的惩罚。”
moral: You are judged by the company you keep.
moral_zh: 近朱者赤，近墨者黑（通过交往的朋友来判断一个人）。

title: The Fox and the Crow
author: Aesop's Fables
content: One bright morning as the Fox was following his sharp nose through the wood in search of a bite to eat, he saw a Crow on the limb of a tree overhead. This was by no means the first Crow the Fox had ever seen. What caught his attention this time and made him stop for a second look, was that the lucky Crow held a bit of cheese in her beak. "No need to search any farther," thought sly Master Fox. "Here is a dainty bite for my breakfast." Up he trotted to the foot of the tree in which the Crow was sitting, and looking up admiringly, he cried, "Good-morning, beautiful creature!" The Crow, her head cocked on one side, watched the Fox suspiciously. But she kept her beak tightly closed on the cheese and did not return his greeting. "What a charming creature she is!" said the Fox. "How her feathers shine! What a beautiful form and what splendid wings! Such a wonderful Bird should have a very lovely voice, since everything else about her is so perfect. Could she sing just one song, I know I should hail her Queen of Birds." Listening to these flattering words, the Crow forgot all her suspicion, and also her breakfast. She wanted very much to be called Queen of Birds. So she opened her beak wide to utter her loudest caw, and down fell the cheese straight into the Fox's open mouth. "Thank you," said Master Fox sweetly, as he walked off. "Though it is cracked, you have a voice sure enough. But where are your wits?"
content_zh: 一个明媚的早晨，狐狸顺着他敏锐的鼻子在树林里寻找食物，他看见头顶的树枝上有一只乌鸦。这绝不是狐狸见过的第一只乌鸦。这次引起他注意并让他停下来多看一眼的，是那只幸运的乌鸦嘴里叼着一块奶酪。“不用再找了，”狡猾的狐狸先生想，“这可是我早餐的美味。”他小跑到乌鸦栖息的树下，仰慕地抬头看着，喊道：“早上好，美丽的生物！”乌鸦歪着头，怀疑地看着狐狸。但她紧紧闭着嘴叼着奶酪，没有回应他的问候。“多么迷人的生物啊！”狐狸说，“她的羽毛多么闪亮！多么优美的体态，多么绚丽的翅膀！这样美妙的鸟一定有非常动听的声音，因为她的一切都是如此完美。如果她能唱一首歌，哪怕就一首，我就要尊她为鸟中女王。”听着这些奉承话，乌鸦忘记了所有的怀疑，也忘了她的早餐。她非常想被称为鸟中女王。于是她张大嘴巴发出最响亮的叫声，结果奶酪径直掉进了狐狸张开的嘴里。“谢谢，”狐狸先生一边走开一边甜甜地说，“虽然声音有点破，但你的确有嗓子。可是你的脑子去哪儿了？”
moral: The flatterer lives at the expense of those who will listen to him.
moral_zh: 奉承者靠听信他的人为生（警惕糖衣炮弹）。

title: The Frogs Who Wished for a King
author: Aesop's Fables
content: The Frogs were tired of governing themselves. They had so much freedom that it had spoiled them, and they did nothing but sit around croaking in a bored manner and wishing for a government that could entertain them with the pomp and display of royalty, and rule them in a way to make them know they were being ruled. No milk and water government for them, they declared. So they sent a petition to Jupiter asking for a king. Jupiter saw what simple and foolish creatures they were, but to keep them quiet and make them think they had a king he threw down a huge log, which fell into the water with a great splash. The Frogs hid themselves among the reeds and grasses, thinking the new king to be some fearful giant. But they soon discovered how tame and peaceable King Log was. In a short time the younger Frogs were using him for a diving platform, while the older Frogs made him a meeting place, where they complained loudly to Jupiter about the government. To teach the Frogs a lesson the ruler of the gods now sent a Crane to be king of Frogland. The Crane proved to be a very different sort of king from old King Log. He gobbled up the poor Frogs right and left and they soon saw what fools they had been. In mournful croaks they begged Jupiter to take away the cruel tyrant before they should all be destroyed. "How now!" cried Jupiter "Are you not yet content? You have what you asked for and so you have only yourselves to blame for your misfortunes."
content_zh: 青蛙们厌倦了自治。他们拥有太多的自由，以至于被宠坏了，他们无所事事，只是坐着无聊地呱呱叫，希望有一个能用皇家的排场和威仪娱乐他们，并以一种让他们感到被统治的方式来统治他们的政府。他们不想这政府太温和。于是他们向朱庇特请愿，要求派一个国王。朱庇特看出他们是多么单纯愚蠢的生物，为了让他们安静下来，让他们以为有了国王，他扔下一根巨大的原木，原木溅起巨大的水花落入水中。青蛙们躲在芦苇和草丛中，以为新国王是个可怕的巨人。但他们很快发现圆木国王是多么温顺平和。没过多久，年轻的青蛙把它当作跳水台，年老的青蛙把它当作聚会场所，在那里大声向朱庇特抱怨政府。为了教训青蛙，众神之王现在派了一只鹤来当青蛙国的国王。鹤证明是与老圆木国王截然不同的一类国王。他在左右两边大口吞食可怜的青蛙，他们很快意识到自己是多么愚蠢。他们用悲惨的叫声恳求朱庇特在他们全被消灭之前带走这个残忍的暴君。“怎么！”朱庇特叫道，“你们还不满足吗？你们得到了你们要求的，所以你们的不幸只能怪你们自己。”
moral: Be sure you can better your condition before you seek to change.
moral_zh: 在寻求改变之前，确保你能改善现状（知足常乐）。

title: The Fisherman and the Little Fish
author: Aesop's Fables
content: A poor Fisherman, who lived on the fish he caught, had bad luck one day and caught nothing but a very small fry. The Fisherman was about to put it in his basket when the little Fish said: "Please spare me, Mr. Fisherman! I am so small it is not worth while to carry me home. When I am bigger, I shall make you a much better meal." But the Fisherman quickly put the fish into his basket. "How foolish I should be," he said, "to throw you back. However small you may be, you are better than nothing at all."
content_zh: 一个靠捕鱼为生的穷渔夫，有一天运气很差，只抓到一条很小的鱼苗。渔夫正要把他放进篮子里，小鱼说：“请放过我吧，渔夫先生！我太小了，不值得带回家。等我长大了，我会成为你更好的一顿饭。”但渔夫迅速把鱼放进了篮子。“如果把你扔回去，我就太傻了，”他说，“不管你多小，总比什么都没有强。”
moral: A small gain is worth more than a large promise.
moral_zh: 到手的小利胜过巨大的空头支票（双鸟在林不如一鸟在手）。

title: The Wolf and the Ass
author: Aesop's Fables
content: An Ass was feeding in a pasture near a wood when he saw a Wolf lurking in the shadows along the hedge. He easily guessed what the Wolf had in mind, and thought of a plan to save himself. So he pretended he was lame, and began to hobble painfully. When the Wolf came up, he asked the Ass what had made him lame, and the Ass replied that he had stepped on a sharp thorn. "Please pull it out," he pleaded, groaning as if in pain. "If you do not, it might stick in your throat when you eat me." The Wolf saw the wisdom of the advice, for he wanted to enjoy his meal without any danger of choking. So the Ass lifted up his foot and the Wolf began to search very closely and carefully for the thorn. Just then the Ass kicked out with all his might, tumbling the Wolf a dozen paces away. And while the Wolf was getting very slowly and painfully to his feet, the Ass galloped away in safety. "Serves me right," growled the Wolf as he crept into the bushes. "I'm a butcher by trade, not a doctor."
content_zh: 一头驴在树林附近的牧场吃草，看到一只狼潜伏在树篱的阴影里。他很容易猜到狼在想什么，于是想出了一个自救的计划。他假装瘸了，开始痛苦地一瘸一拐。当狼走近时，问驴怎么瘸了，驴回答说他踩到了尖刺。“请帮我拔出来，”他呻吟着乞求道，“如果你不拔，吃我的时候可能会卡在你喉咙里。”狼觉得这建议很明智，因为他想毫无窒息危险地享受美餐。于是驴抬起脚，狼开始非常仔细地寻找那根刺。就在这时，驴用尽全力踢了一脚，把狼踢出十几步远。当狼缓慢而痛苦地爬起来时，驴已经安全地跑远了。“活该，”狼爬进灌木丛时咆哮道，“我是个屠夫，不是医生。”
moral: Stick to your trade.
moral_zh: 干好你的本行（不要越俎代庖）。

title: The Sick Stag
author: Aesop's Fables
content: A Stag had fallen sick. He had just strength enough to gather some food and find a quiet clearing in the woods, where he lay down to wait until his strength should return. The Animals heard about the Stag's illness and came to ask after his health. Of course, they were all hungry, and helped themselves freely to the Stag's food; and as you would expect, the Stag soon starved to death.
content_zh: 一只公鹿病倒了。他勉强有些力气收集了一些食物，在树林里找了个安静的空地，躺下等待体力恢复。动物们听说公鹿病了，都来问候他的健康。当然，他们都饿了，便随意享用了公鹿的食物；正如你所料，公鹿很快就饿死了。
moral: Good will is worth nothing unless it is accompanied by good acts.
moral_zh: 没有善行的善意一文不值。

title: The Old Lion and the Fox
author: Aesop's Fables
content: An old Lion, whose teeth and claws were so worn that it was not so easy for him to get food as in his younger days, pretended that he was sick. He took care to let all his neighbors know about it, and then lay down in his cave to wait for visitors. And when they came to offer him their sympathy, he ate them up one by one. The Fox came too, but he was very cautious about it. Standing at a safe distance from the cave, he inquired politely after the Lion's health. The Lion replied that he was very ill indeed, and asked the Fox to step in for a moment. But Master Fox very wisely stayed outside, thanking the Lion very kindly for the invitation. "I should be glad to do as you ask," he added, "but I have noticed that there are many footprints leading into your cave and none coming out. Pray tell me, how do your visitors find their way out again?"
content_zh: 一只老狮子，牙齿和爪子都磨损了，不像年轻时那样容易捕食，便假装生病。他故意让所有邻居都知道这件事，然后躺在洞里等待访客。当他们来表示慰问时，他把他们一个接一个地吃掉了。狐狸也来了，但他非常谨慎。他站在离洞口一段安全距离的地方，礼貌地询问狮子的健康。狮子回答说他确实病得很重，请狐狸进去坐一会儿。但狐狸先生非常明智地待在外面，非常客气地感谢狮子的邀请。“我很乐意照您说的做，”他补充道，“但我注意到有许多脚印通向您的洞穴，却没有任何脚印出来。请告诉我，您的访客是怎么出来的呢？”
moral: Take warning from the misfortunes of others.
moral_zh: 以前车之鉴为戒（从别人的不幸中吸取教训）。

title: The Wolf and the Shepherd
author: Aesop's Fables
content: A Wolf, lurking near the Shepherd's hut, saw the Shepherd and his family feasting on a roasted lamb. "Aha!" he muttered. "What a great shouting and running about would there have been, had they caught me at just the very thing they are doing with so much enjoyment!"
content_zh: 一只狼潜伏在牧羊人的小屋附近，看到牧羊人和他的家人正在享用烤全羊。“啊哈！”他低声说，“如果他们抓到我做他们正在如此享受的事，那该会有多大的叫喊和追逐啊！”
moral: Men often condemn others for what they see no wrong in doing themselves.
moral_zh: 人们常因为别人做了自己也在做的事而谴责别人（双重标准）。

title: The Wolf and the Shepherd
author: Aesop's Fables
content: A Wolf had been prowling around a flock of Sheep for a long time, and the Shepherd watched very anxiously to prevent him from carrying off a Lamb. But the Wolf did not try to do any harm. Instead he seemed to be helping the Shepherd take care of the Sheep. At last the Shepherd got so used to seeing the Wolf about that he forgot how wicked he could be. One day he even went so far as to leave his flock in the Wolf's care while he went on an errand. But when he came back and saw how many of the flock had been killed and carried off, he knew how foolish to trust a Wolf.
content_zh: 一只狼在羊群周围徘徊了很长时间，牧羊人非常焦虑地监视着，防止由于他叼走小羊。但狼并没有试图造成任何伤害。相反，他似乎在帮牧羊人照顾羊群。最后，牧羊人习惯了看到狼在周围，忘记了他有多邪恶。有一天，他甚至在去办事时把羊群托付给狼照看。但当他回来看到羊群被杀死了那么多并被叼走时，他才明白信任一只狼是多么愚蠢。
moral: Once a wolf, always a wolf.
moral_zh: 江山易改，本性难移（狼改不了吃肉）。

title: The Dog and the Oyster
author: Aesop's Fables
content: There was once a Dog who was very fond of eggs. He visited the hen house very often and at last got so greedy that he would swallow the eggs whole. One day the Dog wandered down to the seashore. There he spied an Oyster. In a twinkling the Oyster was resting in the Dog's stomach, shell and all. It pained the Dog a good deal, as you can guess. "I've learned that all round things are not eggs," he said groaning.
content_zh: 从前有一只狗非常喜欢吃鸡蛋。他经常去鸡舍，最后变得非常贪婪，竟然把鸡蛋整个吞下去。一天，狗溜达到海边。在那里他发现了一只牡蛎。一眨眼，牡蛎连壳带肉都进了狗的肚子。你可以猜到，这让狗非常痛苦。“我明白了，并非所有圆的东西都是鸡蛋，”他呻吟着说。
moral: Act in haste and repent at leisure—and often in pain.
moral_zh: 欲速则不达，草率行事后悔莫及——往往还伴随着痛苦。

title: The Astrologer
author: Aesop's Fables
content: A man who lived a long time ago believed that he could read the future in the stars. He called himself an Astrologer, and spent his time at night gazing at the sky. One evening he was walking along the open road outside the village. His eyes were fixed on the stars. He thought he saw there that the end of the world was at hand, when all at once, down he went into a hole full of mud and water. There he stood up to his ears, in the muddy water, and madly clawing at the slippery sides of the hole in his effort to climb out. His cries for help soon brought the villagers running. As they pulled him out of the mud, one of them said: "You pretend to read the future in the stars, and yet you fail to see what is at your feet! This may teach you to pay more attention to what is right in front of you, and let the future take care of itself." "What use is it," said another, "to read the stars, when you can't see what's right here on the earth?"
content_zh: 很久以前有一个人相信他能从星星中预知未来。他自称占星家，晚上把时间都花在仰望天空上。一天晚上，他走在村外的公路上，眼睛盯着星星。他以为看到了世界末日即将来临的迹象，这时突然掉进了一个满是泥水的坑里。他站在齐耳深的泥水里，疯狂地抓着滑溜溜的坑壁想爬出来。他的呼救声很快引来了村民。当他们把他从泥里拉出来时，其中一人说：“你假装能从星星中预知未来，却看不见脚下的东西！这应该教训多关注眼前的事，让未来自己照顾自己吧。”“如果你连地球上眼前的东西都看不见，读星星有什么用呢？”另一个人说。
moral: Take care of the little things and the big things will take care of themselves.
moral_zh: 关注脚下（务实），未来自然会好。

title: The Boy and the Nettle
author: Aesop's Fables
content: A Boy, stung by a Nettle, ran home crying, to get his mother to blow on the hurt and kiss it. "Son," said the Boy's mother, when she had comforted him, "the next time you come near a Nettle, grasp it firmly, and it will be as soft as silk."
content_zh: 一个被荨麻刺伤的男孩哭着跑回家，让母亲吹吹伤口并亲吻它。“孩子，”母亲安慰他后说，“下次你靠近荨麻时，紧紧抓住它，它就会像丝绸一样柔软。”
moral: Whatever you do, do with all your might.
moral_zh: 无论做什么，都要全力以赴（面对困难要果断）。

title: The Cock and the Fox
author: Aesop's Fables
content: A Fox was caught in a trap one fine morning, because he had got too near the Farmer's hen house. No doubt he was hungry, but that was not an excuse for stealing. A Cock, rising early, discovered what had happened. He knew the Fox could not get at him, so he went a little closer to get a good look at his enemy. The Fox saw a slender chance of escape. "Dear friend," he said, "I was just on my way to visit a sick relative, when I stumbled into this string and got all tangled up. But please do not tell anybody about it. I dislike causing sorrow to anybody, and I am sure I can soon gnaw this string to pieces." But the Cock was not to be so easily fooled. He soon roused the whole hen yard, and when the Farmer came running out, that was the end of Mr. Fox.
content_zh: 一个美好的早晨，一只狐狸被捕兽夹抓住了，因为他靠农夫的鸡舍太近了。毫无疑问他饿了，但这并不是偷窃的借口。一只早起的公鸡发现了这一幕。他知道狐狸抓不到他，所以走近了一点想好好看看他的敌人。狐狸看到了一线逃生的机会。“亲爱的朋友，”他说，“我正要去看望一位生病的亲戚，结果绊到了这根绳子被缠住了。但请千万别告诉任何人。我不喜欢给任何人带来悲伤，而且我确信我很快就能把这根绳子咬断。”但公鸡没那么好骗。他很快叫醒了整个鸡舍，当农夫跑出来时，那就是狐狸先生的末日了。
moral: The wicked deserve no aid.
moral_zh: 恶人不值得帮助。

title: The Cat and the Birds
author: Aesop's Fables
content: A Cat was growing very thin. As you have guessed, he did not get enough to eat. One day he heard that some Birds in the neighborhood were ailing and needed a doctor. So he put on a pair of spectacles, and with a leather box in his hand, knocked at the door of the Bird's home. The Birds peeped out, and Dr. Cat, with much solicitude, asked how they were. He would be very happy to give them some medicine. "Tweet, tweet," laughed the Birds. "Very smart, aren't you? We are very well, thank you, and more so, if you only keep away from here."
content_zh: 一只猫变得很瘦。如你所猜，他吃不饱。一天他听说附近的鸟病了，需要医生。于是他戴上一副眼镜，手里拿着皮箱，敲了敲鸟巢的门。鸟儿们探出头来，猫医生非常关切地问他们怎么样。他说很乐意给他们一些药。“叽叽喳喳，”鸟儿们笑道，“挺聪明的嘛，是不是？我们很好，谢谢，如果你能离这儿远点，我们会更好。”
moral: Be wise and shun the quack.
moral_zh: 聪明点，远离江湖骗子。

title: The Serpent and the Eagle
author: Aesop's Fables
content: A Serpent had succeeded in surprising an Eagle and had wrapped himself around the Eagle's neck. The Eagle could not reach the Serpent, neither with beak nor claws. Far into the sky he soared trying to shake off his enemy. But the Serpent's hold only tightened, and slowly the Eagle sank back to earth, gasping for breath. A Countryman chanced to see the unequal combat. In pity for the noble Eagle he rushed up and soon had loosened the coiling Serpent and freed the Eagle. The Serpent was furious. He had no chance to bite the watchful Countryman. Instead he struck at the drinking horn, hanging at the Countryman's belt, and into it let fly the poison of his fangs. The Countryman now went on toward home. Becoming thirsty on the way, he filled his horn at a spring, and was about to drink. There was a sudden rush of great wings. Sweeping down, the Eagle seized the poisoned horn from out his savior's hands, and flew away with it to hide it where it could never be found.
content_zh: 一条蛇成功偷袭了一只鹰，缠住了鹰的脖子。鹰的喙和爪子都够不着蛇。他飞向高空试图甩掉敌人。但蛇缠得更紧了，鹰慢慢地落回地面，喘着粗气。一个农夫偶然看到了这场不平等的战斗。出于对高贵的鹰的怜悯，他冲上去解开了缠绕的蛇，放走了鹰。蛇非常愤怒。他没机会咬到警惕的农夫。相反，他攻击了挂在农夫腰带上的饮水号角，把毒液射了进去。农夫继续往家走。路上渴了，他在泉边装满了号角，正要喝。突然一阵巨大的翅膀声传来。鹰俯冲下来，从救命恩人手中抢走有毒的号角，把它带走藏在了永远找不到的地方。
moral: An act of kindness is well repaid.
moral_zh: 善有善报。

title: The Rose and the Butterfly
author: Aesop's Fables
content: A Butterfly once fell in love with a beautiful Rose. The Rose was not indifferent, for the Butterfly's wings were powdered in a charming pattern of gold and silver. And so, when he fluttered near and told how he loved her, she blushed rosily and said yes. After much pretty love-making and many whispered vows of constancy, the Butterfly took a tender leave of his sweetheart. But alas! It was a long time before he came back to her. "Is this your constancy?" she exclaimed tearfully. "It is ages since you went away, and all the time, you have been carrying on with all sorts of flowers. I saw you kiss Miss Geranium, and you fluttered around Miss Mignonette until Honey Bee chased you away. I wish he had stung you!" "Constancy!" laughed the Butterfly. "I had no sooner left you than I saw Zephyr kissing you. You carried on scandalously with Mr. Bumble Bee and you made eyes at every single Bug you could see. You can't expect any constancy from me!"
content_zh: 一只蝴蝶爱上了一朵美丽的玫瑰。玫瑰也并非无动于衷，因为蝴蝶的翅膀上撒着金银相间的迷人粉末。所以，当他飞近倾诉爱意时，她羞红了脸答应了。经过一番甜蜜的恋爱和许多关于忠贞的誓言后，蝴蝶依依不舍地告别了爱人。但唉！过了好久他才回来。“这就是你的忠贞吗？”她含泪惊呼，“你走了好久，一直都在和各种花朵调情。我看到你亲吻天竺葵小姐，你围着木樨草小姐转，直到蜜蜂把你赶走。我真希望他蛰了你！”“忠贞！”蝴蝶笑道，“我刚离开你，就看到西风在亲吻你。你和大黄蜂先生丑闻不断，还对每一个你看到的虫子抛媚眼。你别指望我对你忠贞！”
moral: Do not expect constancy in others if you have none yourself.
moral_zh: 如果你自己不忠贞，就别指望别人忠贞。

title: The Bees and Wasps, and the Hornet
author: Aesop's Fables
content: A store of honey had been found in a hollow tree, and the Wasps declared positively that it belonged to them. The Bees were just as sure that the treasure was theirs. The argument grew very pointed, and it looked as if the affair could not be settled without a battle, when at last, with much good sense, they agreed to let a judge decide the matter. So they brought the case before the Hornet, justice of the peace in that part of the woods. When the Judge called the case, witnesses declared that they had seen certain winged creatures in the neighborhood of the hollow tree, who hummed loudly, and whose bodies were striped, yellow and black, like Bees. Counsel for the Wasps immediately insisted that this description fitted his clients exactly. Such evidence did not help Judge Hornet to any decision, so he adjourned court for six weeks to give him time to think it over. When the case came up again, both sides had a large number of witnesses. An Ant was first to take the stand, and was about to be cross-examined, when a wise old Bee addressed the Court. "Your honor," he said, "the case has now been pending for six weeks. If it is not decided soon, the honey will not be fit for anything. I move that the Bees and the Wasps be both instructed to build a honey comb. Then we shall soon see to whom the honey really belongs." The Wasps protested loudly. Wise Judge Hornet quickly understood why they did so: They knew they could not build a honey comb and fill it with honey. "It is clear," said the Judge, "who made the comb and who could not have made it. The honey belongs to the Bees."
content_zh: 在一棵空心树里发现了一堆蜂蜜，黄蜂断言那是属于他们的。蜜蜂同样确信这宝藏是他们的。争论变得非常尖锐，眼看不用武力解决不了了，最后他们理智地同意让法官来裁决。于是他们把案子提交给了大黄蜂，也就是那片树林的治安法官。当法官审理案件时，目击者称他们看到空心树附近有一些有翅膀的生物，嗡嗡叫得很响，身体有黄黑条纹，像蜜蜂。黄蜂的律师立即坚持说这描述完全符合他的委托人。这样的证据对大黄蜂法官做决定没有帮助，于是他休庭六周让他思考。当案子再次开庭时，双方都有大量证人。一只蚂蚁刚要上台接受质询，一只聪明的老蜜蜂向法庭发言。“法官大人，”他说，“此案已经搁置六周了。如果不尽快决定，蜂蜜就要坏了。我提议让蜜蜂和黄蜂都去筑一个蜂巢。这样我们很快就能看出蜂蜜到底属于谁。”黄蜂大声抗议。聪明的大黄蜂法官很快明白他们为什么这么做：他们知道自己不会筑巢酿蜜。“很清楚，”法官说，“谁造了巢，谁造不出。蜂蜜属于蜜蜂。”
moral: Ability proves itself by deeds.
moral_zh: 能力用事实证明（事实胜于雄辩）。

title: The Mule
author: Aesop's Fables
content: A Mule had had a long rest and much good feeding. He was feeling very vigorous indeed, and pranced around loftily, holding his head high. "My father certainly was a full-blooded racer," he said. "I can feel that distinctly." Next day he was put into harness again and that evening he was very downhearted indeed. "I was mistaken," he said. "My father was an Ass after all."
content_zh: 一头骡子休息了很久，吃得很好。他感觉精力充沛，高昂着头傲慢地走来走去。“我父亲肯定是一匹纯种赛马，”他说，“我能清楚地感觉到。”第二天他又被套上挽具干活，那天晚上他非常沮丧。“我搞错了，”他说，“我父亲毕竟是一头驴。”
moral: Be sure of your pedigree before you boast of it.
moral_zh: 在吹嘘血统之前先搞清楚（不要数典忘祖，也不要乱攀高枝）。

title: The Man and the Lion
author: Aesop's Fables
content: A Lion and a Man chanced to travel in company through the forest. They soon began to quarrel, for each of them boasted that he and his kind were far superior to the other both in strength and mind. Now they reached a clearing in the forest and there stood a statue. It was a representation of Heracles in the act of tearing the jaws of the Nemean Lion. "See," said the man, "that's how strong we are! The King of Beasts is like wax in our hands!" "Ho!" laughed the Lion, "a Man made that statue. It would have been quite a different scene had a Lion made it!"
content_zh: 一只狮子和一个人偶然结伴穿越森林。他们很快开始争吵，因为每个人都吹嘘自己和同类在力量和智慧上都远胜对方。这时他们来到森林的一块空地，那里立着一尊雕像。表现的是海格力斯正在撕开尼米亚狮子的嘴。“看，”人说，“我们多强大！百兽之王在我们手中就像蜡一样！”“哈！”狮子笑道，“那是人造的雕像。如果是狮子造的，场景会完全不同！”
moral: It all depends on the point of view, and who tells the story.
moral_zh: 这完全取决于观点，以及谁在讲故事（历史由胜利者书写）。

title: The Ass and the Lap Dog
author: Aesop's Fables
content: There was once an Ass whose Master also owned a Lap Dog. This Dog was a favorite and received many a pat and kind word from his Master, as well as choice bits from his plate. Every day the Dog would run to meet the Master, frisking playfully about and leaping up to lick his hands and face. All this the Ass saw with much discontent. Though he was well fed, he had much work to do; besides, the Master hardly ever took any notice of him. Now the jealous Ass got it into his silly head that all he had to do to win his Master's favor was to act like the Dog. So one day he left his stable and clattered eagerly into the house. Finding his Master seated at the dinner table, he kicked up his heels and, with a loud bray, pranced giddily around the table, upsetting it as he did so. Then he planted his forefeet on his Master's knees and rolled out his tongue to lick the Master's face, as he had seen the Dog do. But his weight upset the chair, and Ass and man rolled over together in the pile of broken dishes from the table. The Master was much alarmed at the strange behavior of the Ass, and calling for help, soon attracted the attention of the servants. When they saw the danger the Master was in from the clumsy beast, they set upon the Ass and drove him with kicks and blows back to the stable. There they left him to mourn the foolishness that had brought him nothing but a sound beating.
content_zh: 从前有一头驴，他的主人还养了一只哈巴狗。这只狗是宠儿，经常得到主人的抚摸和好话，还有盘子里的精选美食。每天狗都会跑去迎接主人，顽皮地跳来跳去，跳起来舔他的手和脸。驴子看到这一切非常不满。虽然他吃得很好，但他有很多活要干；而且，主人几乎不注意他。这头嫉妒的驴子愚蠢地以为，只要像狗一样表现就能赢得主人的欢心。于是有一天他离开马厩，急切地跑进屋子。发现主人正坐在餐桌旁，他踢起后跟，大声嘶叫，晕头转向地绕着桌子跑，把桌子都弄翻了。然后他把前蹄搭在主人的膝盖上，伸出舌头去舔主人的脸，就像他看到狗做的那样。但他的体重弄翻了椅子，驴和人一起滚倒在桌子打碎的盘子堆里。主人对驴的奇怪行为感到非常惊恐，大声呼救，很快引来了仆人。当他们看到主人受到这头笨拙野兽的威胁时，便冲上去对驴子拳打脚踢，把他赶回了马厩。把他留在那儿为这招致一顿毒打的愚蠢行为而哀叹。
moral: Behavior that is regarded as agreeable in one is very rude and impertinent in another.
moral_zh: 同样的某种行为，在一方被视为讨人喜欢，在另一方却被视为粗鲁无礼（不要盲目模仿）。

title: The Fox and the Crab
author: Aesop's Fables
content: A Crab one day grew disgusted with the sands in which he lived. He decided to take a stroll to the meadow not far inland. There he would find better fare than briny water and sand mites. So off he crawled to the meadow. But there a hungry Fox spied him, and in a twinkling, ate him up, both shell and claw.
content_zh: 一天，一只螃蟹对他居住的沙地感到厌恶。他决定去内陆不远的草地散步。那里会有比咸水和沙蚤更好的食物。于是他爬向草地。但在那里，一只饿狐狸发现了他，一眨眼，连壳带爪把他吃掉了。
moral: Be content with your lot.
moral_zh: 安分守己（知足常乐）。

title: The Flies and the Honey
author: Aesop's Fables
content: A jar of honey was upset and the sticky sweetness flowed out on the table. The sweet smell of the honey soon brought a large number of Flies buzzing around. They did not wait for an invitation. No, indeed; they settled right down, feet and all, to gorge themselves. The Flies were quickly smeared from head to foot with honey. Their wings stuck together. They could not pull their feet out of the sticky mass. And so they died, giving their lives for the sake of a taste of sweetness.
content_zh: 一罐蜂蜜打翻了，粘稠的甜液流到了桌子上。蜂蜜的甜味很快引来了一大群苍蝇嗡嗡叫。他们没等邀请。不，事实上；他们直接落下来，连脚带身子，准备大吃一顿。苍蝇很快从头到脚都沾满了蜂蜜。翅膀粘在了一起。脚也拔不出来了。于是他们死了，为了尝一口甜头送了命。
moral: Be not greedy for a little passing pleasure. It may destroy you.
moral_zh: 不要贪图短暂的快乐，那可能会毁灭你（人为财死，鸟为食亡）。

title: The Stag, the Sheep, and the Wolf
author: Aesop's Fables
content: One day a Stag came to a Sheep and asked her to lend him a measure of wheat. The Sheep knew him for a very swift runner, who could easily take himself out of reach, were he so inclined. So she asked him if he knew someone who would answer for him. "Yes, yes," answered the Stag confidently, "the Wolf has promised to be my surety." "The Wolf!" exclaimed the Sheep indignantly. "Do you think I would trust you on such security? I know the Wolf! He takes what he wants and runs off with it without paying. As for you, you can use your legs so well that I should have little chance of collecting the debt if I had to catch you for it!"
content_zh: 一天，一只公鹿来找绵羊，想借一斗小麦。绵羊知道他跑得很快，如果不想还，很容易就能跑得没影。所以她问他有没有人愿意为他担保。“有，有，”公鹿自信地回答，“狼答应做我的担保人。”“狼！”绵羊愤怒地惊呼，“你以为有了这样的担保我就会借给你吗？我了解狼！他想拿什么拿什么，拿了就跑根本不付钱。至于你，如果你跑了，我想追债根本追不上！”
moral: Two blacks do not make a white.
moral_zh: 两个坏人加在一起变不成好人（狼狈为奸）。

title: The Lion, the Ass, and the Fox
author: Aesop's Fables
content: A Lion, an Ass, and a Fox were hunting in company, and caught a large quantity of game. The Ass was asked to divide the spoil. This he did very fairly, giving each an equal share. The Fox was well satisfied, but the Lion flew into a great rage over it, and with one stroke of his huge paw, he added the Ass to the pile of slain. Then he turned to the Fox. "You divide it," he roared angrily. The Fox wasted no time in talking. He quickly piled all the game into one great heap. From this he took a very small portion for himself, such undesirable bits as the horns and hoofs of a mountain goat, and the end of an ox tail. The Lion now recovered his good humor entirely. "Who taught you to divide so fairly?" he asked pleasantly. "I learned a lesson from the Ass," replied the Fox, carefully edging away.
content_zh: 一只狮子、一头驴和一只狐狸结伴打猎，抓到了大量猎物。驴被要求分配战利品。他分得很公平，每份一样多。狐狸很满意，但狮子勃然大怒，挥起巨大的爪子，把驴也拍死在了猎物堆里。然后他转向狐狸。“你来分，”他愤怒地咆哮道。狐狸没废话。他迅速把所有猎物堆成一大堆。只给自己留了一小部分，比如山羊的角和蹄子，还有牛尾巴尖。狮子完全恢复了心情。“谁教你分得这么公平的？”他愉快地问。“我从驴那儿学到了一课，”狐狸回答，小心翼翼地溜走了。
moral: Learn from the misfortunes of others.
moral_zh: 从别人的不幸中吸取教训。

title: The Mole and his Mother
author: Aesop's Fables
content: A little Mole once said to his Mother: "Why, Mother, you said I was blind! But I am sure I can see!" Mother Mole saw she would have to get such conceit out of his head. So she put a bit of frankincense before him and asked him to tell what it was. The little Mole peered at it. "Why, that's a pebble!" "Well, my son, that proves you've lost your sense of smell as well as being blind."
content_zh: 一只小鼹鼠曾对妈妈说：“哎呀，妈妈，你说我是瞎子！但我肯定我能看见！”鼹鼠妈妈觉得必须打消他的自负。于是她在面前放了一点乳香，让他说是什么。小鼹鼠盯着看。“哎呀，那是一块鹅卵石！”“好吧，孩子，这证明你不仅瞎了，连嗅觉也丢了。”
moral: Boast of one thing and you will be found lacking in that and a few other things as well.
moral_zh: 吹嘘一件事，结果往往暴露你在那件事和其他事上的无能（欲盖弥彰）。

title: The North Wind and the Sun
author: Aesop's Fables
content: The North Wind and the Sun had a quarrel about which of them was the stronger. While they were disputing with much heat and bluster, a Traveler passed along the road wrapped in a cloak. "Let us agree," said the Sun, "that he is the stronger who can strip that Traveler of his cloak." "Very well," growled the North Wind, and at once sent a cold, howling blast against the Traveler. With the first gust of wind the ends of the cloak whipped about the Traveler's body. But he immediately wrapped it closely around him, and the harder the Wind blew, the tighter he held it to him. The North Wind tore angrily at the cloak, but all his efforts were in vain. Then the Sun began to shine. At first his beams were gentle, and in the pleasant warmth after the bitter cold of the North Wind, the Traveler unfastened his cloak and let it hang loosely from his shoulders. The Sun's rays grew warmer and warmer. The man took off his cap and mopped his brow. At last he became so heated that he pulled off his cloak, and, to escape the blazing sunshine, threw himself down in the welcome shade of a tree by the roadside.
content_zh: 北风和太阳争论谁更强。当他们激烈争吵时，一个旅行者裹着斗篷走在路上。“我们约定，”太阳说，“谁能让那个旅行者脱掉斗篷，谁就更强。”“好吧，”北风咆哮道，立刻向旅行者发出寒冷刺骨的狂风。第一阵风吹得斗篷在旅行者身上乱舞。但他立刻把斗篷紧紧裹在身上，风刮得越猛，他裹得越紧。北风愤怒地撕扯着斗篷，但一切努力都无济于事。然后太阳开始照耀。起初他的光芒很温和，在经历北风的严寒后，这种舒适的温暖让旅行者解开了斗篷，松松地搭在肩上。太阳的光芒越来越热。那人脱下帽子擦了擦汗。最后他热得受不了，脱掉了斗篷，为了躲避烈日，躺在了路边树荫下。
moral: Gentleness and kind persuasion win where force and bluster fail.
moral_zh: 温柔的劝导胜过暴力的威逼（以柔克刚）。

title: The Goose and the Golden Egg
author: Aesop's Fables
content: There was once a Countryman who possessed the most wonderful Goose you can imagine, for every day when he visited the nest, the Goose had laid a beautiful, glittering, golden egg. The Countryman took the eggs to market and soon began to get rich. But it was not long before he grew impatient with the Goose because she gave him only a single golden egg a day. He was not getting rich fast enough. Then one day, after he had finished counting his money, the idea came to him that he could get all the golden eggs at once by killing the Goose and cutting it open. But when the deed was done, not a single golden egg did he find, and his precious Goose was dead.
content_zh: 从前有个农夫拥有一只你能想象到的最神奇的鹅，因为每天当他去巢里看时，鹅都下了一个美丽闪亮的金蛋。农夫把蛋拿到市场去卖，很快就富有了。但没过多久，他对鹅失去了耐心，因为她每天只下一个金蛋。他觉得富得不够快。一天，数完钱后，他冒出一个念头：杀了鹅把肚子剖开就能一次得到所有金蛋。但当他这么做后，连一个金蛋也没找到，而他珍贵的鹅已经死了。
moral: Those who have plenty want more and so lose all they have.
moral_zh: 贪得无厌者终将失去所有（杀鸡取卵）。

title: Mercury and the Woodman
author: Aesop's Fables
content: A poor Woodman was cutting down a tree near the edge of a deep pool in the forest. It was late in the day and the Woodman was tired. He had been working since sunrise and his strokes were not so sure as they had been early that morning. Thus it happened that the axe slipped and flew out of his hands into the pool. The Woodman was in despair. The axe was all he possessed with which to make a living, and he had not money enough to buy a new one. As he stood wringing his hands and weeping, the god Mercury suddenly appeared and asked what the trouble was. The Woodman told what had happened, and straightway the kind Mercury dived into the pool. When he came up again he held a wonderful golden axe. "Is this your axe?" Mercury asked the Woodman. "No," answered the honest Woodman, "that is not my axe." Mercury laid the golden axe on the bank and sprang back into the pool. This time he brought up an axe of silver, but the Woodman declared again that his axe was just an ordinary one with a wooden handle. Mercury dived down for the third time, and when he came up again he had the very axe that had been lost. The poor Woodman was very glad that his axe had been found and could not thank the kind god enough. Mercury was greatly pleased with the Woodman's honesty. "I admire your honesty," he said, "and as a reward you may have all three axes, the gold and the silver as well as your own." The happy Woodman returned to his home with his treasures, and soon the story of his good fortune was known to everybody in the village. Now there were several Woodmen in the village who believed that they could easily win the same good fortune. They hurried out into the woods, one here, one there, and hiding their axes in the bushes, pretended they had lost them. Then they wept and wailed and called on Mercury to help them. And indeed, Mercury did appear, first to this one, then to that. To each one he showed an axe of gold, and each one eagerly claimed it to be the one he had lost. But Mercury did not give them the golden axe. Oh no! Instead he gave them each a hard whack over the head with it and sent them home. And when they returned next day to look for their own axes, they were nowhere to be found.
content_zh: 一个穷樵夫正在森林深潭边砍树。天色已晚，樵夫累了。他从日出就开始工作，挥斧的动作不像早上那么稳了。就这样，斧头滑手飞进了水潭。樵夫绝望了。斧头是他维持生计的唯一工具，他又没钱买新的。正当他搓着手哭泣时，赫尔墨斯神突然出现，问他怎么了。樵夫如实相告，善良的赫尔墨斯立刻潜入水中。当他再上来时，手里拿着一把奇妙的金斧头。“这是你的斧头吗？”赫尔墨斯问樵夫。“不，”诚实的樵夫回答，“那不是我的斧头。”赫尔墨斯把金斧头放在岸上，又跳进水里。这次他拿上来一把银斧头，但樵夫再次声明他的斧头只是普通的木柄斧。赫尔墨斯第三次潜下去，上来时手里拿着那把丢失的斧头。可怜的樵夫很高兴斧头找到了，感激不尽。赫尔墨斯对樵夫的诚实非常满意。“我钦佩你的诚实，”他说，“作为奖励，你可以拥有这三把斧头，金的、银的还有你自己的。”快乐的樵夫带着财宝回家了，很快他的好运故事传遍了全村。村里有几个樵夫觉得自己也能轻易获得同样的好运。他们跑到树林里，这儿一个那儿一个，把斧头藏在灌木丛里，假装丢了。然后他们哭天抢地呼唤赫尔墨斯帮忙。赫尔墨斯确实出现了，对每个人都展示了一把金斧头，每个人都急切地声称那是自己丢的。但赫尔墨斯没有给他们金斧头。不！相反，他用斧头狠狠敲了他们的脑袋，把他们赶回了家。第二天当他们回去找自己的斧头时，发现斧头都不见了。
moral: Honesty is the best policy.
moral_zh: 诚实是上策。

title: The Farmer and the Cranes
author: Aesop's Fables
content: Some Cranes saw a farmer plowing a large field. When the work of plowing was done, they patiently watched him sow the seed. It was their feast, they thought. So, as soon as the Farmer had finished planting and had gone home, down they flew to the field, and began to eat as fast as they could. The Farmer, of course, knew the Cranes and their ways. He had had experience with such birds before. He soon returned to the field with a sling. But he did not bring any stones with him. He expected to scare the Cranes just by swinging the sling in the air, and shouting loudly at them. At first the Cranes flew away in great terror. But they soon began to see that none of them ever got hurt. They did not even hear the noise of stones whizzing through the air, and as for words, they would kill nobody. At last they paid no attention whatever to the Farmer. The Farmer saw that he would have to take other measures. He wanted to save at least some of his grain. So he loaded his sling with stones and killed several of the Cranes. This had the effect the Farmer wanted, for from that day the Cranes visited his field no more.
content_zh: 几只鹤看到农夫在耕一块大田。耕完地后，他们耐心地看着他播种。他们想，这是一顿大餐。所以，农夫刚播种完回家，他们就飞到田里，拼命地吃。农夫当然了解鹤和他们的习性。他以前有过对付这种鸟的经验。他很快带着弹弓回到田里。但他没带石头。他打算只是在空中挥舞弹弓，大声叫喊来吓跑鹤。起初鹤惊恐地飞走了。但他们很快发现自己毫发无伤。他们甚至没听到石头划过空气的声音，至于言语，杀不死人。最后他们完全不理会农夫了。农夫意识到必须采取其他措施。他想至少挽救一些谷物。于是他装上石头，打死了几只鹤。这达到了农夫想要的效果，从那天起，鹤再也没来过他的田里。
moral: Bluff and threatening words are of little value with rascals.
moral_zh: 对于无赖，虚张声势和威胁的话没什么用（必须动真格的）。

title: The Cat and the Fox
author: Aesop's Fables
content: Once a Cat and a Fox were traveling together. As they went along, picking up provisions on the way—a stray mouse here, a fat chicken there—they began an argument to while away the time between bites. And, as usually happens when comrades argue, the talk began to get personal. "You think you are extremely clever, don't you?" said the Fox. "Do you pretend to know more than I? Why, I know a whole sackful of tricks!" "Well," retorted the Cat, "I admit I know one trick only, but that one, let me tell you, is worth a thousand of yours!" Just then, close by, they heard a hunter's horn and the yelping of a pack of hounds. In an instant the Cat was up a tree, hiding among the leaves. "This is my trick," he called to the Fox. "Now let me see what yours are worth." But the Fox had so many plans for escape he could not decide which one to try first. He dodged here and there with the hounds at his heels. He doubled on his tracks, he ran at top speed, he entered a dozen burrows,—but all in vain. The hounds caught him, and soon put an end to the boaster and all his tricks.
content_zh: 有一次，一只猫和一只狐狸结伴旅行。他们一边走，一边在路上找吃的——这儿抓只迷路的老鼠，那儿抓只肥鸡——一边争论以打发吃东西之间的空闲时间。就像通常同伴争论时那样，话题开始针对个人。“你觉得你极其聪明，是吗？”狐狸说，“你假装比我知道得更多？哎呀，我知道整整一麻袋的计谋！”“好吧，”猫反驳道，“我承认我只知道一招，但那一招，我告诉你，抵得上你的一千招！”就在这时，附近传来了猎人的号角声和一群猎狗的叫声。猫瞬间爬上了树，躲在树叶里。“这就是我的计谋，”他对狐狸喊道，“现在让我看看你的计谋值多少钱。”但狐狸有太多的逃跑计划，没法决定先试哪一个。他在猎狗的追逐下东躲西藏。他折返跑，全速跑，钻进十几个洞穴，——但都无济于事。猎狗抓住了他，很快终结了这个吹牛大王和他所有的计谋。
moral: Common sense is always worth more than cunning.
moral_zh: 一招鲜，吃遍天（实用的常识胜过花哨的计谋）。

title: The Mouse and the Weasel
author: Aesop's Fables
content: A little hungry Mouse found his way one day into a basket of corn. He had to squeeze himself a good deal to get through the narrow opening between the strips of the basket. But the corn was tempting and the Mouse was determined to get in. When at last he had succeeded, he gorged himself to bursting. Indeed he he became about three times as big around the middle as he was when he went in. At last he felt satisfied and dragged himself to the opening to get out again. But the best he could do was to get his head out. So there he sat groaning and moaning, both from the discomfort inside him and his anxiety to escape from the basket. Just then a Weasel came by. He understood the situation quickly. "My friend," he said, "I know what you've been doing. You've been stuffing. That's what you get. You will have to stay there till you feel just like you did when you went in. Good night, and good enough for you." And that was all the sympathy the poor Mouse got.
content_zh: 一天，一只饥饿的小老鼠发现了一个装玉米的篮子。他不得不费力挤过篮子条之间狭窄的缝隙。但玉米很诱人，老鼠决心进去。当他终于成功后，他吃得肚子都要撑破了。实际上，他的腰围变得大概是进去时的三倍。最后他感到满足了，拖着身子想从缝隙出去。但他最多只能把头伸出去。于是他坐在那里呻吟哀叹，既因为肚子里的不适，也因为急于逃出篮子。这时一只鼬鼠路过。他很快明白了情况。“朋友，”他说，“我知道你干了什么。你暴饮暴食。这就是你的报应。你得待在那儿直到你变回进去时的样子。晚安，你活该。”这就是可怜的老鼠得到的全部同情。
moral: Greediness leads to misfortune.
moral_zh: 贪婪导致不幸（贪心不足蛇吞象）。

title: The Fox Without a Tail
author: Aesop's Fables
content: A Fox that had been caught in a trap, succeeded at last, after much painful tugging, in getting away. But he had to leave his beautiful bushy tail behind him. For a long time he kept away from the other Foxes, for he knew well enough that they would all make fun of him and crack jokes and laugh behind his back. But it was hard for him to live alone, and at last he thought of a plan that would perhaps help him out of his trouble. He called a meeting of all the Foxes, saying that he had something of great importance to tell the tribe. When they were all gathered together, the Fox Without a Tail got up and made a long speech about those Foxes who had come to harm because of their tails. This one had been caught by hounds when his tail had become entangled in the hedge. That one had not been able to run fast enough because of the weight of his brush. Besides, it was well known, he said, that men hunt Foxes simply for their tails, which they cut off as prizes of the hunt. With such proof of the danger and uselessness of having a tail, said Master Fox, he would advise every Fox to cut it off, if he valued life and safety. When he had finished talking, an old Fox arose, and said, smiling: "Master Fox, kindly turn around for a moment, and you shall have your answer." When the poor Fox Without a Tail turned around, there arose such a storm of jeers and hooting, that he saw how useless it was to try any longer to persuade the Foxes to part with their tails.
content_zh: 一只被捕兽夹夹住的狐狸，在经过痛苦的挣扎后终于逃脱了。但他不得不把他美丽蓬松的尾巴留在了后面。很长一段时间他都躲着其他狐狸，因为他很清楚他们都会取笑他，在他背后讲笑话嘲笑他。但独自生活很难，最后他想出了一个也许能帮他摆脱困境的计划。他召集了所有狐狸开会，说有非常重要的事情要告诉大家。当大家聚齐后，断尾狐狸站起来，发表了一篇长篇大论，讲述那些因为尾巴而受害的狐狸的故事。这只因为尾巴缠在树篱里被猎狗抓住了。那只因为尾巴的重量跑得不够快。而且，他说，众所周知，人类猎杀狐狸仅仅是为了他们的尾巴，把尾巴割下来当战利品。既然有这么多证据证明拥有尾巴的危险和无用，狐狸先生说，如果有谁珍视生命和安全，他建议每只狐狸都切掉尾巴。当他说完后，一只老狐狸站起来，微笑着说：“狐狸先生，请转过身去一下，你就会得到答案。”当那只可怜的断尾狐狸转过身时，爆发出一阵嘲笑和起哄声，他意识到试图说服狐狸们割掉尾巴是多么没用。
moral: Do not listen to the advice of him who seeks to lower you to his own level.
moral_zh: 不要听信那些试图把你拉低到他们水平的人的建议。

title: The Lark and Her Young Ones
author: Aesop's Fables
content: A Lark made her nest in a field of young wheat. As the days passed, the wheat stalks grew tall and the young birds, too, grew in strength. Then one day, when the ripe golden grain waved in the breeze, the Farmer and his son came into the field. "This wheat is now ready for reaping," said the Farmer. "We must call in our neighbors and friends to help us harvest it." The young Larks in their nest close by were much frightened, for they knew they would be in great danger if they did not leave the nest before the reapers came. When the Mother Lark returned with food for them, they told her what they had heard. "Do not be frightened, children," said the Mother Lark. "If the Farmer said he would call in his neighbors and friends to help him do his work, this -wheat will not be reaped for a while yet." A few days later, the wheat was so ripe, that when the wind shook the stalks, a hail of wheat grains came rustling down on the young Larks' heads. "If this wheat is not harvested at once," said the Farmer, "we shall lose half the crop. We cannot wait any longer for help from our friends. Tomorrow we must set to work, ourselves." When the young Larks told their mother what they had heard that day, she said: "Then we must be off at once. When a man decides to do his own work and not depend on any one else, then you may be sure there will be no more delay." There was much fluttering and trying out of wings that afternoon, and at sunrise next day, when the Farmer and his son cut down the grain, they found an empty nest.
content_zh: 一只百灵鸟在一块麦田里筑了巢。日子一天天过去，麦秆长高了，小鸟也强壮了。有一天，金黄成熟的麦子在微风中摇曳，农夫和他的儿子来到田里。“这麦子该收了，”农夫说，“我们必须叫邻居和朋友来帮我们收割。”附近巢里的小百灵鸟吓坏了，因为他们知道如果在收割者来之前不离开巢穴就会非常危险。当百灵鸟妈妈带回食物时，他们告诉了她听到的话。“别怕，孩子们，”百灵鸟妈妈说，“如果农夫说要叫邻居和朋友来帮忙，这麦子一时半会儿还收不了。”几天后，麦子熟透了，风吹过麦秆时，麦粒沙沙地落在小百灵鸟的头上。“如果这麦子不马上收，我们就得损失一半庄稼了，”农夫说，“我们不能再等朋友帮忙了。明天我们必须自己动手。”当小百灵鸟告诉妈妈那天听到的话时，她说：“那我们必须马上离开。当一个人决定自己动手而不依赖别人时，你可以肯定不会再拖延了。”那天下午大家忙着扑腾翅膀练习飞行，第二天日出时，当农夫和他的儿子割下麦子时，发现了一个空巢。
moral: Self-help is the best help.
moral_zh: 求人不如求己。

title: The Cat and the Old Rat
author: Aesop's Fables
content: There was once a Cat who was so watchful, that a Mouse hardly dared show the tip of his whiskers for fear of being eaten alive. That Cat seemed to be everywhere at once with his claws all ready for a pounce. At last the Mice kept so closely to their dens, that the Cat saw he would have to use his wits well to catch one. So one day he climbed up on a shelf and hung from it, head downward, as if he were dead, holding himself up by clinging to some ropes with one paw. When the Mice peeped out and saw him in that position, they thought he had been hung up there in punishment for some misdeed. Very timidly at first they stuck out their heads and sniffed about carefully. But as nothing stirred, all trooped joyfully out to celebrate the death of the Cat. Just then the Cat let go his hold, and before the Mice recovered from their surprise, he had made an end of three or four. Now the Mice kept more strictly at home than ever. But the Cat, who was still hungry for Mice, knew more tricks than one. Rolling himself in flour until he was covered completely, he lay down in the flour bin, with one eye open for the Mice. Sure enough, the Mice soon began to come out. To the Cat it was almost as if he already had a plump young Mouse under his claws, when an old Rat, who had had much experience with Cats and traps, and had even lost a part of his tail to pay for it, sat up at a safe distance from a hole in the wall where he lived. "Take care!" he cried. "That may be a heap of meal, but it looks to me very much like the Cat. Whatever it is, it is wisest to keep at a safe distance."
content_zh: 从前有一只猫非常警觉，老鼠几乎不敢露出胡须尖，生怕被活吃。那只猫似乎无处不在，爪子随时准备扑击。最后老鼠们紧闭洞门，猫意识到必须用脑子才能抓到一只。于是有一天，他爬上架子，倒挂着，仿佛死了一样，用一只爪子抓着绳子支撑着。当老鼠们探出头看到这姿势时，以为他是因为犯错被吊在那里受罚的。起初他们小心翼翼地探出头，仔细嗅探。但见没有动静，大家快乐地成群结队出来庆祝猫的死。就在这时，猫松开了手，在老鼠们从惊讶中恢复之前，他已经杀死了三四只。现在老鼠们比以前更严格地待在家里。但还想吃老鼠的猫不止这一个花招。他在面粉里打滚直到全身覆盖，然后躺在面粉箱里，睁只眼等着老鼠。果然，老鼠很快开始出来了。对猫来说，仿佛爪子下已经按住了一只肥嫩的小老鼠，这时一只老鼠，他对猫和陷阱非常有经验，甚至为此失去了一部分尾巴，在离洞口安全距离的地方坐了起来。“小心！”他喊道，“那可能是一堆面粉，但在我看来很像那只猫。不管那是什么，保持安全距离是最明智的。”
moral: The wise do not let themselves be tricked a second time.
moral_zh: 智者不会被骗第二次（吃一堑长一智）。

title: The Ass and His Shadow
author: Aesop's Fables
content: A Traveler had hired an Ass to carry him to a distant part of the country. The owner of the Ass went with the Traveler, walking beside him to drive the Ass and point out the way. The road led across a treeless plain where the Sun beat down fiercely. So intense did the heat become, that the Traveler at last decided to stop for a rest, and as there was no other shade to be found, the Traveler sat down in the shadow of the Ass. Now the heat had affected the Driver as much as it had the Traveler, and even more, for he had been walking. Wishing also to rest in the shade cast by the Ass, he began to quarrel with the Traveler, saying he had hired the Ass and not the shadow it cast. The two soon came to blows, and while they were fighting, the Ass took to its heels.
content_zh: 一个旅行者租了一头驴载他去远方。驴的主人陪旅行者一起去，走在旁边赶驴指路。路穿过一片没有树木的平原，阳光猛烈地照射着。热度变得如此强烈，旅行者最后决定停下来休息，因为找不到其他阴凉处，旅行者坐在了驴的影子里。现在，炎热对赶驴人的影响和对旅行者一样大，甚至更大，因为他一直在走路。他也想在驴投下的阴影里休息，于是开始和旅行者争吵，说他租的是驴，不是驴的影子。两人很快打了起来，正当他们打架时，驴撒腿跑了。
moral: In quarreling about the shadow we often lose the substance.
moral_zh: 因小失大（为了影子争吵往往失去了实体）。

title: The Wolf, the Kid, and the Goat
author: Aesop's Fables
content: Mother Goat was going to market one morning to get provisions for her household, which consisted of but one little Kid and herself. "Take good care of the house, my son," she said to the Kid, as she carefully latched the door. "Do not let anyone in, unless he gives you this password: 'Down with the Wolf and all his race!'" Strangely enough, a Wolf was lurking near and heard what the Goat had said. So, as soon as Mother Goat was out of sight, up he trotted to the door and knocked. "Down with the Wolf and all his race," said the Wolf softly. It was the right password, but when the Kid peeped through a crack in the door and saw the shadowy figure outside, he did not feel at all easy. "Show me a white paw," he said, "or I won't let you in." A white paw, of course, is a feature few Wolves can show, and so Master Wolf had to go away as hungry as he had come. "You can never be too sure," said the Kid, when he saw the Wolf making off to the woods.
content_zh: 一天早上，母山羊要去市场为家里买必需品，家里只有她和一只小山羊。“看好家，我的儿子，”她小心地锁上门时对小山羊说，“别让任何人进来，除非他能说出这个口令：‘打倒狼和他全家！’”奇怪的是，一只狼正潜伏在附近，听到了母山羊的话。所以，母山羊刚消失在视线中，他就跑到门口敲门。“打倒狼和他全家，”狼轻声说。口令是对的，但当小山羊通过门缝看到外面的黑影时，他感到一点也不踏实。“给我看看白爪子，”他说，“否则我不让你进来。”白爪子当然是很少有狼具备的特征，所以狼先生不得不饿着肚子走了。“永远不能太确信，”小山羊看到狼逃向树林时说。
moral: Two sureties are better than one.
moral_zh: 双重保险强过单一保险（小心驶得万年船）。

title: The Wolves and the Sheep
author: Aesop's Fables
content: A pack of Wolves lurked near the Sheep pasture. But the Dogs kept them all at a respectful distance, and the Sheep grazed in perfect safety. But now the Wolves thought of a plan to trick the Sheep. "Why is there always this hostility between us?" they said. "If it were not for those Dogs who are always stirring up trouble, I am sure we should get along beautifully. Send them away and you will see what good friends we shall become." The Sheep were easily fooled. They persuaded the Dogs to go away, and that very evening the Wolves had the grandest feast of their lives.
content_zh: 一群狼潜伏在羊牧场附近。但狗让他们保持着敬畏的距离，羊群非常安全地吃草。但现在狼想出了一个欺骗羊的计划。“为什么我们要一直敌对呢？”他们说，“如果不是那些总是挑拨离间的狗，我确信我们会相处得很好。把他们赶走，你会看到我们会成为多么好的朋友。”羊群很容易被骗了。他们说服狗离开，就在那天晚上，狼享受了他们一生中最盛大的宴席。
moral: Do not give up friends for foes.
moral_zh: 不要因为敌人而放弃朋友（唇亡齿寒）。

title: The Fighting Bulls and the Frog
author: Aesop's Fables
content: Two Bulls were fighting furiously in a field, at one side of which was a marsh. An old Frog living in the marsh, trembled as he watched the fierce battle. "What are you afraid of?" asked a young Frog. "Do you not see," replied the old Frog, "that the Bull who is beaten, will be driven away from the good forage up there to the reeds of this marsh, and we shall all be trampled into the mud?" It turned out as the Frog had said. The beaten Bull was driven to the marsh, where his great hoofs crushed the Frogs to death.
content_zh: 两头公牛在田野里激烈搏斗，田边有一片沼泽。住在沼泽里的一只老青蛙看着激战，瑟瑟发抖。“你怕什么？”一只年轻青蛙问。“难道你没看见，”老青蛙回答，“那头被打败的公牛会被赶出上面的好草地，逃到这片沼泽的芦苇丛里，我们都会被踩死在泥里吗？”结果正如青蛙所说。被打败的公牛被赶到了沼泽，他巨大的蹄子把青蛙踩死了。
moral: When the great fall out, the weak must suffer for it.
moral_zh: 神仙打架，凡人遭殃（城门失火，殃及池鱼）。

title: The Goatherd and the Wild Goats
author: Aesop's Fables
content: One cold stormy day a Goatherd drove his Goats for shelter into a cave, where a number of Wild Goats had also found their way. The Shepherd wanted to make the Wild Goats part of his flock; so he fed them well. But to his own flock, he gave only just enough food to keep them alive. When the weather cleared, and the Shepherd led the Goats out to feed, the Wild Goats scampered off to the hills. "Is that the thanks I get for feeding you and treating you so well?" complained the Shepherd. "Do not expect us to join your flock," replied one of the Wild Goats. "We know how you would treat us later on, if some strangers should come as we did."
content_zh: 一个寒冷的暴风雨天，牧羊人把他的山羊赶进一个山洞避难，那里也有一些野山羊。牧羊人想把野山羊变成自己羊群的一部分；所以他喂给他们好吃的。但对他自己的羊群，他只给了刚好维持生命的食物。当天气放晴，牧羊人带山羊出去吃草时，野山羊逃到了山上。“这就是我喂你们、对你们那么好得到的感谢吗？”牧羊人抱怨道。“别指望我们加入你的羊群，”一只野山羊回答，“我们知道如果以后有像我们一样的陌生人来，你会怎么对待我们（即喜新厌旧）。”
moral: It is unwise to treat old friends badly for the sake of new ones.
moral_zh: 为了新朋友而亏待老朋友是不明智的。

title: The Spendthrift and the Swallow
author: Aesop's Fables
content: A young fellow, who was very popular among his boon companions as a good spender, quickly wasted his fortune trying to live up to his reputation. Then one fine day in early spring he found himself with not a penny left, and no property save the clothes he wore. He was to meet some jolly young men that morning, and he was at his wits' end how to get enough money to keep up appearances. Just then a Swallow flew by, twittering merrily, and the young man, thinking summer had come, hastened off to a clothes dealer, to whom he sold all the clothes he wore down to his very tunic. A few days later a change in weather brought a severe frost; and the poor swallow and that foolish young man in his light tunic, and with his arms and knees bare, could scarcely keep life in their shivering bodies.
content_zh: 一个年轻小伙子，因为出手阔绰而在狐朋狗友中很受欢迎，为了维持名声很快挥霍掉了财产。早春的一个好天气，他发现自己身无分文，除了身上的衣服别无长物。那天早上他要去见一些快乐的年轻人，正为如何弄到钱撑门面而发愁。就在这时，一只燕子快乐地叫着飞过，年轻人以为夏天来了，急忙跑到旧衣商那里，卖掉了所有的衣服，只剩下一件单衣。几天后天气突变，严霜降临；可怜的燕子和那个只穿单衣、露着胳膊膝盖的愚蠢年轻人，冻得瑟瑟发抖，几乎保不住性命。
moral: One swallow does not make a summer.
moral_zh: 一燕不成夏（孤证不立）。

title: The Miser
author: Aesop's Fables
content: A Miser had buried his gold in a secret place in his garden. Every day he went to the spot, dug up the treasure and counted it piece by piece to make sure it was all there. He made so many trips that a Thief, who had been observing him, guessed what it was the Miser had hidden, and one night quietly dug up the treasure and made off with it. When the Miser discovered his loss, he was overcome with grief and despair. He groaned and cried and tore his hair. A passerby heard his cries and asked what had happened. "My gold! O my gold!" cried the Miser, wildly, "someone has robbed me!" "Your gold! There in that hole? Why did you put it there? Why did you not keep it in the house where you could easily get it when you had to buy things?" "Buy!" screamed the Miser angrily. "Why, I never touched the gold. I couldn't think of spending any of it." The stranger picked up a large stone and threw it into the hole. "If that is the case," he said, "cover up that stone. It is worth just as much to you as the treasure you lost!"
content_zh: 一个守财奴把金子埋在花园的一个秘密地方。每天他都去那里，挖出宝藏一块一块地数，确保都在。他去得太频繁了，以至于一个小偷观察到了，猜到了守财奴藏了什么，一天晚上悄悄挖出宝藏偷走了。当守财奴发现损失时，悲痛欲绝。他呻吟哭泣，撕扯头发。一个路人听到哭声问发生了什么。“我的金子！哦，我的金子！”守财奴疯狂地喊道，“有人抢了我！”“你的金子！就在那个洞里？你为什么要放在那儿？为什么不放在屋里，买东西方便拿呢？”“买！”守财奴愤怒地尖叫，“哎呀，我从来不碰那些金子。我想都没想过花它。”陌生人捡起一块大石头扔进洞里。“如果是那样，”他说，“埋上这块石头吧。它对你的价值和你失去的宝藏一样大！”
moral: A possession is worth no more than the use we make of it.
moral_zh: 财富的价值在于使用它（物尽其用）。

title: The Bat and the Weasels
author: Aesop's Fables
content: A Bat blundered into the nest of a Weasel, who ran up to catch and eat him. The Bat begged for his life, but the Weasel would not listen. "You are a Mouse," he said, "and I am a sworn enemy of Mice. Every Mouse I catch, I am going to eat!" "But I am not a Mouse!" cried the Bat. "Look at my wings. Can Mice fly? Why, I am only a Bird! Please let me go!" The Weasel had to admit that the Bat was not a Mouse, so he let him go. But a few days later, the foolish Bat went blindly into the nest of another Weasel. This Weasel happened to be a bitter enemy of Birds, and he soon had the Bat under his claws, ready to eat him. "You are a Bird," he said, "and I am going to eat you!" "What," cried the Bat, "I, a Bird! Why, all Birds have feathers! I am nothing but a Mouse. 'Down with all Cats,' is my motto!" And so the Bat escaped with his life a second time.
content_zh: 一只蝙蝠误闯进了一只鼬鼠的窝，鼬鼠冲上来要吃他。蝙蝠求饶，但鼬鼠不听。“你是老鼠，”他说，“我是老鼠的死敌。抓住老鼠我就吃！”“但我不是老鼠！”蝙蝠叫道，“看我的翅膀。老鼠会飞吗？我只是一只鸟！请放我走！”鼬鼠不得不承认蝙蝠不是老鼠，便放了他。但几天后，这只愚蠢的蝙蝠又瞎撞进了另一只鼬鼠的窝。这只鼬鼠恰好是鸟类的死敌，很快把蝙蝠按在爪下准备吃掉。“你是鸟，”他说，“我要吃了你！”“什么，”蝙蝠叫道，“我，一只鸟！哎呀，所有鸟都有羽毛！我只是一只老鼠。‘打倒所有猫’是我的座右铭！”就这样，蝙蝠第二次逃脱了性命。
moral: Set your sails with the wind.
moral_zh: 见风使舵（随机应变）。

title: The Fox and the Monkey
author: Aesop's Fables
content: At a great meeting of the Animals, who had gathered to elect a new ruler, the Monkey was asked to dance. This he did so well, with a thousand funny capers and grimaces, that the Animals were carried entirely off their feet with enthusiasm, and then and there, elected him their king. The Fox did not vote for the Monkey and was much disgusted with the Animals for electing so unworthy a ruler. One day he found a trap with a bit of meat in it. Hurrying to King Monkey, he told him he had found a rich treasure, which he had not touched because it belonged by right to his majesty the Monkey. The greedy Monkey followed the Fox to the trap. As soon as he saw the meat he grasped eagerly for it, only to find himself held fast in the trap. The Fox stood off and laughed. "You pretend to be our king," he said, "and cannot even take care of yourself!" Shortly after that, another election among the Animals was held.
content_zh: 在动物们聚集选举新统治者的盛大集会上，猴子被要求跳舞。他跳得太好了，做了一千个滑稽的动作和鬼脸，动物们热情高涨，当场推选他为王。狐狸没投猴子的票，对动物们选出这么不称职的统治者感到非常厌恶。一天，他发现了一个放了肉的捕兽夹。他急忙跑去告诉猴王，说发现了一件珍宝，他没敢动，因为这理应属于猴王陛下。贪婪的猴子跟着狐狸来到陷阱前。一看到肉，他就急切地去抓，结果被牢牢夹住。狐狸站在一旁大笑。“你假装是我们的国王，”他说，“却连自己都照顾不了！”那之后不久，动物们又举行了一次选举。
moral: The true leader proves himself by his qualities.
moral_zh: 真正的领袖靠品质证明自己（德不配位，必有灾殃）。

title: The Lion and the Mouse
author: Aesop's Fables
content: A Lion lay asleep in the forest, his great head resting on his paws. A timid little Mouse came upon him unexpectedly, and in her fright and haste to get away, ran across the Lion's nose. Roused from his nap, the Lion laid his huge paw angrily on the tiny creature to kill her. "Spare me!" begged the poor Mouse. "Please let me go and some day I will surely repay you." The Lion was much amused to think that a Mouse could ever help him. But he was generous and finally let the Mouse go. Some days later, while stalking his prey in the forest, the Lion was caught in the toils of a hunter's net. Unable to free himself, he filled the forest with his angry roaring. The Mouse knew the voice and quickly found the Lion struggling in the net. Running to one of the great ropes that bound him, she gnawed it until it parted, and soon the Lion was free. "You laughed when I said I would repay you," said the Mouse. "Now you see that even a Mouse can help a Lion."
content_zh: 一只狮子在森林里睡觉，巨大的头枕在爪子上。一只胆小的老鼠意外撞见了他，惊慌逃跑时跑过了狮子的鼻子。狮子被从睡梦中惊醒，愤怒地把巨大的爪子按在这个小生物身上要杀她。“饶了我吧！”可怜的老鼠乞求道，“请放我走，总有一天我会报答你的。”狮子觉得老鼠能帮他这个想法很可笑。但他很宽宏大量，最终放走了老鼠。几天后，狮子在森林里捕食时，被猎人的网困住了。他无法脱身，愤怒的吼声响彻森林。老鼠听出了声音，很快发现狮子在网里挣扎。她跑过去咬断了绑着他的大绳子，很快狮子就自由了。“我说我会报答你时你笑了，”老鼠说，“现在你看到，即使是老鼠也能帮助狮子。”
moral: A kindness is never wasted.
moral_zh: 善行永远不会白费（勿以善小而不为）。

title: The Crow and the Pitcher
author: Aesop's Fables
content: In a spell of dry weather, when the Birds could find very little to drink, a thirsty Crow found a pitcher with a little water in it. But the pitcher was high and had a narrow neck, and no matter how he tried, the Crow could not reach the water. The poor thing felt as if he must die of thirst. Then an idea came to him. Picking up some small pebbles, he dropped them into the pitcher one by one. With each pebble the water rose a little higher until at last it was near enough so he could drink.
content_zh: 在一段干旱的日子里，鸟儿们几乎找不到水喝，一只口渴的乌鸦发现了一个只有一点水的水罐。但水罐很高，瓶口很窄，无论乌鸦怎么试，都够不着水。可怜的家伙觉得自己要渴死了。这时他想到了一个主意。他捡起一些小石子，一颗一颗扔进水罐里。随着每颗石子的落下，水位升高了一点，最后终于高到他可以喝到了。
moral: In a pinch a good use of our wits may help us out.
moral_zh: 在紧要关头，善用智慧可以帮我们脱困（乌鸦喝水）。

title: The Boys and the Frogs
author: Aesop's Fables
content: Some Boys were playing one day at the edge of a pond in which lived a family of Frogs. The Boys amused themselves by throwing stones into the pond so as to make them skip on top of the water. The stones were flying thick and fast and the Boys were enjoying themselves very much; but the poor Frogs in the pond were trembling with fear. At last one of the Frogs, the oldest and bravest, put his head out of the water, and said, "Oh, please, dear children, stop your cruel play! Though it may be fun for you, it means death to us!"
content_zh: 一天，几个男孩在住着一窝青蛙的池塘边玩耍。男孩们扔石头打水漂取乐。石头密集而快速地飞来，男孩们玩得很开心；但池塘里可怜的青蛙却吓得发抖。最后，其中一只最老最勇敢的青蛙把头伸出水面说：“哦，求求你们，亲爱的孩子们，停止你们残酷的游戏吧！虽然这对你们来说很有趣，但对我们来说意味着死亡！”
moral: Always stop to think whether your fun may not be the cause of another's unhappiness.
moral_zh: 不要把快乐建立在别人的痛苦之上。

title: The Ant and the Dove
author: Aesop's Fables
content: A Dove saw an Ant fall into a brook. The Ant struggled in vain to reach the bank, and in pity, the Dove dropped a blade of straw close beside it. Clinging to the straw like a shipwrecked sailor to a broken spar, the Ant floated safely to shore. Soon after, the Ant saw a man getting ready to kill the Dove with a stone. But just as he cast the stone, the Ant stung him in the heel, so that the pain made him miss his aim, and the startled Dove flew to safety in a distant wood.
content_zh: 一只鸽子看到一只蚂蚁掉进了小溪。蚂蚁挣扎着想爬上岸，但徒劳无功，鸽子出于同情，叼了一根稻草扔到它旁边。蚂蚁像遭遇海难的水手抓着断桅杆一样紧紧抓住稻草，安全地漂到了岸边。不久之后，蚂蚁看到一个人正准备用石头打死鸽子。正当他要扔石头时，蚂蚁咬了他的脚后跟一口，疼痛让他失了准头，受惊的鸽子飞到了远处安全的树林里。
moral: A kindness is never wasted.
moral_zh: 善行永远不会白费。

title: The Wolf and the Crane
author: Aesop's Fables
content: A Wolf had been gorging on an animal he had killed, when suddenly a small bone in the meat stuck in his throat and he could not swallow it. He soon felt terrible pain in his throat, and ran up and down groaning and groaning and seeking for something to relieve the pain. He tried to induce every one he met to remove the bone. "I would give anything," said he, "if you would take it out." At last the Crane agreed to try, and told the Wolf to lie on his side and open his jaws as wide as he could. Then the Crane put its long neck down the Wolf's throat, and with its beak loosened the bone, till at last he got it out. "Will you kindly give me the reward you promised?" said the Crane. The Wolf grinned and showed his teeth and said: "Be content. You have put your head inside a Wolf's mouth and taken it out again in safety; that ought to be reward enough for you."
content_zh: 一只狼正在大口吞食他杀死的动物，突然一块小骨头卡在了喉咙里，吞不下去。他喉咙剧痛，跑来跑去呻吟着，寻找缓解痛苦的办法。他试图恳求遇到的每个人帮他取骨头。“只要你帮我取出来，你要什么我都给，”他说。最后鹤同意试试，让狼侧躺下，把嘴张大。鹤把长脖子伸进狼的喉咙，用喙把骨头弄松，最后取了出来。“请给我你承诺的报酬好吗？”鹤说。狼咧嘴露出牙齿说：“知足吧。你把头伸进狼嘴里还能安全拿出来；这对你来说已经是足够的报酬了。”
moral: Gratitude and greed go not together.
moral_zh: 贪婪的人不懂感恩（农夫与蛇）。

title: The Farmer and His Sons
author: Aesop's Fables
content: A rich old farmer, who felt that he had not many more days to live, called his sons to his bedside. "My sons," he said, "heed what I have to say to you. Do not on any account part with the estate that has belonged to our family for so many generations. Somewhere on it is hidden a rich treasure. I do not know the exact spot, but it is there, and you will surely find it. Spare no energy and leave no spot unturned in your search." The father died, and no sooner was he in his grave than the sons set to work digging with all their might, turning up every foot of ground with their spades, and going over the whole farm two or three times. No hidden gold did they find; but at harvest time when they had settled their accounts and had pocketed a rich profit far greater than that of any of their neighbors, they understood that the treasure their father had told them about was the wealth of a bountiful crop, and that in their industry had they found the treasure.
content_zh: 一个富有的老农夫觉得自己时日无多，把儿子们叫到床前。“儿子们，”他说，“听好我要说的话。无论如何不要卖掉我们家族几代相传的土地。那里某个地方藏着丰富的宝藏。我不知道确切位置，但它就在那里，你们一定会找到的。不遗余力，挖遍每一寸土地去寻找。”父亲死后，刚下葬不久，儿子们就全力挖掘，用铲子翻遍了每一寸土地，整个农场翻了两三遍。他们没找到隐藏的金子；但在收获季节，当他们结清账目，获得了远超邻居的丰厚利润时，他们明白了父亲所说的宝藏就是丰收的财富，他们的辛勤劳动就是宝藏。
moral: Industry is itself a treasure.
moral_zh: 勤劳本身就是宝藏。

title: The Two Goats
author: Aesop's Fables
content: Two Goats, frisking gayly on the rocky steeps of a mountain valley, chanced to meet, one on each side of a deep chasm through which poured a mighty mountain torrent. The trunk of a fallen tree formed the only means of crossing the chasm, and on this not even two squirrels could have passed each other in safety. The narrow path would have made the bravest tremble. Not so our Goats. Their pride would not permit either to stand aside for the other. One set her foot on the log. The other did likewise. In the middle they met horn to horn. Neither would give way, and so they both fell, to be swept away by the roaring torrent below.
content_zh: 两只山羊在山谷陡峭的岩石上快乐地嬉戏，偶然在一条深渊两边相遇，深渊下面是汹涌的山洪。一棵倒下的树干是过深渊的唯一途径，上面连两只松鼠都无法安全错车。狭窄的路径会让最勇敢的人发抖。但我们的山羊不会。他们的骄傲不允许任何一方让路。一只踏上了圆木。另一只也踏了上去。在中间他们角对角相遇了。谁也不肯让步，于是他们都掉下去了，被下面咆哮的洪流卷走。
moral: It is better to yield than to come to misfortune through stubbornness.
moral_zh: 退一步海阔天空（固执导致不幸）。

title: The Ass and the Load of Salt
author: Aesop's Fables
content: A Merchant, driving his Ass homeward from the seashore with a heavy load of salt, came to a river crossed by a shallow ford. They had crossed this river many times before without accident, but this time the Ass slipped and fell when halfway over. And when the Merchant at last got him to his feet, much of the salt had melted away. Delighted to find how much lighter his burden had become, the Ass finished the journey very gayly. Next day the Merchant went for another load of salt. On the way home the Ass, remembering what had happened at the ford, purposely let himself fall into the water, and again got rid of most of his burden. The angry Merchant immediately turned about and drove the Ass back to the seashore, where he loaded him with two great baskets of sponges. At the ford the Ass again tumbled over; but when he had scrambled to his feet, it was a very disconsolate Ass that dragged himself homeward under a load ten times heavier than before.
content_zh: 一个商人赶着他的驴子，驮着重重的一袋盐从海边回家，来到一条有浅滩的河边。他们以前多次安全渡过这条河，但这一次驴子走到一半时滑倒了。当商人终于让他站起来时，大部分盐已经融化了。发现负担变轻了这么多，驴子非常高兴地完成了旅程。第二天，商人又去运盐。在回家的路上，驴子记起在浅滩发生的事，故意让自己跌进水里，又一次摆脱了大部分负担。愤怒的商人立刻转身赶着驴子回到海边，在那里给他装了两大筐海绵。在浅滩处，驴子又跌倒了；但当他爬起来时，这只沮丧的驴子不得不拖着比以前重十倍的负担回家。
moral: The same measures will not suit all circumstances.
moral_zh: 同样的方法并不适用于所有情况（弄巧成拙）。

title: The Lion and the Gnat
author: Aesop's Fables
content: "Away with you, vile insect!" said a Lion angrily to a Gnat that was buzzing around his head. But the Gnat was not in the least disturbed. "Do you think," he said spitefully to the Lion, "that I am afraid of you because they call you king?" The next instant he flew at the Lion and stung him sharply on the nose. Mad with rage, the Lion struck fiercely at the Gnat, but only succeeded in tearing himself with his claws. Again and again the Gnat stung the Lion, who now was roaring terribly. At last, worn out with rage and covered with wounds that his own teeth and claws had made, the Lion gave up the fight. The Gnat buzzed away to tell the whole world about his victory, but instead he flew straight into a spider's web. And there, he who had defeated the King of beasts came to a miserable end, the prey of a little spider.
content_zh: “滚开，卑鄙的昆虫！”狮子对一只在他头边嗡嗡叫的蚊子愤怒地说。但蚊子一点也没被吓到。“你以为，”他恶毒地对狮子说，“因为他们叫你国王我就怕你吗？”下一瞬间他飞向狮子，狠狠地叮了他的鼻子。狮子气得发疯，猛烈地拍打蚊子，但只把自己的脸抓破了。蚊子一次又一次地叮咬狮子，狮子发出可怕的吼声。最后，狮子精疲力竭，满身都是自己牙齿和爪子造成的伤口，放弃了战斗。蚊子嗡嗡叫着飞走，想告诉全世界他的胜利，但他却径直飞进了一张蜘蛛网。在那里，这个打败了万兽之王的家伙迎来了悲惨的结局，成了一只小蜘蛛的猎物。
moral:
The least of our enemies is often the most to be feared.
Pride over a success should not throw us off our guard.
moral_zh: 最小的敌人往往最可怕。胜利后的骄傲不应让我们放松警惕。

title: The Monkey and the Camel
author: Aesop's Fables
content: At a great celebration in honor of King Lion, the Monkey was asked to dance for the company. His dancing was very clever indeed, and the animals were all highly pleased with his grace and lightness. The praise that was showered on the Monkey made the Camel envious. He was very sure that he could dance quite as well as the Monkey, if not better, so he pushed his way into the crowd that was gathered around the Monkey, and rising on his hind legs, began to dance. But the big hulking Camel made himself very ridiculous as he kicked out his knotty legs and twisted his long clumsy neck. Besides, the animals found it hard to keep their toes from under his heavy hoofs. At last, when one of his huge feet came within an inch of King Lion's nose, the animals were so disgusted that they set upon the Camel in a rage and drove him out into the desert. Shortly afterward, refreshments, consisting mostly of Camel's hump and ribs, were served to the company.
