content_zh: 在为狮子王举行的盛大庆典上，猴子被邀请为大家跳舞。他的舞姿确实非常灵巧，动物们都对他优雅轻盈的动作非常满意。对猴子的赞美让骆驼心生嫉妒。他确信自己也能跳得和猴子一样好，甚至更好，于是他挤进围观猴子的人群，用后腿站立起来，开始跳舞。但这只笨重的骆驼踢着满是疙瘩的腿，扭着细长笨拙的脖子，让自己看起来非常可笑。而且，动物们很难不被他沉重的蹄子踩到脚。最后，当他的一只大脚差点踢到狮子王的鼻子时，动物们非常厌恶，愤怒地攻击骆驼，把他赶到了沙漠里。不久之后，大家享用了点心，主要是骆驼峰和骆驼排骨。
moral: Do not try to ape your betters.
moral_zh: 东施效颦。

title: The Wild Boar and the Fox
author: Aesop's Fables
content: A Wild Boar was sharpening his tusks busily against the stump of a tree, when a Fox happened by. Now the Fox was always looking for a chance to make fun of his neighbors. So he made a great show of looking anxiously about, as if in fear of some hidden enemy. But the Boar kept right on with his work. "Why are you doing that?" asked the Fox at last with a grin. "There isn't any danger that I can see." "True enough," replied the Boar, "but when danger does come there will not be time for such work as this. My weapons will have to be ready for use then, or I shall suffer for it."
content_zh: 一只野猪正忙着在树桩上磨牙，这时一只狐狸路过。狐狸总是找机会取笑邻居。通过他故意装出焦虑的样子四处张望，好像害怕有什么隐藏的敌人。但野猪继续干他的活。“你为什么那样做？”狐狸最后咧嘴笑着问，“我看没什么危险啊。”“确实，”野猪回答，“但当危险真的来临时，就没有时间做这种工作了。那时我的武器必须准备好，否则我就会吃亏。”
moral: Preparedness for war is the best guarantee of peace.
moral_zh: 居安思危，有备无患。

title: The Ass, the Fox, and the Lion
author: Aesop's Fables
content: An Ass and a Fox had become close comrades, and were constantly in each other's company. While the Ass cropped a fresh bit of greens, the Fox would devour a chicken from the neighboring farmyard or a bit of cheese filched from the dairy. One day the pair unexpectedly met a Lion. The Ass was very much frightened, but the Fox calmed his fears. "I will talk to him," he said. So the Fox walked boldly up to the Lion. "Your highness," he said in an undertone, so the Ass could not hear him, "I've got a fine scheme in my head. If you promise not to hurt me, I will lead that foolish creature yonder into a pit where he can't get out, and you can feast at your pleasure." The Lion agreed and the Fox returned to the Ass. "I made him promise not to hurt us," said the Fox. "But come, I know a good place to hide till he is gone." So the Fox led the Ass into a deep pit. But when the Lion saw that the Ass was his for the taking, he first of all struck down the traitor Fox.
content_zh: 一头驴和一只狐狸成了亲密伙伴，总是形影不离。驴子吃新鲜的青草时，狐狸就吃从邻居农场偷来的鸡或从奶牛场顺来的奶酪。一天，这对搭档意外遇到了一只狮子。驴子吓得不轻，但狐狸安抚了他。“我去跟他谈谈，”他说。于是狐狸大胆地走到狮子面前。“陛下，”他低声说，不想让驴子听见，“我有个好主意。如果您答应不伤害我，我就把那个愚蠢的家伙引到一个出不来的坑里，您可以尽情享用。”狮子同意了，狐狸回到驴子身边。“我让他答应不伤害我们了，”狐狸说，“不过来吧，我知道个躲藏的好地方，等他走了再说。”于是狐狸把驴子引到了一个深坑里。但当狮子看到驴子已经是囊中之物时，他首先打死了背叛朋友的狐狸。
moral: Traitors may expect treachery.
moral_zh: 背叛者必遭背叛。

title: The Birds, the Beasts, and the Bat
author: Aesop's Fables
content: The Birds and the Beasts declared war against each other. No compromise was possible, and so they went at it tooth and claw. It is said the quarrel grew out of the persecution the race of Geese suffered at the teeth of the Fox family. The Beasts, too, had cause for fight. The Eagle was constantly pouncing on the Hare, and the Owl dined daily on Mice. It was a terrible battle. Many a Hare and many a Mouse died. Chickens and Geese fell by the score—and the victor always stopped for a feast. Now the Bat family had not openly joined either side. They were a very politic race. So when they saw the Birds getting the better of it, they were Birds for all there was in it. But when the tide of battle turned, they immediately sided with the Beasts. When the battle was over, the conduct of the Bats was discussed at the peace conference. Such deceit was unpardonable, and Birds and Beasts made common cause to drive out the Bats. And since then the Bat family hides in dark towers and deserted ruins, flying out only in the night.
content_zh: 鸟类和兽类宣战了。没有妥协的可能，于是它们展开了殊死搏斗。据说这是因为鹅族受到狐狸家族的迫害引发的争吵。兽类也有战斗的理由。鹰不断扑杀野兔，猫头鹰每天吃老鼠。这是一场可怕的战斗。许多野兔和老鼠死去了。鸡和鹅成批倒下——胜利者总是停下来享用盛宴。蝙蝠家族没有公开加入任何一方。它们是非常圆滑的种族。所以当它们看到鸟类占上风时，它们就全力支持鸟类。但当战局逆转时，它们立即倒向兽类。战斗结束后，在和平会议上讨论了蝙蝠的行为。这种欺骗行为是不可原谅的，鸟类和兽类联合起来驱逐了蝙蝠。从此以后，蝙蝠家族就躲在黑暗的塔楼和废墟中，只在夜间飞出来。
moral: The deceitful have no friends.
moral_zh: 骗子没有朋友。

title: The Sheep and the Pig
author: Aesop's Fables
content: One day a shepherd discovered a fat Pig in the meadow where his Sheep were pastured. He very quickly captured the porker, which squealed at the top of its voice the moment the Shepherd laid his hands on it. You would have thought, to hear the loud squealing, that the Pig was being cruelly hurt. But in spite of its squeals and struggles to escape, the Shepherd tucked his prize under his arm and started off to the butcher's in the market place. The Sheep in the pasture were much astonished and amused at the Pig's behavior, and followed the Shepherd and his charge to the pasture gate. "What makes you squeal like that?" asked one of the Sheep. "The Shepherd often catches and carries off one of us. But we should feel very much ashamed to make such a terrible fuss about it like you do." "That is all very well," replied the Pig, with a squeal and a frantic kick. "When he catches you he is only after your wool. But he wants my bacon! gree-ee-ee!"
content_zh: 一天，牧羊人发现他的羊群吃草的牧场里有一只肥猪。他很快抓住了这只猪，牧羊人一碰它，它就拼命尖叫。听到那响亮的尖叫声，你还会以为这只猪受到了残酷的伤害。但尽管它尖叫挣扎着想逃跑，牧羊人还是夹着战利品前往市场的肉铺。牧场里的羊对猪的行为感到非常惊讶和好笑，跟着牧羊人和他的猎物走到牧场门口。“你为什么叫成那样？”一只羊问，“牧羊人经常抓我们中的一个带走。但如果像你这样大吵大闹，我们会感到非常羞愧。”“说得轻巧，”猪一边尖叫一边疯狂踢打回答道，“他抓你们只是为了要你们的毛。但他想要我的肉啊！唧——唧——唧！”
moral: It is easy to be brave when there is no danger.
moral_zh: 站着说话不腰疼（没有危险时表现勇敢很容易）。

title: The Travelers and the Purse
author: Aesop's Fables
content: Two men were traveling in company along the road when one of them picked up a well-filled purse. "How lucky I am!" he said. "I have found a purse. Judging by its weight it must be full of gold." "Do not say 'I have found a purse,'" said his companion. "Say rather 'we have found a purse' and 'how lucky we are.' Travelers ought to share alike the fortunes or misfortunes of the road." "No, no," replied the other angrily. "I found it and I am going to keep it." Just then they heard a shout of "Stop, thief!" and looking around, saw a mob of people armed with clubs coming down the road. The man who had found the purse fell into a panic. "We are lost if they find the purse on us," he cried. "No, no," replied the other, "You would not say 'we' before, so now stick to your 'I'. Say 'I am lost.'"
content_zh: 两个人在路上结伴而行，其中一人捡到了一个装得满满的钱包。“我真幸运！”他说，“我捡到了一个钱包。看这重量里面肯定装满了金子。”“别说‘我捡到了一个钱包’，”他的同伴说，“应该说‘我们捡到了一个钱包’，还有‘我们真幸运’。旅行者应该同甘共苦。”“不，不，”那人愤怒地回答，“是我捡到的，我要自己留着。”就在这时，他们听到有人喊“抓贼啊！”，回头一看，一群人拿着木棍冲了过来。捡到钱包的人慌了。“如果我们被发现身上有钱包，我们就完了，”他叫道。“不，不，”同伴回答，“你之前不肯说‘我们’，所以现在坚持你的‘我’吧。说‘我完了’。”
moral: We cannot expect any one to share our misfortunes unless we are willing to share our good fortune also.
moral_zh: 除非我们愿意分享好运，否则不能指望别人分担我们的不幸。

title: The Wolf and His Shadow
author: Aesop's Fables
content: A Wolf left his lair one evening in fine spirits and an excellent appetite. As he ran, the setting sun cast his shadow far out on the ground, and it looked as if the wolf were a hundred times bigger than he really was. "Why," exclaimed the Wolf proudly, "see how big I am! Fancy me running away from a puny Lion! I'll show him who is fit to be king, he or I." Just then an immense shadow blotted him out entirely, and the next instant a Lion struck him down with a single blow.
content_zh: 一天傍晚，一只狼离开巢穴，精神饱满，胃口极好。当他奔跑时，落日把他的影子在地上拉得很长，看起来比他实际大了一百倍。“哇，”狼骄傲地惊叹，“看我有多大！想想我竟然还要躲避一只瘦小的狮子！我要让他看看谁才配当国王，是他还是我。”就在这时，一个巨大的阴影完全遮住了他，下一瞬间，一只狮子一巴掌把他打倒在地。
moral: Do not let your fancy make you forget realities.
moral_zh: 不要让幻想使你忘记现实（要有自知之明）。

title: The Oak and the Reeds
author: Aesop's Fables
content: A Giant Oak stood near a brook in which grew some slender Reeds. When the wind blew, the great Oak stood proudly upright with its hundred arms, battling with the storm. But the Reeds bowed low in the wind and sang a sad and mournful song. "You have reason to complain," said the Oak. "The slightest breeze that ruffles the surface of the water makes you bow your heads, while I, the mighty Oak, stand upright and firm before the howling tempest." "Do not worry about us," replied the Reeds. "The winds do not harm us. We bow before them and so we do not break. You, in all your pride and strength, have so far resisted their blows. But the end is coming." As the Reeds spoke a great hurricane rushed out of the north. The Oak stood proudly and fought against the storm, while the yielding Reeds bowed low. The wind redoubled in fury, and all at once the great tree fell, torn up by the roots, and lay among the pitying Reeds.
content_zh: 一棵巨大的橡树站在小溪边，溪里长着一些纤细的芦苇。当风吹来时，巨大的橡树骄傲地挺立着，用它的百条手臂与风暴搏斗。但芦苇在风中低头弯腰，唱着悲伤的歌。“你们有理由抱怨，”橡树说，“微风吹皱水面就把你们吹得低头，而我，强大的橡树，在怒号的暴风雨面前挺立不倒。”“别担心我们，”芦苇回答，“风伤不到我们。我们在风面前弯腰，所以我们不会折断。你，凭着所有的骄傲和力量，到现在为止抵抗了风的打击。但结局快来了。”正当芦苇说话时，一场大飓风从北方袭来。橡树骄傲地站立着，与风暴对抗，而顺从的芦苇则深深低下头。风势加倍猛烈，突然，大树倒了，被连根拔起，倒在怜悯它的芦苇丛中。
moral: Better to yield when it is folly to resist, than to resist stubbornly and be destroyed.
moral_zh: 识时务者为俊杰（在抵抗是愚蠢的时候，妥协比顽抗被毁灭要好）。

title: The Rich Man and the Tanner
author: Aesop's Fables
content: A rich man bought a house next to a Tanner. Soon he found that the smell was more than he could bear. He went to the Tanner and tried to get him to move. But the Tanner kept putting it off, saying he would move in a little while. This went on for some time, until at last the rich man got used to the smell and made no more complaints.
content_zh: 一个富人买了一栋房子，隔壁是个制革匠。很快他发现那气味让他无法忍受。他去找制革匠，试图让他搬走。但制革匠一直推脱，说过一阵子就搬。这样过了一段时间，最后富人习惯了那气味，也就不再抱怨了。
moral: We can get used to anything.
moral_zh: 习惯成自然（入鲍鱼之肆，久而不闻其臭）。

title: The Owl and the Grasshopper
author: Aesop's Fables
content: The Owl always takes her sleep during the day. Then after sundown, when the rosy light fades from the sky and the shadows rise slowly through the wood, out she comes ruffling and blinking from the old hollow tree. Now her weird "hoo-hoo-hoo-oo-oo" echoes through the quiet wood, and she begins her hunt for the bugs and beetles, frogs and mice that she likes so well to eat. Now there was a certain old Owl who had become very cross and hard to please as she grew older, especially if anything disturbed her daily slumbers. One warm summer afternoon as she dozed away in her den in the old oak tree, a Grasshopper nearby began a joyous but very raspy song. Out popped the old Owl's head from the opening in the tree that served her both for door and for window. "Get away from here, sir," she said to the Grasshopper. "Have you no manners? You should at least respect my age and leave me to sleep in quiet!" But the Grasshopper answered saucily that he had as much right to his place in the sun as the Owl had to her place in the old oak. Then he struck up a louder and still more rasping tune. The wise old Owl knew quite well that it would do no good to argue with the Grasshopper, nor with anybody else for that matter. Besides, her eyes were not sharp enough by day to permit her to punish the Grasshopper as he deserved. So she laid aside all hard words and spoke very kindly to him. "Well sir," she said, "if I must stay awake, I am going to settle right down to enjoy your singing. Now that I think of it, I have a wonderful wine here, sent me from Olympus, of which I am told Apollo drinks before he sings to the high gods. Please come up and taste this delicious drink with me. I know it will make you sing like Apollo himself." The foolish Grasshopper was taken in by the Owl's flattering words. Up he jumped to the Owl's den, but as soon as he was near enough so the old Owl could see him clearly, she pounced upon him and ate him up.
content_zh: 猫头鹰总是在白天睡觉。日落后，当天空玫瑰色的光芒褪去，阴影缓缓升起穿过树林时，她就从那棵古老的空心树里扑腾着翅膀，眨着眼睛出来了。现在她怪异的“呼-呼-呼-呜-呜”声回荡在寂静的树林里，她开始捕猎她最爱吃的虫子、甲虫、青蛙和老鼠。有一只老猫头鹰，年纪越大脾气越坏，越难伺候，特别是如果什么东西打扰了她白天的睡眠。一个温暖的夏日午后，当她在老橡树的巢穴里打瞌睡时，附近一只蚂蚱开始唱起欢快但非常刺耳的歌。老猫头鹰把头从那个既当门又当窗的树洞伸出来。“滚远点，先生，”她对蚂蚱说，“你没礼貌吗？你至少应该尊重我的年纪，让我安静地睡觉！”但蚂蚱傲慢地回答说，他在阳光下待着的权利和猫头鹰在老橡树里待着的权利一样大。然后他唱起了更响亮、更刺耳的曲子。聪明的老猫头鹰很清楚，和蚂蚱争论没什么用，和谁争论都没用。而且，她的眼睛在白天不够敏锐，无法按他应得的那样惩罚蚂蚱。于是她收起所有严厉的话，非常和蔼地对他说。“好吧，先生，”她说，“既然我不得不醒着，我就打算好好享受你的歌声。既然我想到了，我这里有一瓶美酒，是从奥林匹斯山送来的，据说阿波罗在给众神唱歌之前就是喝这种酒。请上来和我一起品尝这美味的饮料。我知道这会让你唱得像阿波罗本人一样好。”愚蠢的蚂蚱被猫头鹰的奉承话骗了。他跳上猫头鹰的巢穴，但他一靠近到老猫头鹰能看清他的地方，她就扑向他把他吃掉了。
moral:
Flattery is not a proof of true admiration.
Do not let flattery throw you off your guard against an enemy.
moral_zh: 奉承不是真正钦佩的证明（口蜜腹剑）。不要让奉承使你对敌人放松警惕。
